reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: The Bureau: XCOM Declassified
Original Release: 2013
Genre Tags: Action; Tactical; Third-Person; Strategy; RPG; Sci-Fi; Story Rich
My Overall Grade: B+
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 10-25 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: None
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Fans of the intellectual property; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseurs
REVIEWThe Bureau: XCOM Declassified is an action-tactical, third-person shooter that incorporates cover systems, tactical pausing, and squad commands to make for riveting combat scenarios.  The story is fairly enthralling and while the characters are definitely cliché, I thought they were diverse and interesting enough, with the exception being the unquestionably boring main character.  It is far from perfect, but I enjoyed it, that much I know.  I think if you like games in this style, then you will probably enjoy it too; but if you’re someone who easily dislikes things that aren’t absolutely perfectly crafted, you may want to reconsider trying this.

This game is not like other X:COM games you may have played; rather it is a different type of game altogether that is simply set in the X:COM universe.  Evidently, this bothered many people; but I find it hard to understand why some people feel the core gameplay is so absolutely terrible.  The style of play is very similar to the Mass Effect series.  You combat in third-person shooter style, with the ability to use tactical pausing and to issue commands (move, target, use ability) to squadmates.  There is an XP and leveling system for both your main character and squadmates, with a handful of different squadmate classes to work with.  It certainly doesn’t have the most refined, expansive, and exemplary combat/gameplay mechanics out there, but I thought it was good enough and enjoyed playing the game.

The story is somewhere between mediocre and good.  I liked the atmosphere and setting of an alien invasion in 1960s America.  The narrative and characters are undoubtedly cliché at times, but I felt it was all intriguing enough to hold my interest as I played through the game.  Some of the plot developments do come out of nowhere, but ultimately I thought they actually helped to make the story more interesting.

I didn’t experience any jarring bugs or glitches and I thought the graphics and soundscape were pleasant.  Some of the cutscenes had a grainy look to them even after I turned film grain off, but it wasn’t the end of the world— the in-game graphics were still crisp and attractive.  For me, the most egregious negative aspect of the game was the checkpoint autosave system.  I don’t like playing a game on a PC in this day & age and not have the option to quicksave and/or make multiple saves.  (You can, however, also load up the start of any level and continue playing from there, if you missed something).  But, to be honest, the checkpoints were extremely frequent and never really caused any true frustration.

The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a decent game that suffered from overzealous people’s unrealistic expectations.  Not every game can be the best game ever or the best game of the year.  If you are someone who only likes to play a few games a year and wants them all to be absolute top-notch games, I can respect that and I will then suggest that you might not want to play this.  The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a moderate-to-good game that will appeal to those who enjoy the style of gameplay it offers and who play enough different games that they understand they can’t all be the best but they can be good enough.

Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

reviewText:
The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is for me, the surprise of the year. It received a slew of mediocre review scores which painted a pretty bleak picture. However, upon playing it myself, I have found the game to be incredibly enjoyable.

You are thrust into the shoes of William Carter --  an agent with a troubled past -- in the midst of an alien invasion. With the military essentially being wiped out and all communications jammed, it falls to the XCOM organisation to deal with the alien threat.

As an XCOM agent, you will spend much of your time in the undergound base: delegating mission assignments (where your fellow XCOM agents can gain experience), exploring, completing side missions and talking to the various personalities within the facility. Many comparisons have been made between the XCOM base and the Mass Effect Citadel, which I would say are apt.

When you're done with the base activites, you can head out into the field. Most of the time you may choose between minor (side) and major (main) operations. The minor operations are fun little deviations, providing insight into what the people of that region have been through. You may happen upon individuals who have been infected by the aliens (this renders them basically catatonic) or dismembered bodies  scattered thoughout.

In terms of gameplay, you lead two squadmates into battle, stopping (well, nearly stopping) time in order to provide them with orders. To me, it feels like Enemy Unknown, except in third person. Along with providing them orders, you level them up, allowing them to use new and varied powers. If you play it as a straight up shooter, neglecting to order your AI squadmates around, you may have a bad time. I believe this is where a lot of the negative attitudes towards the gameplay comes from. The AI needs direction or they will get themselves killed.

A typical encounter would see you approach the enemy, getting yourself into cover and your allies. Pausing time, surveying the battlefield then deciding how to proceed. Perhaps you make your sniper cloak, move around to flank the enemy, then hit them with a critical strike? Perhaps you have your engineer throw down a rocket turret, which you then lift above cover to rain hell upon your enemies? Each battle is varied, giving you a lot of strategic options. This is something that I loved about The Bureau: XCOM Declassified.

The story goes from somewhat generic to Wow
date: this is batshit insane!" As I made my way through
recommended: I became more and more engaged
hoursPlayed: to the point where I couldn't put it down.\n\nThe game does have its problems

reviewText:
Rating 7.5/10
Overview: Cover Based- Third Person Shooter

The Good:

+I really loved the 1960's American setting. Both artistically and technically the developers did a good job making this game feel alive.

+The game takes place across a series of locations each one unique in its own way. The game has a lot of good set pieces

+Side quests are fleshed out and fun to play

+ The game allows you to take 2 squad members with you into battle. You can customize your squad any way you like. There are four classes to choose from:  support, sniper, engineer, and commando. Each class has its own set of abilities and weapons to choose from. You pick whatever you want to suit your playstyle.

+ The game has a wide variety of abilities not only for the main character but your squad as well. The abilities are varied for each class and serve a very practical purpose in battle

The Average:

The story starts off strong and is constantly building up to something...problem is, the story starts getting too convoluted for its own good. Eventually it gets so ridiculous it becomes hard to care about the story. By the end of the game I was playing it just to see the next setting.

The characters are also one dimensional and a bit stereotypical.

The game doesn't do a whole lot to change up the game play formula. Every side quest/main mission plays out the same way, kill lots of enemies, move on to the next area...repeat.

The Bad:

- Your teammates are completely useless. First they don't manually use there abilities, you have to manually select them for them to use it. Some people may like this, I did not.  The second major problem is that they make very stupid decisions resulting in death. The pop out of cover at the wrong time and get shot at, move to locations where the enemies are, etc.   The third major problem is that they do very little damage, 99% of the kills will come from you.

For a game that is supposed to be a tactical" shooter
date:
there is nothing tactical about it. Because of the stupidity of your teammates the game plays out like a solo third person shooter. You only have teammates to choose their abilities.

Conclusion

For all the fun I had with this game
recommended: it does have some serious faults. I would have liked to see more variety in the gameplay and stronger A.I. I still think its worth playing especially if you like cover based shooters."

reviewText:
I love XCOM (old and new). I like third (and first) person shooters. This should have been right up my alley. The concept is, but the execution falls flat for me.

My AI squad mates are imbeciles: running in front of turrets, running INTO the explosion radius of grenades, etc. I guess maybe I'm supposed to micro-manage the crap out of them, but that's not very fun -- especially when I'm struggling with getting my own damn guy to actually go into cover, move around simple objects, etc. 90% of the game boils down to me shooting an alien, cranking off my healing power to keep my idiot squad mates alive, shooting another alien, running to revive a downed ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that walked out of cover, shooting an alien, cranking off my healing power again...lather, rinse, repeat.

It's not a terrible game, but it's just not for me. I don't have the patience for this kind of nonsense.

reviewText:
The Bureau: XCOM Declassified was not well received by mainstream reviewers, but I personally enjoyed it a lot. Overall, it feels like a stripped down version of Mass Effect, but the combat stands out above other cover shooters. The game has a lot of flaws, but I encountered no bugs in the core game. The Hangar 6 DLC, however, would freeze briefly every few seconds and rendered the game nearly unplayable.

The Bureau's combat puts you in control of William Carter, a rather generic protagonist with a gravelly voice. Conversations in the game are carried out with a radial menu lifted directly from Mass Effect. The dialogue isn't terribly interesting, and some of the characters facial animations appeared to not actually be finished. Their mouths move with odd robotic motions, and their eyes look eerily dead. Carter himself, and some of the other core characters have much better, albeit repetitive animations. The story is forgettable overall, but moves the game on well enough. It doesn't come anywhere close to the likes of Mass Effect though, and the fact that the developers chose to base their game design so heavily on Mass Effect is unfortunate given the weak story. Even still, the combat made the experience worthwhile.

Combat in the Bureau is at it's core a cover shooter in the vein of Mass Effect or Gears of War. It also gives you a pair of squadmates and allows you to give direct orders to them. The rookies you start with only have one or two abilities, as well as a command to focus on a specific target, and move to a location. Choosing where to move your squadmates is where the game gets a lot of it's strategic depth. You have to take into account how long they'll be exposed for, how far the nearest ally is if they need a revive, where the enemies are, how much protection the cover offers, and how easily they can use their abilities from their location. Overall it makes for a far more interesting experience than your standard cover shooter. Abilities range from dropping mines, shield domes, artillery strikes, and others.

The combat isn't perfect though. Your squadmates seem to move into stupid locations occasionally, either exposing themselves to unnecessary fire, going down somewhere difficult to revive them, or both. It's not quite clear why this happens, but it doesn't happen very often at least. The encounters feel somewhat repetitive, but they ramp up in difficulty at a good rate. The weapons are fairly standard for a cover shooter; human and alien variations of the standard rifle, pistol, sniper and so on. Enemies on the other hand provide a bit more variety, healing their allies, granting them shields, spawning new enemies, or even mind controlling your squadmates.

The graphics generally look good, with a variety of scenes ranging from idyllic small towns to metallic alien structures. Some elements though stand out like a sore thumb. An ugly low res skybox in one of the first scenes of the game is jarringly bad to look at in stark contrast to the cutscene that precedes it. Other elements like a destroyed tank with an ugly texture and a low poly model, or the abyss below an alien tower filled with an ugly brown fog that would have been acceptable years ago, but looks disappointing today. The rest of the game, however, especially the weapon reload animations look and sound good.

The Bureau's worst offense however, is sure to be a dealbreaker for some fans of the mainstream XCOM games. The only thing The Bureau has in common with XCOM itself is the aliens and the weapon types. Unlocking new weapons is done merely by picking them up off the ground rather than researching them. Dying only puts you back to the latest checkpoint, and while you can lose squadmates permanently if they bleed out in some difficulty settings, I'm fairly sure if you die yourself they'll be back with you at the last checkpoint.

By removing research, permadeath, and forcing the player down a linear path, I'm sure some players will deem the game unworthy of the XCOM title. While these issues did grate on me at first, it was the combat that kept me playing and enjoying every minute of it. Even though the story is just average, it isn't particularly time consuming like it is in Mass Effect. While I feel the game could have played more to it's strengths, it was still well worth the time and money while on sale. I wouldn't hesitate to reccomend this game to fans of Mass Effect, though fans of the classic XCOM games or Enemy Unknown will not enjoy it unless they also enjoy a good cover shooter.

reviewText: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=412295963\nHighly recommended. I absolutely enjoyed every minute of this game, it stands on it's own in the franchise. From the convincing, immersive 1962 atmosphere to the gorgeously rendered and extremely detailed environments, it is immensely engaging and entertaining from start to finish. The tactical combat system is smooth and satisfying without being too easy, just the right balance of simplicity and complexity for me. I found the characters, especially the protagonist, to be realistic, believable people. Agent Carter is the quintessential tragic antihero with a scarred past, bad habits, and post traumatic stress disorder. A cynical misanthropist, but a man of the highest honor, we can't help but hope he finds redemption in saving the world. The expertly written story draws you in and helps greatly to suspend disbelief in an otherwise unbelievable nightmare. I would like to see this subject matter treated more in gaming, I think it is a richly complex, provocative and potentially horrifying, largely untapped genre. The Bureau is by far the best game to address it so far.

reviewText:
The Bureau is a strange game. It's essentially a Mass Effect game without the plot choices (save for a few near the end). The squad controls like a Mass Effect 3 squad. You order them to cover and use abilities (like warp blast and lift...). There's a main mission hub where you talk to your companions with dialogue wheels. It's Mass Effect-lite.

It's pretty well made and the combat is engaging enough. I really enjoy the rare game that tries to capture cold war era America and I think The Bureau succeeds here quite well. Everything about this game is very 1962.

If you like the XCOM lore or are just looking for a decent third person squad shooter to spend some time with, you could do much worse. Skip the DLC though.

reviewText:
I really enjoyed The Bureau: XCOM Declassified.

It's a tactical cover-based shooter in a thirdperson view.
You're playing one of the agents of XCOM, fighting back an alien invasion on the earth.

It has a pretty nice '50s/'60s style which fits the game perfectly and looks pretty neat (sure, no high-end graphic but it has still some nice and atmospheric visuals).
It's very linear and you'll always see when a fight is going to happen (you'll spot the covers you can use).
I found the gameplay and fights to be quite enjoyable. Though, the A.I. has some flaws (and i just played on a low difficulty, so maybe it might be worse on higher difficulties).
It plays like every other cover-based shooter, with the exception that you can give your 2 companions orders (there are maximum 2 you can take on missions with you). Opening up this menu will trigger a super slow-motion, giving you time to activate skills, place your companions on specific points on the map or heal yourself.
You also have to be careful/tactical as the characters won't take too much damage, so run&gun isn't the best option here.

Between missions you're always going back to the underground base of XCOM, where you can find some people to talk with, read some notes and do some smaller side-missions, which was a nice idea in my opinion.

You can also recruit different soldiers which have different classes and therefor different skills they will use, e.g. one can use a shield, another one can place a turret and the next one can make himself invisible.

If you're a die-hard fan of the old XCOM games, you might be dissappointed, as it is not the typical turn-based strategy game, but apart from that i found it to be pretty enjoyable.

Worth a look if you like SciFi and tactical third-person shooters.

reviewText:
As far as games go, I can't think of too many that are more demonized than this one. Most people went into it thinking they were going to get some sort of polished up grid-style xcom team FPS and the reality is that while this game doesn't quite fall into that category, it isn't exactly the worst thing ever either.

The game itself has a fairly interesting storyline that fits in “ok” to the XCOM universe despite not making a whole lot of sense until late game. Most levels consist of you running from point A to point B and collecting whatever tidbits of information (if any) and special items/weapons in addition to killing anything in your way.

The combat is a bit frustrating at first as your cohorts movement commands are issued in a way relative to their position which makes using their abilities a bit difficult if they happen to be out of range. Also, they seem to be incredibly bad at dodging anything so expect to have to babysit them for the entirety of the game. As far as strategy goes, I managed to find a sweet spot with scout and commando but other class mixes are viable all the way until the last few battles (your experience may vary).

Overall, the game came off as a bit tedious and I kind of sloughed through the last few hours of level plus multiple respawns". Additionally the plot revolving around the main character (Carter) is pretty nonsensical and random which made it kind of difficult to get “into” the story. I would only recommend this game for diehard fans of XCOM who want to see another take on the popular franchise."

reviewText:
The Bureau: XCOM Declassified not only fails to grasp its strategy based roots but struggles to smoothly incorporate some of the most basic elements of gameplay.

Set in the 1960′s you take the role of William Carter, a CIA agent with the task of delivering a mysterious object, as things don’t turn out as planned Carter finds himself caught within a global alien invasion. After showing the ability to command, Carter is brought into the XCOM project to combat the new alien threat and keep it hidden from public domain.

While the story has plenty of potential, filled with plot twists and interesting concepts that promised much however the abysmal animation quality and equally poor dialogue stomps on any attempts for the story to blossom. As your character speaks to others, it won’t take long for you to notice the constant repeat of three animations that just feel artificial, along with poor voice acting that simply changes tone every sentence making it impossible to take anything they say with any care. Plot holes run amok with many of the side quests, and dialogue not connected to the main focus of the storyline.

The Bureau tries to blend the turn based strategy of the XCOM series with real time cover based shooting. Promoting teamwork and RPG elements to overcome challenges works well on paper but poor execution through AI simply makes many of the strategy components redundant. Often finding my partners simply refuse to take any useful cover unless directly told to do so, however when they take position the poor AI simply takes over, soon making them move out of cover instantly. The AI will often struggle to perform basic tasks, watching myself go down right next to an ally as they simply stand on my face watching my hp slide down to zero.

While enemies are based on those featured in previous XCOM games, within The Bureau they lack the identity and unique traits that made combat diverse, tense and tactical. As you progress through the game, enemies will remain the same except for an additional armor or shield bar with the word elite lazily thrown after their names.

Character progression within the game is very limited, offering little combat customization. As you and your squad levels up you are given the choice between two new upgrades, often being the choice between duration and damage. This design has been taken from XCOM: Enemy unknown which worked fine within the game design however playing as a single character through the whole story, and only having two teammates with you at all times means characters simply feel too limited, with a maximum of three skills per class, you’ll soon find your preferred attacks and have no reason to add diversity to your tactics throughout the entire game. Skills are activated by bringing up a battle HUD, giving you access to your own and team skills, during this the game will slow down giving you more time to plan and consider your options. Though slowing down the game reduces the pressure, the game continues to play making many tactical attacks an impossibility. Many times I found myself trying to time my snipers critical strike with turrets and protective abilities however the moment a skill is selected it will begin to play out giving you little time to organize the ambush you planned in your mind, often resulting in a messy and inconsistent first attack.

One of the huge holes apparent within the game seems to be a lack of co-op within the game, the structure of combat and the storyline feel setup for two players. Situations where the main character become split up for short periods of time from the team, as well as the dependency on tight coordinated teamwork scream out for two player interaction. Many flaws within the game, specifically the unreliability of the AI would be overcome and none apparent with a second human player. With a second player the game could be incredible enjoyable and the fact developers missed this opportunity is a great disappointment.

The Bureau is definitely not one of the worst games available for sale, but simply tries to do so many things, it does none of them well. Barely meeting the line of mediocre in any aspects of gameplay giving it no identity on the market, and as such simply giving no reason to buy it especially at a full AAA title price.

edit: Fixed typo.

reviewText:
The Bureau: XCOM Declassified isn't bad, it just isn't very good. It's a bit threadbare, feeling like several incomplete ideas that have been rushed out the gate.

Realistically, I suspect The Bureau was completed on a small-ish budget after lingering around in development hell for a few years. Something about the game makes it feel like it's ten years or more old, if it wasn't for some of the DirectX 11 effects looking so sparkly it'd be easy to think it was from the early 2000's. Many of the locations are bare and empty places, feeling like they've been built in a rush, and often with several such vacant sets stitched together without any combat or events to distract, assumably to give the impression of covering a lot of ground in a mission. Other areas have clearly had some time and attention spent on them, and the locations and missions waver back-and-forth on this attention / quality scale, leaving the experience feeling quite jarring. You'll wander from a well-realised street, strewn with debris, bodies and signs of previous life... into an area that feels like it's been imported from a PS2 game.

The mechanics of the game basically play out like Mass Effect's combat, or Mass Effect 3 more specifically. It's a cover-based shooter where you run around with two squadmates, you have abilities with cooldowns, can issue orders and give movement directions to your squad. Enemies come in multiple varieties, some with shields and some with armour, with a few enemy types creating interesting tactical choices (a unit that supplies shields to all other nearby units, for example, if taken out the shields drop and make the fight easier). Unfortunately, where Mass Effect shines in making you care for your squad, here they are just flat cardboard bodies waiting for you to pull their puppet strings. They also keep respawning in front of you whenever you cross through a 'loading door' (frequent area transitions where the game loads the next section as your character very slowly opens a door and looks left and right before giving you control again), which is a bit distracting.

In fact, I felt the game lacked polish in general. I fell through the level geometry and died twice in eight hours of play, once whilst just running down a straight corridor. Audio logs can be found and played, although walking away from them they fade until inaudible (if I have to stand still to listen to them, they may as well be written text!). The controls aren't terrible, but movement feels clunky and stiff, for example; when you run there is absolutely no strafing, not even in a limited fashion, leaving you to clumsily course-correct with your mouse as you charge forward. You also tend to pop in and out of cover randomly at times, especially if strafing in cover, and controlling your squadmates feels awkward (fortunately the game slows down time during this).

Much of the story is told over radio as you run between fights, although there are some cutscenes that deal with exposition. The game also uses a dialogue wheel, just like the Mass Effect series, allowing you to choose between being vaguely rude or agreeable, it's a nice enough touch, although it felt a bit redundant with such small scope for actual meaningful choice. Levels are basically linear paths that open into combat arenas, the main missions last 30 to 60 minutes each, with side missions from 15 to 30 minutes roughly (I only did a couple, they felt fairly pointless). The game isn't overly long with six main missions, the story is mildly amusing with some interesting characters (although the main player character really started to grate on me). The plot felt like it tried to raise the stakes too high a number of times implying that Earth has basically been wiped out and already lost by the midway point of the game, then later claiming it's not as bad as implied, which breaks the suspension of disbelief somewhat.

Imbetween the missions, the game flirts with the idea of being an XCOM-style strategy game where you pick missions and kit out your squad, but with only six main plot missions and (I believe) seven side-quest 'minor missions', it doesn't feel like there's a lot of variety or choice. The equipment feels limited, with only a handful of weapons to equip and the only other equipment slot being a 'backpack' which acts as a kind of modifier for ammo, health regen, or ability cooldowns.

Overall, not a bad game, just not a particularly good one. It feels like it didn't succeed at being the mixture of genres it wanted to be, and it's not particularly good at being any ONE genre either. The plot is so-so, and the clunky and unpolished feel doesn't help. But if you don't mind all this and want a simple squad and cover-based shooter, this might entertain.

reviewText:
After all the bad press surrounding slapping the famous XCOM (sic.) brand on a TPS there is a surprising decent game left behind.  You are Agent Carter, a cynical broken man thrust into the limelight after an Alien invasion now tasked as the tip of the spear against this new threat.

There are many elements and ideas drawn from the previous games but it is a strictly linear and pre determined experience.  You operate out of XCOM headquarters between the main story missions.  You have free run of the base and are able to go on minor side missions, perform investigations inside the base and sent agents out on missions on their own to gain experience and new equipment.  Sadly even though the base has vast Engineering and Lab sections, they are cosmetic.  You can't perform research on new equipment or ideas or perform autopsies.  The only way to get new equipment is to find it during a mission and the only way to learn about various elements is to click on one of the copious clickables in the world.

Carter can bring two additional henchmen with him on a mission from one of the four classes.  They are all pretty standard tropes from other games but do add an interesting element to the game.  Do you go all out attack with commandos and snipers, sit back and dig in with engineers and support specialists or a combination of the four.  You can move henchmen around the battleground, conveniently littered with waist high walls, flank enemies and use the various abilities in conjunction with Carter's unique ones for a multitude of strategies. But...

A warning: The friendly henchmen AI is some of the worst you'll ever see.  They'll jump out of cover, run left, run right, turn a full circle, jump over another wall landing right next the nearest enemy before coming back to you.  They need to be babysat at all times or they will be useless.

Where the game shines is in the fantastic recreation of cold-war early sixties America and the digital acting.  The influence of Mass Effect is obvious but still welcome and the story?  Well, let's just say it takes quite the left turn near the end!

I'll give it 7.5/10 on the AAA scale of 7-10

reviewText:
The Bureau: XCOM Declassified   Overall Score: 4/5

If you're a fan of tactical games I invite you to give this game a try.
I'm nearly 14 hours into this game and I'm really enjoying it.
I didn't play any other of XCOM games so because of this game I will also try XCOM : Enemy Unknown.

RPG Elements: (4/4)
+You get to customize your agents by how they look (yes, even painting their clothes) and changing their names.
+Choosing of 4 different classes to each agent (Recon/Support/Engineer/Commando)
+Choosing of 6 different roles to each agent (Defensive/Assault/Survivalist/Smart etc..)
+Choosing equipment and abilities.

Storyline: (3/4)
+The storyline is clear and understandable but a little obvious and expected.
+Character voices are well made that give extra content to the storyline.
-Some dialogues are boring but most of them stick to the storyline, you can skip them if you want to.

Gameplay: (3/4)
You get to play as 3 agents on the same time.
+Give orders and launch them on the enemy style (Pause menu with abilities just like Game of Thrones (2012) and Of Orcs And Men).
+Different types of enemies including boss fights. Different maps and different levels of difficulty. (Can be challenging for those hardcore players).
+Basic and easy to use cover system.
+Side missions which include base investigations and minor operations.
-Gameplay is repetitive if you play it for a long period.

Tactics point of view: (4/4)
+Take advantage of the different classes and roles that this game gives to you, and use it on the battlefield.
On your back: A medic for health/revive recovery, mabye a skilled marksman? Or a scout with Invisible ability.
With you: Engineer who can deploy turrents or Support who can buff your teammates.
On your frontline: Skilled soldier who will help you in you fight against the aliens.
+And ofcourse pick equipment like Frag/C4 grenades , Assault Rifle , Pistols , SMG's , Lazer guns ...
+Move your agents to strategic points on the battlefield and plan wisely against the enemy.


Enjoyment: (8/10)
Repetetive: (3/10)
Replayability (7/10)
Frustraiton (4/10) - When you play cat&mouse with the agents to revive each other while fighting a boss with aliens around.
Boredom (3/10) - Only in-between missions.

Overall Score: 4/5
* Skip it.
** Not Recommended.
*** Give It A Try.
**** Recommended On Sale.****** Recommended On Full Price.
Thanks for reading.

reviewText:
A decent squad based third person shooter. Nothing more. The Bureau brings nothing new to the table but is still mostly enjoyable. The 60's style is done very well, even though the sci-fi elements detract from the experience at times making it feel like a 90's or even 00's game. It doesn't mix the settings properly I guess.

The graphics are solid, nothing special, but not bad either. They get the job done, like most games. Same goes for the voice acting. The effects on the other hand are done very well.

The gameplay itself is hit and miss. There's no research to be done, so if you pick up an alien's weapon you can fire it right away. It's something I missed, especially after playing last year's Xcom. There are mini missions to be completed and agents can be sent on different missions to level up and gather gear. Those missions can not be played so it basically comes down to selecting which agents you want to go.

Each agent has abilities that can be unlocked by leveling up. They're all fun to use and there's plenty of variation to mix things up during battle.

The battles play out in real time and with the press of a button time can be slowed down to make more tactical choices. Later on you'll have no choice but to use it as more and tougher enemies will be deployed. Without it you'll have a pretty hard time, let me tell you.

Also, If you're agents are down you'll have a certain amount of time to help them up. If you don't help them in time they'll die and you'll lose them forever. So it's important that you work together and manage them in the best way you can to prevent them from dying. Near the end of the game this becomes much less important because your other agents will be around level 4 or 5 already.

The Bureau is actually pretty lenghty. I finished it in about 14-15 hours on Veteran so I guess it can be completed in roughly 13 hours or so, if you stay alive the entire time. That's actually pretty decent in an age where most action (adventure) games can be completed within 7-8 hours.
If I had to rate The Bureau I'd give it a 7/10. It's frustrating at times, but fun enough to play and finish. The only issue here is the price, because even though there's plenty of content the game itself just isn't fun enough to pay full price.

[Rating: 73/100]

reviewText:
I seriously wanted to like this game.  I've been a huge XCOM fan since forever.  This game is just so maddeningly mediocre any true XCOM fan should just forget it exists.

Pros:
-Shooting aliens with M14s I guess
-Retro 60s theme is neat
-Mutons are terrifying

Cons:
-Faux RPG elements are minimally important
-Map design is brutally linear
-The gameplay isn't interesting and sometimes frustrating when cover doesn't work right in a firefight
-Squad routinely abandons perfectly good cover to walk into searing barrages of enfilading plasma fire
-Squad is less than useless, never had them kill more than 20% of the enemy even when fully upgraded and constantly spamming their abilities
-The story gets pretty ridiculous by the end
-Blaster launcher is boring as hell

Bottom line is you're playing a squad based tactics game where the squad is useless, the tactics are simplistic and the maps are so small as to prevent critical thinking.  Then you slog through to an ending that isn't very good.

reviewText:
I wanted to give this game a proper chance, I really did. Even as a serious X-COM nut I know the plotlines have always been 'meh' and after FiraXCOM was announced I was more accepting of this as a spinoff (like Command and Conquer: Renegade, which I liked). It was still a daft move to make the first XCOM game announced for years the one that closest resembles X-COM: Enforcer, the lowest point of the series.

This game however is a perfect example of what happens when you force a franchise into somthing unrelated. I like the 1960's and I like the Men in Black angle but by cramming in lacklustre combat and a horribly broken squad command interface into a game that was not designed from the start to be something different has hampered the game horribly.

I said 'lacklustre combat' but I suspect that is being generous. 'Broken' is more like it. To squeeze as much as possible from the squad command gimmick the only way to do serious damage is by flanking the enemy. That in itself wouldn't be too bad if a) you weren't being constantly forced down linear pathways with little chance to spread your tactical wings and b) most importantly, the squad AI wasn't atrocious. I even tried getting them to stay in place while I flanked as they kept with the lemming act when I gave them the move command. What did they do? The followed me. There is no 'halt' command, before you ask. Add to all that bugger all ammo capacity and you'll spend the game running for a thousand guns just to take care of a handful of mooks.

The graphics are mediocre at best, the base command is even less than what you got from Mass Effect 2 (at least you could choose your research there) but the worst crime in my eyes is the plot. The 1960's was a troublesome time with not just the Cold War but rights movements for women and people of colour. Does any of this get to the game? There's one Soviet agent which is nothing more than 'you can recruit this dude to be a generic squad mate,' only a handful (2 on my admittedly amateurish count) of comments about one of the star agents being a woman and not a single sausage about the amount of black agents and scientists (Again, this is the sixties, that would have been huge and quite interesting). I keep thinking they missed an opportunity by not doing something like Expeditions: Conquistador; imagine if your squaddies had personalities. Likes and hates and all that jazz. Some are progressive and some are more traditional. Do you stick by your guns and rely on women and coloured folk despite the anger you'll recieve or will you bow down to social pressure and prejudice?

Between the lack of care for anything happening in the 60's and all the sci fi weaponry there is no reason this couldn't have been set in modern day, the eighties, or even in World War 2. It takes effort to make one of the most interesting decades in the last century that generic.

Add to that the most generic hero character ever (seriously, the guy is every bland hero trope imaginable; WW2 veteran, dead family, alcoholic, tortured past, gravelly voice, etc) and a plot that makes Independence Day seem high brow and it's a total loss on story as well as gameplay.

The tragic thing is when I look back at the original vids (the ones which sparked the public outcry) it looked really good; the old 'man in black' conspiracies mixed in with the Stepford Wives. That could have lead to some interesting investigative angles and could have created a properly eerie alien plot. If it was allowed to be it's own thing instead of having a brand name forced on it (a brand name not unfamiliar with being abused, admittedly) and not reworked time and time again for stupid reasons we would have had a much better game. For those who whine about the Devil May Cry reboot (which I say was solid), that was at least in the spirit of the originals. The Bureau reeks of the sort of soulless boardroom mandates that I would have expected from EA.

Would I recommend it? It's better than the Syndicate Reboot, but then very little isn't. The word 'generic' appears in the above text a lot. That should tell you everything you need to know.

Quick edit: Yes I know this is a 2K Games published title and not EA, that was a stab at the people who could turn Syndicate into a FPS far worse than Goldeneye: Rogue Agent (which had the excuse of being unfinished and rushed and was still reasonably fun) and the sort of people who looked at the Divine Comedy, social, theological and political commentary that it was and say to themselves, Yes
date: this is perfect God of War clone material!" That's right; I am comparing the Bureau to EA's Dante's Inferno."

reviewText:
I don't think I've ever felt so burned buying a game day one. Do not let the XCOM name fool you. It has nothing to do with the overall story. If anything this game makes a mess of the overall narrative of XCOM. The story is below average with one little unexpected twist but if anything it's more unexpected because up until that point you don't expect much after hearing all the character's dull droning and uninspired dialog.
The graphics range from sub-par to bland. Strange phenomenons appear all the time, from the shimmering hair of one of your colleagues that change from blond to brunette, all the way to identical twin guards that also bare a striking resemblance to a scientist you just passed down stairs.
The game play is standard cover-based shooting. You move, kill aliens, wave ends, then keep moving; sound like some real white knuckle action? If so, get out more. Sometimes you find an alien weapon and get to use it...that's it. No research, no testing, no means of duplicating the tech. You just have it now and so do your teammates.
Speaking of which, your A.I. partners are dumb as suicidal rocks. You give them orders, to which they either ignore so they can do what they want or they follow orders and keep following them regardless of whether or not they are about to die by continuing to obey. They rarely kill an enemy and are more of a liability than a useful asset. When they take too much damage they fall and you have a short amount of time to get to them before they die for good...not that you'd notice. More than a few times I had a teammate warn me I was standing near an alien-thrown grenade. I would jump out of the way while the A.I. teammate that warned me would sit there and get blown up.
This game was short. I beat it along with all the achievements on the first time around. The DLC mission Codebreakers" was horrible. Not only is it an obvious mission that was cut out of the original product to make more money and incentivize pre-orders
date: it is the SHORTEST MISSION IN THE GAME AND ADDS NOTHING TO THE STORY! What do you get to show for it? Another backpack mod thing that you probably won't use.\nI've played some bad games in my life but this one hurt. I like the XCOM franchise but this one was nothing but a cheap cash-in that used the XCOM name to boast sales. Do yourself a favor and buy XCOM: Enemy Unknown or continue to play it  if you already own it. This game is only XCOM in name
recommended: not in game play nor spirit. Learn from my mistake."

reviewText:
X-Com for Monkeys

This may be a good game for those who drool over the UFO's, conspiracy theories, alternative histories as well as those who love the 50's and the 60s (even though they weren't even born then). This is not such a great game for everyone else.

The game plays like a straight B movie, at best.

It pains me that this game used the Unreal 3 engine instead of Mafia's II Ilusion engine, even though 2K Games owns the former. The differences are apparent and Mafia II came out 3 years ago. The game's facial animations are pretty lifeless, the lip sync is nonexistent, the anti-aliasing is somewhat noticeable, there are some texture pop-ins in the background in open levels, the fire/explosion effects are bad as well. It is ridiculous to still be playing with such graphics in Q3 2013, but at least the game allows you to get a 100 FOV which makes you see a enough of your surroundings,.

The overall visuals resemble some sort of a grainy pallet, as if you are watching the game through the lens of the late 70's camera.

Walking around the Xcom base is one of the best highlights of the game, at least it seems so at first. Once you soak in the fact that most AI models are pretty much lifeless the feeling wears off pretty fast.

Unlike in the Enemy Unknown you will have opportunities to sneak up on enemies and be able to set up mini-ambushes, although your element of surprise won't last longer than 2 seconds, the enemy will always know where you are, and why shouldn't they? There is always only one approach to beating the level. The levels are linear although they do provide for some flexibility with cover. And this is the first game that I have seen (since Splinter Cell Conviction) that allows you to switch cover diagonally.

The game loads the level as you progress - each time you open a door a new portion of the level loads while your character cautiously looks around, it's pretty clever.

The game is moderately easy even on the hardest difficulty wherein your agents DO get permadeath, however you can always reload the checkpoint and start over. That kind of defeats the purpose of the Ironman feature that Enemy Uknown had. But then again, Enemy Uknown did not feature the main protagonist. Or maybe it makes little sense to compare the two games since they have been in a parallel
development for quite some time. If anything, this game's combat is closer to Mass Effect than anything. You can heal your squad in an instant, you can pull enemies out of their cover, zap the enemy's shield, set up turrets, use drones, except somehow you manage to do so in mid-twentieth century America.

The squad AI is so-so. Sometimes they are able to kill the enemy by themselves and sometimes they rush out into the battlefield and get knocked down and later bleed out if you don't rush into the hail of bullets yourself in order to try to save them - which kind of defeats the purpose of a smart squad especially when you are on the defensive - major minus. However, it does feel good when you send an enemy to outflank a turret while you get the turret's attention. Moments like that work in the Bureau's favor.

Your squad mates are sure to run out of cover into the open when they are being flushed out with the grenades. And keeping them in line by rallying them to yourself does not work in the midst of the battle. However, all of this DOES push you forward to be decisive in your actions. Should you take a little too long to outsmart and outgun the enemy you are likely to lose a squad-made.

As for the enemy AI, well, 90% of the time they expose their heads from out of cover - so sniper rifle is essential, even with its 15 bullet ammo capacity. So even on the hardest mode all you need is one head shot to kill a medium strength alien.

There are a few things that bothered me. Some of the human tech you have from the beginning is way too advanced. Stealth? Automatic Squad Heal? Smart turrets? What's cool about the X-Com games is that you always faced overwhelming odds with realistic human tech at first - it's the way of the underdog. It's the challenge that counts. And that's what I expected to get from this game.

The game did not do a good job of building up the tension. The prologue mission has you killing aliens left and right. Your character is a natural right away. Okay, he fought the Japanese and then some Vietnamese, but still...

Sure there is a story: it tries to capture the step by step alien invasion across the US and has you traveling to various hot-spots and points of interest. Recruiting new soldiers doesn't cost a thing. So you may never run out of soldiers. What's nice is the constant dialogue between you and your squadmates - helps with immersion and everything.

The game is, by all means, playable.
B for effort.

reviewText:
If you haven't heard about this game, let me be the first to tell you that you aren't missing out. Do not buy it until it is on steam sale (which should be relatively soon at this rate). Here are a few reasons why I say this about The Bureau: XCOM Declassified:
1) The game is extremely buggy. I fell off the map into oblivion at least a dozen times for one reason or another. I even have a screenshot of it occurring and me simultaneously dying. Top this off with a few animation glitches, enemies not spawning or allowing you to progress, and you are setting yourself up for repeating some parts or entire battles in a mission.
2) It has an autosave feature only. No option like in XCOM: Enemies Unknown for what kind of save system you want. This is atrocious when mixed with all the bugs in the game aforementioned.
3) The game is disappointingly short. It took my crappy laptop longer to download the game than to actually play through it--and I completed every side/optional mission as well (My achievements are proof of that).
4) Your companions/troops are utterly useless to you. I have screenshots that show just how little they actually contribute to the mission. Hardly any kills, don't know how to use cover effectively, die too often, and literally run into grenades after avoiding them due to a slight time delay in their detonation. It is unbearably annoying, and doesn't improve as they level up.
5) After you get about halfway through the campaign, you just repeat the same tactics nonstop. This gets repetitive and detracts from the overall interest in the game. You defeat the enemies in the same methods over and over, and it doesn't leave you feeling like you accomplished anything truly.
6) Getting anywhere in the base is simply a pain in the ♥♥♥. You cannot sprint inside the giant labyrinth that is XCOM headquarters, so it takes forever to go from person to person to talk to anyone for missions. Also, there is a decontamination room in between the lab and the rest of the base. While this feature is neat to travel through the first couple of times, after about 30 times you start getting really agitated/impatient, really quick.
7) The storyline is not all that immersive for the player sadly enough. A few moral choices here and there, but in the end it is linear, monotonous, and unfulfilling.
These are just a FEW of the issues I have had with this game. It was not worth the $45 that i paid for it, but I hope some of the other XCOM games I received with the pre-order bundle prove to be more worthwhile. I give this game a rating of an out of this world letdown". This is mainly for all the hype it received

reviewText:
Like a fair number of other games today XCOM Declassified is a case of the mistaken identity.  Bureau is a great game solid 3D person action with surprisingly deep tactical elements, great visuals, and nice (for the pulp genre) story.

The problem is the game has a lot more in common with Mass Effect than with XCom.

Combat, squad management, agent powers, level design... everything is patterned after Mass Effect.  Even story really - loose team-building part, replace Reapers with Outsiders, replace indoctrination with infection... few more similar changes... put the whole thing on 1960s Earth = Mass Effect Deja Vu.

The bottom line, if you are looking for an XCom game - you might as well pass.  If Mass Effect streamlined for combat missions and set in 60s sounds interesting - the game is more than worth the price tag.

Note: Keep in mind the game really is tactical, on anything but the easiest difficulty expect to spend more of your time commanding the squad than pulling a trigger.

reviewText:
One of the most underrated game ever due to X-Com fans hating change. This is basically the Command and Conquer Renegade version of X-Com series.

If you are into Agency/FBI like games you got to get this game. It is one of a kind. Not much games out there that is set like this one. Sure there is no stealth like Hitman series but, it is war.  You can say the same for Condemned series, but that is horror. I've seen far worst Agency like games than this, if anything it comes out on top of the list.

Sure, there are a couple of issues with this game though. Here are some cons, but, they are very small.
- Hold shift for running and cover at the same time can get you trap from running away from the wall(cannot be changed).
- You need to press shift again to vault over.
- Scanning is pointless in this game as there is no encyclopedia, even for DLCs to look back at for info. Other than that it is for a steam achievement for main game.
- Hangar 6 DLC AK47 and Micro Wave Gun is not updated or cannot be accessed for Main storyline, they do not exists in the main story.

There are some stuff you should know when you buy this game.
a. There are no secrets to unlock, so don't bother scrolling around unless you want to read all the letters.
b. Hangar 6" DLC is a prequel to the game and should be played first before Main story.
c. Code Breakers is an optional "Operation" that should be bought when discounted. It is just an extra mission for Main game(was a Pre-order DLC). Very Short.
d. You cannot scan documents or letters.
e. Do not buy Light Plasma Pistol DLC. I do believe one of the DLC's come with it. I don't remember how I got it. But I could access it in main game. I don't even have the Light Plasma Pistol DLC.
f. You do not unlock anything at all for playing highest difficulty other than one steam achievement. As for DLC go ahead play Rookie mode and enjoy the story.

There are also 4 endings for the Main Story line. So you can replay it 4 times or load back save checkpoint."

reviewText:
The Bureau doesn't quite measure up to the other XCOM games. It's a tactical third person shooter that plays a lot like Mass Effect (although not as good) opposed to the classic XCOM turn-based style games. The story is a bit ridiculous, and it has a lot of graphical glitches and audio bugs while the core gameplay is still fairly fun.

For a more indepth review, check out my video:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=175587890

I would recommend waiting for this to go on sale if you're looking to pick it up.


If you enjoyed this review, feel free to follow me as a Steam Curator: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/4886473/
voteText: 290 of 496 people (58%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
-- Foreword - 3D VISION --

First of all I have to clarify that I played The Bureau completely with NVidia's 3D vision and used a fix by the community to enhance the quality of it. If you do not know 3D vision check out NVidia's forum: https://forums.geforce.com/default/board/49/.

What's the point of 3D vision? It changes the immersion you feel in a game. Characters are a bit outside of the screen and hallways in the game have a realistic deepth; that means it goes deep into your wall. It is like watching through your screen. It is something you have to check out yourself  as it is difficult to be explained. Do not make the mistake and compare it to 3D movies. The deepth and convergence is very different. It is more the kind of 3D you will see with the Oculus Rift or the HTC Vive.

-- Substance of the game --

First of all, I have to admit that I needed quite some time to get into the mechanics. So I stopped playing the game after 4 hours when I first started it one and half years ago, knowing at this time however that I want to retry it again someday in the future.

This weekend it was this day and I got hooked this time and played through it in three days.

-- What are the pros and cons? --

Pros:

- Great atmospheric setting, great story, great characters, great voice-acting
- Decent graphics with very good science fiction design
- A great variety of coloufull lights
- It's the 50s! Everyone in the game looks very classy
- Rewarding and satisfying combat system
- First playthrough around 20 hours
- Replayability because of the combat system and different difficulties
- Decent skill system
- A lot short well-written readings within the game that give you some background information of the story

Cons:

- AI of your squad:

-->Let me explain: it might not be a big issue if you play on easy but it is going to be very frustrating on the harder difficulties; actually it was also the AI of my fellow combattants that stopped me from playing the game the first time. If you have the feeling a combat is too demanding change the difficult settings. It is possible during every fight.
-->What's the issue? The AI sometimes is just not holding cover correctly. The combat system is missing commands about what the AI should do at a specific place you move one of your two characters. Sometimes it would just be better for your squad members to stay in cover and let you do all the hard work. But they always decide to get out of the cover and shoot the enemies, but not going back to cover in time so they brutally injured.

- Level-UP system finishes for your main character at level 10 and for your squad members at level 5 - I could imagine a Game+ with more levels and maybe even more variety in skills

- Dispatch missions are good to level up but not really fun because there is no interaction whatsoever

- Story in the beginning a bit confusing

***

==> Conclusion: very atmospheric real-time strategy shooter with issues in the AI. Combat system is easy to learn and difficult to master with some very frustrating moments. Unique game in design and story.

==> Rating: 8/10 (without 3D vision 6.5/10)

reviewText: I truly wanted to like this game.  After having played the excellent XCOM: Enemy Unknown, I had high hopes for this game.  The problem I have with this game is the squad AI.  It is terrible.  They just charge out to attack the aliens and get incapacitated repeatedly.  It is hard enough staying alive yourself without having to go rescue your ignorant squadmates.  It is like babysitting 3 year olds on the battlefield.  I issued them orders to stay in cover but like most 3 year olds, they start to wander into harms way.  The story seems okay, but it never truly engaged me.  There is no research to be done, which makes it feel more shallow than XCOM: Enemy Unknown.  The graphics are average to above average.  But the gameplay in battle was such a chore, I just quit playing.  Life is too short to waste playing a game that is not fun for you.  Just my 2 cents...

reviewText:
As a long time XCOM fan, I was uncertain about the direction of The Bureau.  Here was a series that I loved with strong tactical strategy roots that had influenced the genre for nearly two decades... and it's newest release was going to be a third-person shooter.  I assumed that the game was a way to use the XCOM name to cash in on yet another Call of Duty clone.  Fast forward a couple of years and I realized that I was wrong.

The XCOM 2 announcement got me hyped up on the series once again and I decided that instead of playing through another war in XCOM: Enemy Within (which would've been a blast, even if it were my billionth war) I would try something new and actually give The Bureau a go.  It was a good decision.

The story in the game is enjoyable, though it gets a little weird and unexpectedly complicated toward the end.  Base building doesn't make an appearance in this game, however, there is an XCOM base where you spend your time in between missions and it is quite well done.  Different scenes play out as you wander through the base depending on events that you've experienced and choices that you've made.  For example, after defeating each new enemy type that you run across you can often see them being studied (in one way ot another) in your laboratory.

Combat, the meat and potatoes of this game, is significantly more fun than I had been assuming.  You issue commands to your squad mates (who come in Recon, Engineer, Support, and Soldier varieties) which include utilizing the abilities that they possess.  These squaddies level up and gain new abilities on a skill tree exclusive to each class that is reminiscent of XCOM: Enemy Unknown.  Two agents of the same class could use their abilities in different ways.

The feel of the combat itself reminds me of Mass Effect 2.  The cover system, the use of alien abilities (some which are very similar to biotics), and even the large variety of weapons to choose from in the game and their varying strengths and weaknesses.  However, it can not be overstated that the AI in this game is less than amazing.  You'll find yourself micromanaging your agents often as they can't seem to utilize themselves to be anywhere near as efficient as when you hold them by the hand and tell them what to do.  On a few occassions, I watched in horror as one of my agents moved away from an enemy grenade, only to realize that the best cover was were that grenade was and return to it to his imminent death.

All in all, this is a good game with plenty to offer that I recommend to XCOM fans and shooter/RPG fans alike.  As long as you can get past the AI it is a solid game with around a couple of dozen hours of content if you're playing on a difficulty level that challenges you.

reviewText:
An atmospheric, fairly challenging, Third Person Shooter with Squad Elements.

The 1960's art style & quite fun gameplay is worth a playthrough. Using the DiectX 11 mode, I was very impressed with the graphical quality.

There are elements of making decisions and speaking to charactors with a very Bioware-Inspired (Mass Effect) choice system,

During the game, you will always have 2 charactors following you in the field which you can command/send orders to at any time.

Its quite an interesting spin on the Xcom formula.

But sadly not worth the full price of $19.99, rather get it during a sale.

To score it...

Gamplay  - 7/10 Fun, but abit repetitive. Linear. Very little replayability.
Story       - 5/10 so-and-so, a means to an end essentially.
Audio       - 7/10 Good, no problems. Fits the 1960's Aesthetic.
Graphics  - 8/10 You can see alot of work went into this, Really grabs you in.

I only had one problem with the game, my Saves got corrupted halfway through the game.
No matter what I did, I could not get it into a workable condition.
Using a save that someone else made was my only resort.
Just in case, I did a backup of my save each.and.every.time.

reviewText:
I wanted to give this game a chance. When i saw it being compared to mass effect i was intrigued, but ultimately i was left frustrated by gameplay mechanics that are at odds with each other. The Bureau wants you to use its squad command system so much, yet stacks all the odds against you by forcing you down a linear corridor of cramp combat areas with practically zero room to make any worthwhile tactical decisions. Even when you attempt to move your AI partners to flank an enemy, half the time they just get downed almost instantly by pinpoint accurate enemy fire. Add to that horrible weapons with small ammo capacity yet a LAUGHABLY abundant amount of ammo crates littered across the battlefield. The combat is just not fun in ANY way, shape, or form.

It's a real shame because the story seemed to be pretty decent (minus the completely lifeless and uninteresting generic squad mates), but i just could not bring myself to push forward. I could forgive a game with solid and fun gameplay but a weak story, i would still have a fun time albeit with some regrets. This, however, is just a painful and frustrating experience.

reviewText: The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is an interesting hybrid between a traditional third-person shooter and a strategic game, with elements of role-playing game; but the impression is a game crippled by a troubled production.It offers a glimpse in the history of XCOM through a tactical third person shooter, without becoming a simple mindless shooter. The Bureau requires a good amount of tactical thinking, which really makes it feel like a true XCOM game. Lack of strategy, however, might make the game less appealing to some XCOM fans, but the majority of players will revel in the tactical gameplay.The Bureau builds up adequately on a lot of ideas taken from XCOM. As a result it is entertaining and generally true to the XCOM canon but its potential is, more often than not, half-expressed. I like the fact that it forces teamwork, has a great atmosphere and solid graphics. The aliens tend to attack with various and difficult to kill forces from the beginning - that's good as well. Unfortunately later on the magic kind of disappears - the story becomes silly, fights get easier and the interface irritates more and more. But taking all things into consideration, The Bureau is a solid, well made game.\nConsidering the game’s fraught development history and arguably ill-conceived premise, The Bureau is practically a best-case scenario.
voteText: 45 of 71 people (63%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Suffering from a heavy case of casual and consolitis, the Bureau is the result of a lengthy development hell. A mediocre shooter for the masses that bears the X-COM name without including any of the things that makes X-COM, X-COM. Mainly that missing element is depth.

Features have been either overly simplified or cut entirely to fit the forced mold of a 3rd person cover based shooter. So you have no base building, researching or resource management. Capturing aliens is now a plot point, alien weapons can be used as soon as they're found, soldiers have a generic pre-assigned personality stopping you from making up your own backgrounds for them, and so on. Squad size is now also limited to 3 and the main character can't die. The level progression is also screwed up which means the game gets easier as you progress. There's no tactic to anything, just spam everything you've got.

So one wonders what was the point in making this game and calling it X-COM. You could argue that it's easier to move the game with brand recognition but I bet you the audience of this game doesn't even know or care what X-COM is. The Bureau was made by 2K Marin whose previous outing was Bioshock 2, a game set in the same time period, making alot of the assets feel reused aswell. The writing is mediocre and boring so I ended up skipping most of the dialoque as a result.

The Bureau is the bad of Mass Effect and Bioshock rolled into one.

reviewText: Extremely underrated squad based cover shooter. This was my sleeper hit of 2013. The story is a prequel to X-com Enemy Unknown and ties in directly to that game. Gameplay reminds me of Gears of War but with squad commands. I think this game got alot of hate because it was an Xcom shooter and many people wanted to hate it. There are also some lite rpg elements with leveling, squad choice and mini quests inbetween missions at the Xcom base.\nGame isn't perfect, missions are very linear and disguised corridors, base stuff could have been better, story was alittle weak in the middle. The climax was amazing though both from a story perpective and gameplay.

reviewText:
The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a vapid tactical TPP shooter.
Unless you are a die hard XCOM fan, keep out.
And even if you are, it'll most likely leave you dissatisfied.

PROS:

+ the setting
+ little details(squaddies going on a smoke break if standing idle for a while, the protagonist's hat falling off his head when suffering major damage)
+ the story has some cool twists

CONS:

- the gameplay
- imbalanced difficulty(once you get the hold of alien weaponry- the odds skyrocket in your favour)
- very limited soldier customization
- zero mission diversity

I've completed the game for the sole reason of feeding my inner XCOM fanboy while waiting for the release of XCOM 2.
The game starts slow and makes a horrible first impression.
I couldn't resist the feeling that Declassified is suffering from a disturbing case of schizophrenia;
not knowing whether it wants to be an action TPP title or a tactical cover-based shooter.
It fails at both.
Gotta admit- after pushing myself through the first 2 or 3 missions it started growing on me, mainly because of the awesome setting.
However, it isn't enough to make The Bureau a good game.
So much locked potential remaining.
Would love to play a solid TPP XCOM shooter one day.

Never half-♥♥♥ two things. Whole-♥♥♥ one thing." - Ron Swanson"

reviewText:
You are Gruff Mc Gruffington, the gruffiest agent to ever gruff in the sixties and lose his family in some freak fire accident.

It's a squad based over-the-shoulder third person shooter in which you and 2 other agents of your choice with varying abilities and weaponry beat the ♥♥♥♥ out of hostile alien scum. With bullets. (AND LAZER BEAMS!)

So you gruff around the environment from point to point, and so on, sometimes viewing various notes, documents, photos, and audio logs between fights.

You can choose between a bunch of backpacks you find throughout the game which give you passive bonuses and make you look like a ghostbuster.

The game looks pretty decent and doesn't seem to have many glitches, the main ones I found, besides hilarious physics, is sounds glitch out sometimes, and then theres the permanent nanomachines distortion anomaly at the bottom of my screen, I think the same thing happened in
Alpha Protocol. Ha ha, oh Unreal Engine and your shenanigans.

Your agent allies' AI is sometimes about as reliable as the Left 4 Dead 2 Survivor AI, so you will be cringing incredibly hard when you die for the 3rd time in a row waiting for your twitchy agent to revive you while Steroids Mc LaserTwat is busy murdering your other agent.

You also gruff around in dialogue trees every now and then, where you got your several optional dialogue options, and then the Let's get the f*** on with this game" option to the left.

And that's about it. Gruff.


And no

reviewText:
Metacritic score (~67) is not that far off. Not impressed so far, although I'll update my recommendation if my opinion changes. It's not that the game is terrible, but it gives lots of hints about the game that it wishes it could be, but fails to be. And I think I would like THAT game more than I like this cover-based third-person real-time-strategy shooter hybrid that can't make up its mind on what it wants to be and ends up second rate at either.

The things that the devs put a lot of effort and care into look/work great. Unfortunately, those things don't seem to encompass quite enough, and not in the most key areas. Examples: When you go into the AI-teammate command mode, time doesn't stop, it only slows down to something like 25% speed. The writing is... um, not the worst, but I'm bored of these people already and I only just met them. AI's kind of dumb early on, although supposedly later on in the game it stops feeling like escort missions and they actually hold their own.

It's not without its good elements. I like the setting itself; care definitely went into that, if not necessarily the dialogue. Where it's not a dark corner with fog and darkness covering up the extremely flat and featureless textures in unimportant corners and other corner-cutting measures, the world looks decent. The promise of what it could be/could have been is still a significant part, however.

It'd probably be a fun multiplayer co-op game, to be honest. Ditch the AI and just choose different classes and run through a campaign with 2-3 of your friends.

reviewText:
I tried to give it a chance
I honestly did. I went into it expecting a decent game that just used X-com names, and after all, it can't be worse than X-com Enforcer, now could it?
Well, it can. Enforcer had its over the top, fast paced shooting with loads of weapons to amuse you. The Bureau has chest high walls to protect their chest high walls that you can sit behind.

I only got about 3 hours in until I just plain could not play any more. With poor controls(Very obviously a console port that they didn't care enough about to make it work for PC), and absolutely awful AI. Several times have I seen the AI just run right into the open without any cover without any prompting whatsoever, and several more times did I wonder if the AI actually follows your commands or knows what end of their gun to point at the enemy. After some experimenting I found the answers to these questions.

No, they do not know what end of their gun goes to the enemy, and they do not understand 'go sit in cover here so I can flank them' either. And speaking of flanking, you will need to do it. For the first few minutes I wondered why the aliens had titanium skulls, but then I realised a headshot and a torso shot are about the same. You get a flat damage bonus if you flank your opponent though. Good concept - but it just doesn't work with the braindead AI and clumsy controls. It isn't actually explained anywhere either, so unless you're quick to figure things out you'll blow all your ammo on an alien who is 'in cover' but still sticking most of his head and torso out for you to shoot(And deal nearly no damage because of this 'cover'), get frustrated, and quit.

The story seemed interesting enough and I did want to see what was next, but I just can't justify spending more time on it than I already have. The story just can't carry the rest of the game and I can't really care enough to play further.

Oh, and the glass physics were pretty good. It was nice to see parts of the glass shatter under fire without the whole window immediately collapsing. If only that attention to detail could have been spend on the rest of the game as well it may have been good

reviewText:
7 / 10. In short words: If you like XCOM:Enemy Unknown and it's former, ancient games, you won't like this.
If not, you might like it.

Beautiful graphics, but gameplay gets repetitive really quick, and the story stops getting interesting in the middle of the game.
And the endings are letdowns. If it wasn't for a single good story part, I'd consider this 'wasted time'.

There's no research or reverse engineering - which is what XCOM has been about since always. All you have to do is pick up enemy weapons and that's it. Nerd note: Remember that in XCOM, alien weapons are rigged to self-destruct if the owner dies, only rarely they fail to self-destruct. Also, they have DNA scanners, so the weapons cannot be immediatelly used by a race different than the one it's programmed for.

Gameplay and dialog seems to have beem mimicked from Mass Effect, which would be a good thing if it didn't feel WAY too similar.
XCOM base - which should be the most interactive and fun part of the game IMO - is just an interactive menu with sidequests, and nothing affects the game's ending. Even saving a fellow agent (which you can fail to do so) makes no impact in the game at all.

The mix of FPS, squad management in the field and tactical combat is very fun, however. Unfortunately, it gets repetitive quickly. And your squadmates are, like the plot, expendable.

For XCOM fans: while it IS fun to explore and see the XCOM universe in first person, you will feel tired and uninterested if you expect the same experience from other XCOM games.
It is also very weird how quickly things go south for humanity and how everything seems to fall apart in days, in comparison to other XCOM games. You have to let that go to get any fun from it.

reviewText: I've had a few friends in my time. Shocking, I know. And therefore, I'm well-acquainted with a certain type of friend. Let me paint a picture here. He's always had your back, always been there when you needed him, but he has a couple of really, really painfully annoying quirks. For instance, remember that time a fly entered your flat? He just wouldn't shut up about it. It's always something small, something minor, but he ensures you pay the closest attention to it, regardless of how meaningless it actually is.\n\nWell, today I made such a friend in The Bureau: XCOM Declassified. Agent Carter is the kind of guy who's the first to let you know he won five bucks in the lottery, there's a strange car going by, or a slightly interesting sesame seed happens to be on his burger bun. How do I know this, you ask? Because that's the Bureau experience! Pass the 100th enemy craft in the past five minutes? Carter's right there, with an, erm, clever WHAT IS THIS THING?" He always brings along two of his best friends who are personified in exactly the same way

reviewText:
This game might seem like an interesting alternate take on history, decent and varied shooting and a gripping storyline to boot, but it isn't.
the game itself is buggy, graphical errors, hit detection problems, constant crashing and framerate issues hamper the gameplay, at least before my save ended up being corrupted.
the story is bland, shallow and fairly meh. times that should seem tense convey a mood of slight importance. characters are weak and easily forgettable.
and as for history? most of the history in it consists of slight twists on the pseudo-60's style aesthetics of suburbia and life, even though the entire game takes place in a bunker
