reviewText:
As of writing I'm only about 6 hours in but I feel compelled to write this review now while some impressions are fresh in my mind.

Being a long time fan of the XCOM franchise I approached this game with a fair amount of skeptisism. It turns out that skeptisism was somewhat unwarranted. While I'm still not entirely sure if the game belongs in the franchise but it's more than capable of standing on it's own.

Let's get deal with it's weaknesses first; of which it's biggest by far are the clunky controls. They make movement particularly during combat a bit of a gamble. Sometimes you can't get into cover, sometimes you can't get out, sometimes you just find yourself popping out of cover and not going anywhere. I can't help but feel this comes as a result of it's console affiliation. The sprint button is the same button used to take and leave cover. Moving around corners while in cover is not performed automatically like in most games, it requires it's own keypress. Another weakness appears to be the friendly AI; they're just not terribly bright. While they seem to know when a grenade is thrown and move away, at least first, they often just rush straight back to where they were _before_ the grenade has gone off! They require constant babysitting. Sometimes they'll stay where they're instructed to, other times they'll just go wherever they please. The enemy AI aren't Einsteins either - they have a tendancy to run back and forth between two cover positions - but they appear to be more capable than the friendlies. They actually move from grenades for a start, and are capable of flanking when possible.

Now for what makes this game genuinely good. Firstly the outstanding visuals. The models, textures, lighting are brilliant. The levels are highly detailed making it feel like ones really in old 1960s America. The immersion is deepened by small touches like photos, audio reels, documents and notes, my favourite being ones that instruct folks to ask specific questions - like what sound does a dog make or where someone was when President Johnson was assassinated - to aid in identifying disguised aliens - because they aren't able to reproduce a woof" sound and they have trouble with distinguishing Human names so won't know that President Johnson wasn't assasinated. It's the sort of thing one could imagine actually happening in such a scenario. Great little touch! The story itself while not all that original is told really well through discussions with NPCs and the documents and audio reels all over the place. You get fed the story in small chunks and the underlying mystery is slowly revealed. The sound is top notch and the voice acting isn't half bad either.

The gameplay
date: now this is a bit a mixed bag. A key mechanic is the use of a "Battle Focus" mode which slows time to a crawl and allows you to issue orders to your squad. This is actually done extremely well. Moving a squadmate into cover shows the level of cover provided by that position - partial or full. Orders can be queued up for execution. They system works really well. Having said that I have a few qualms about it; I don't like the fact it just slows time down instead of pausing it altogether for example. At least it should be an option to do so. To use the main characters abilities you're required to execute them through the "Battle Focus" mode as well
recommended: you can't just push a button to do so. This is particuarly annoying when you want to heal your squad quickly
hoursPlayed: you have to open "Battle Focus"
voteText: hover over the characters skill bar
helpfulPercent: click the skill or push the number associated with that skill. I would rather just be able to push the button. Back at base the player is given the choice of missions to run; the choice varies between storyline missions which must be completed at some point and side missions. Side missions are a great way to increase the XP of the player and his squad. And that brings me to another hit-and-miss part of the game; the RPG element. The player and his squad obtain XP through kills

votesTotal: leveling up translates into new skills and stats; the usual affair. That all works just fine. One can even customise their squads names and looks - a nice touch. reviewText:
Short version: I quite enjoyed this game despite its mixed reviews; I would recommend it to anyone who's a fan of the XCOM franchise and third-person shooter games.

Short, short version: Is good game.  You buy.

Longer version: When I bought this game I went into it noting the 'Mixed' status and numerous less-than-enthusiastic reviews, thinking it to be one of those games I could ignore for a while and then install and play when I was bored enough.  In fact I played through a number of other games before getting to it.

I was surprised to find it both engaging and enjoyable.  A few people have said it has certain... similarities, shall we say, to the Mass Effect series and I'd have to agree.  It's a cover-based 3PS which involves a lot of hitting Space and going into slo-mo, issuing orders and flanking enemies.  It also has a radial conversation menu and various forms of pseudo-magical technology (most pertinently telekinesis and mind control).  Not only that but one of the squadmates' voices is done by Brandon Keener, who voiced Mass Effect's inestimable Garrus Vakarian (and he's not the only one; Courtenay Taylor, who voiced Angela Weaver in this game, also voiced Jack in the ME series - and there are plenty of others).  So that was nice.

From a story perspective it has plenty of depth for what it is: a 60s themed alien invasion game.  This isn't Shakespeare and there's no point expecting it to be.  The whole story is based around giving you excuses to go out and shoot aliens and really, isn't that what you bought the game for?

What the story doesn't have is complexity.  Don't bother looking for interpersonal nuances in this one because the conversation choices at most boil down to 'be nice' and 'be an a-hole,' with no difference in the outcome.

You can't choose your character - or, at least, you can't at first.  You play through most of the game as Agent William Carter, a generic gravelly-voiced white dude with a tragic backstory who at least lacks stubble.  Later in the game you get to make a choice between playing for a little as one of three other characters but there's no character creation (or, for that matter, character development) in this one.

The landscape is pleasing to me.  Sometimes you're in town, at other times you're in the middle of alien bases.  Sometimes it's both.  Wherever you are, though, the art style remains recognisably XCOM.  Running through alien architecture at eye level where normally you'd be directing a squad from above is definitely a novel approach.

The UI is a little cumbersome at times but, having said that, I'm not entirely sure how I'd recommend the developers could have done it differently.  It works, it gets you through the game and it's not enough to drag you out of the game so hey, I could handle it.

Mechanics are very simplfied in some ways - there is no research or XCOM base inventory, for example.  You pick up a weapon, you collect it for use by anyone in your squad who's trained to use that item type (anyone skilled in pistol use can wield a plasma pistol, for example, even if you've only ever picked up one of them).  There's no armour (though you can wear 'backpacks' and some of them do indeed reduce enemy damage).

And this is the point: The Bureau is not like other games in the XCOM series and some people find that jarring.  If you want turn-based squad mechanics with research, base inventories and other stuff like that, go to a different XCOM game (or wait for XCOM2).  This is not what you're looking for.  This is something different.

If, however, you're happy to play a 3PS game set in the same universe (if much earlier) with a story that doesn't require you to make notes on what choices you've made, this is a good one.

reviewText:
I feel the critics have been overly harsh with this game. I just finished it, having put in about 9 hours into it, I think I did the majority of the side missions too. It's definitely not Enemy Unknown, but I enjoyed it non the less.

The story was compelling, if a bit rushed in parts, and I wish they had incorporated some of the research and building aspects of Unknown but in the end I was completely happy with my purchase. The end of the game feels very rushed, and I would have liked a bit more diversity among my squad as I tended to use the same two every mission.

Definitely worth a buy though, as long as your expectations are right.

reviewText:
The idea of a 1962 XCOM is attractive, with Cold War technology and mindset to go with it.

But unfortunately the gameplay is just too repetitive to stay interested beyond the first real mission. Although a lot of hard work went into many details, in its core it is a very simple and ultimately boring game. Move to the next cover fight, move to next cover fight, etc. but without the tactics and strategy that makes the XCOM series a success. I was left with the feeling that beyond the styling - which is pretty good - this is just a poor version of Brothers in Arms.

In end even at the current discount I'd recommend to skip it.

This is a sub USD 10,- game

Actually you can miss it altogether...

And I'm sorry to say so because there are so many nice late 50-ies early 60-ies details in this game, it must have been a labour of love for many involved, but it got lost in a  simple and boring game. Even the story cannot save it

reviewText:
I'm surprised this game has so many negative reviews, since I enjoyed the game from start to finish.

A lot of people stated that their squads are dimwits and always get killed, while they struggle with their own character to get to safety. This wasn't the case in my playthrough - I completed everything without a single agent killed. I suppose once you tailor your squad to YOUR playstyle, it will become much more managable. Sure, you have to micromanage your squad like all hell before the battle, but if you do things correctly, even the toughest battles are a breeze.

....maybe I'm the 20% of people who actually enjoy the combat. Maybe.

I suppose the negative criticism is also because some people are upset that this game isn't like Enemy Unknown. Sure, the game story/choices thing mirrors Mass Effect (there's even an I should go" option)

reviewText: A vapid, soulless ripoff of Mass Effect done extremely poorly, with the XCOM name slapped on it as if that's going to make it any better.\n\nThe plot is completely ridiculous and is set up as some sort of prequel to the Firaxis XCOM games. Problem with that being that there are only token references to anything XCOM, with it becoming more and more obvious that it's a cynical cash-in the further into the game you get. Even if you remove the notion of it being an XCOM game entirely, the plot is absurd and extremely poorly-written, from the humans just somehow" being able to hotwire alien doors down to the headdesk-inducing stupidity of the major plot twist. The main character is effectively "Gruff Growly McGrowlson" without any personality or noteworthy traits other than "he's a grizzled veteran." None of the other characters are interesting in any fashion
date: instead all being cardboard cutouts that exist purely to have NPC's around to move the plot forward.\n\nThe AI
hoursPlayed: is incredibly stupid. It's not at all uncommon for your guys to run directly into enemy fire
voteText: expose themselves entirely to said enemy fire even when sitting "in cover
helpfulPercent:
get stuck on things, and so on. You're constantly having to give them orders and engage healing just so they won't get themselves killed. Enemies aren't any better, though at least they throw grenades on occasion to try to flush you out.

The shooting mechanics are functional at least, but they're nothing more than that. The weapons themselves aren't satisfying to use, and the shooting itself is just your normal cover-based shooting that you've seen in Gears of War or Mass Effect... just completely unrefined and unpolished.

The game's riddled with glitches and other technical problems, some of which are hilariously nonsensical. For example: it's an NVIDIA-optimized game, yet turning on NVIDIA's PhysX functionality causes the game to crash every single time you try to play it, until you disable the feature. Tons of animations glitches, sound bugs, and so on pop up all the time. Sometimes entire lines of dialogue are missing entirely, as if they just couldn't be bothered to implement them due to time constraints or something.

It should be noted that this game started life as an FPS. More specifically, it started off as something that looked like a really crappy version of BioShock, yet was eventually retooled into what we have now, which is a garbage Mass Effect ripoff. There's no creative drive here. No soul. It's just a game that was cobbled together to complete a contract and be a cynical cash-in on the series' popularity. Except, nobody wanted it. Fans of XCOM want more XCOM. They don't want this crap.

Needless to say, the game is awful. Don't buy it. Don't even look at it. Just let it be forgotten, as it should've been in the first place. If this weren't branded as if it's an XCOM game, it would've been completely swept under the rug as just another crappy ripoff." Let that be so."

reviewText: I was afraid to start this game because of the multifarious reviews and comments but after completing XCOM: Enemy Within a few times I decided to give it a try because it was in my library for ages. Don't expect a game similar to the turn-based tactical shooter XCOM games, it's a completely different game and to be honest it's in my opinion a weird decision to relate the game to the XCOM Universe. STILL, after playing a couple of hours I'm actually enjoying this game. It's challenging, different (in a good way) and once again your team mates can die in combat permanently. The story has a cool twist, interesting characters (the main character also looks and sounds alot like Charlie Sheen, which is actually a bonus for me!) and the combat system is very unique compared to other games in the same genre. I'm playing with a controller so I can't really comment on the consoleport issues altho i'm encountering some framerate issues from time to time but nothing that would disrupt the gameplay in a hard way. If you're in doubt check some gameplay videos, it's definitely not a game for everyone but surely a nice pickup for a couple of bucks.

reviewText:
Both the spiritual successor and spiritual predecessor to XCOM: ENEMY UNKNOWN, in this thrilling reboot, the enemy is both KNOWN and DECLASSIFIED. Although I confess that I don't actually understand the title, because in XCOM DECLASSIFIED, the enemy is not only.. well, classified.. but you engage in a vast cover-up campaign in the epilogue. Sooo. There's that. Whatever. That's not important. What IS important is that if you can overlook the gameplay, music, and writing, this game was really good! Unfortunately, and with much regret, those three things were included in the game and for some unknowable reason were made integral, and so the final score must suffer slightly as a result.

The ending was very strange with a weird narrative device that would have been interesting in a written format, but felt a little frustrating with you being ripped out of the driver's seat of your own character.

Final score: 42 tiny sectoids in my ♥♥♥♥ cavity
voteText: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText: Coming into The Bureau, I was expecting a mediocre experience at best. In my 10 hours spent with it I've learned I was wrong. So far the combat has been incredibly satisfying. Lifting a Sectoid into the air and ordering a Sniper to use a critical strike to blow its head clean off its shoulders feels incredibly fantastic. I don't know how they did it, but it feels (to me at least) like an XCOM game. Graphically, the game looks good. Not great, just good. I must admit, I had no idea that there was PhysX suport and I haven't used it yet. The story so far has been alright. Nothing truly spectacular, although it does keep me on the edge of my seat trying to figure out who you can trust. Squad customization is not nearly as deep as it is in XCOM: Enemy Unknown, but it's there. So in short, I'm enjoying my time with the game a great deal. If you enjoy XCOM and are looking for a diversion, then I highly recommend this game. If you've never played XCOM before, then I suggest starting with Enemy Unknown, not The Bureau, because c'mon, Enemy Unknown was awesome.

reviewText:
A third person Mass Effect interpretation of XCOM.  It uses a lot of the mechanics and lore from the Enemy Unknown relaunch.  Still not as good as the original.

No base building, research, or anything that you associate with XCOM games.  The missions are very linear.  There's not much variation you can really employ.

Lot of small touches to add to immersive experience if you want to explore them.  Some good visual effects, decent use of the Unreal engine.

I reccomend it.  It's a fun game.  People obviously spent some time adding the details.

reviewText:
Story: 9/10

Great start, Great twist, Great choice in endings. Not going to go too much into this because it would require spoilers. Let's just say the beginning is REALLY important to remember throughout the entire game. It's where the great twist towards the end started planting itself.

Gameplay: 8/10

A better experience than mass effect. Uses the same sort of control ( keyboard mouse/gamepad ) set up as Mass Effect franchise but it's more responsive and more action packed. Running is actually useful and you can do tight turns while running without the clunky stop and move turning mass effect had/s. Cover is useful here and needed. If you're not in cover you're dead, this isn't a run and gun. You NEED to tell your squad what to do. Management of your squad is your duty. This isn't made easy for you by having overpowered teammates.

Flanking enemy entrenchments and positions is key to winning. Falling back and moving is the only way to survive being pinned down. If you've played XCOM: Enemy Unknown you'll be familiar with the systems in play here. I will say it is dumbed down at the beginning but the Infiltrator boss fight is when the game shows it's real design. Enemies do NOT run at you like idiots they take cover and try to get you to reveal yourself by dropping grenades and setting up flanking maneuvers. As you progress enemies get more aggressive, the shielded enemies have a tendancy of flanking your team and trying to strike from vantage points. Enemies with higher health are more likely to push and attack aggressively, while enemies with lower health pools tend to hang back in cover while pressuring flanks.

Glitches: Not really a problem.

I've seen a bunch of posts about this game being glitchy and in truth, I saw almost no glitches. I had 3 things happen that didn't really break the game. To fix them I just simply picked the reload checkpoint" option in the pause menu.

1. There was a sound glitch where sounds were sort of cut off as they were fading out. making it sound like there was a stutter in dialog or just simply dialog
recommended:
or battle sounds being cut prematurely. reload checkpoint fixed this.

2. Squad member got stuck inside of something while reviving. During a mission a squad member was stuck in a bookcase when he went to try to revive a squaddie and even though I was down a team member it didn't make a difference I still finished the fight and he immediately became "unstuck" and teleported out of the glitch on his own.

3. This one didn't cause me trouble but I did have to "load a save" that was a couple of minutes behind my progress. I just lost about 3 minutes of progress and it wasn't even in a firefight but right before a boss fight. These gates are supposed to close and the way into the fight arena is supposed to be closed off. Well I spawned in a checkpointed save INSIDE the rubble. There's AMPLE checkpoints in the game and I never found myself "redo'ing" an entire fight.

Sound(track): 8/10

There's not really much to say about it
hoursPlayed: everything fits
voteText: from the 1960's music in the quiet streets of an overrun town to the creepy alien noises and loud bangs everything fits. The guns later in the game sound really good. Crisp reloading sounds let you know what gun you're using. Every gun's reload sound is different
helpfulPercent: some pop
votesHelpful: some crackle
votesTotal: some wind up. You'll know when a squad mate is pinned down and can't attack
votesFunny:
they're constantly telling you about their situation ( I'm pinned down! Need healing! I'm about to go down commander! We're being flanked! ) or asking for orders. They'll also yell out what they're using so you always know what's on cooldown ( Turret out! Cloaking! )

Length: 5/10

Unfortunately

reviewText: I picked up this game on a steam sale, amid the lackluster reviews.  While the general concept of the game was good, the story and the replayability is seriously lacking. reviewText:
Was very excited for this game, but sadly, it flopped.  Hard.

Overview :
The Bureau is a TP squad based shooter and is 2K Marins verson for XCOM.  Originally in 2010 being a FPS with really nothing to do with the original games.

The Bureau now combines TPS and strategy elements together and tries to be somewhat similar to the X:COM people know and love.  The game is real time, but if you want to assign an order to a squad mate, it slows time down to a crawl, which is Marins way of giving some love to classic X;COM fans.  Similar to waht Bethesda did with FO:3 with VATS.


Pros :
-Pretty fun squad based third-person combat (when it works).
-Upgrade trees, while not amazing, are kind of fun to go through the first time.
-It does take some thinking when faced with many enemies in a high difficulty.
-It has enemies from from classic X:COM such as Sectoids, Mutons, and Outisders, etc, while also adding new enemies to the mix, though not many.

Cons :
-Has annoying bugs, for example, when I play, if someone is talking and I look away from them, I can't hear their voice at all.  Even if I don't move away from them, but just look away.
-Now I don't know if this is a bug, or a result of being unfinished, but if you tell a squad mate to go somewhere, many times they will move away from where you told them to be.  Many times, this has ruined strategies I had planned out because they got killed or something and I couldn't do what I planned.
-it has weak ♥♥♥ graphics,
-character models look awkward
-voice acting isn't complete trash, but isn't good by any means,
- it has weak story telling.

Some other things to point out are the boss battles (in my opinion) were really lazy, the way you gain more weapons is just dumb, all you have to do is pick up an alien weapon, and then you have it for the game.  I liked X:COM EU's way of doing it where you actually had to research it and build it, THEN you get the weapon.

Last words :

I really wish they made this more like X:COM EU but with the TPS setting, but sadly, we got this.
This could have been amazing, but it really isn't worth $50 at all.  If you are okay with dealing with bugs and annoying design choices and you love TPS's, then maybe pick it up if you see it for like 30 bucks, MAYBE

Overall, it's a weak, one time playthrough game with very little heart put into it.  Sad as 2K Marin made Bioshock 2 which I thought was a phenomenal game.

The DLC also sucks as well IMO, but I won't write another review just for that.

I rate it a 4/10

reviewText:
The Bureau is no good. Play it only if you love Satan and relish human suffering.

Here is what I did not like:

The story is incoherent: The idea is that you will appropriate alien technology and use it against them sounds cool, but how can you and your squadmates already use unexplainable powers against them from the tutorial mission? Why do the player's dialogue choices do absolutely nothing?

Controls: Sluggish. In Gears of War and Mass Effect, having the 'dash' button being the same as the 'use cover' button was nice because the game understood what you were doing and wouldn't unnecessarily stick you to walls you weren't interested in. Not so in The Bureau.

Poor Performance/optimization: My gtx 735, while not the most powerful card, should be able to handle this mediocre looking game without having to go to the lowest settings.

AI: The pits.The squad AI is helpless beyond measure. They stand in the open unless told to find cover. They continue to get shot while in cover because they don't know when to shoot and when to stay down. While issuing orders, the game is not paused- only in slow motion. Your enemies are still shooting and moving while you do this. Most of your combat playtime will be in 'tactical mode.'

This game was the preorder that made me decide to never do preorders again.

reviewText: When this game was announced, i was really excited. I love XCOM a bunch. I was a bit disheartened when the game got lukewarm reviews at first, and only recently picked it up from the summer sale.\nThe game wants to be two things at once, but doesn't do either very well. it tries to be a cover based shooter, but the controls are sticky and a bit awkward. It tries to be a strategy game, but your teammates die too quickly for the to make much of a difference. Not to mention that the last level is basically XCOM horde mode if you were on wave 100, 7 times.\n

reviewText:
This game is a true tragedy.
At first the genius world building and the atmosphere capture you with a force field, especially if you are into the whole XCOM setting. Although they do quite a few things differently, you recognize all the parts effortlessly.

Unfortunately, you soon are bound to realize, that the gaming parts are quite the letdown. The missions, although well set up, are just a much tighter Mass Effect shooting gallery.
The shooting itself is very very unsatisfying. Has no impact, no class and no flow.

Customiziation is nice enough, but very shallow.

For a couple of bucks this is a nice enough romp for a few hours, nothing more.
If you like the setting, go take the plunge, if not wait for a sale maybe.

I had my fun, hence I recommend it, but they squandered the great opportunity they had with the genuine world they´ve build here...

reviewText:
Personally I love the noir feeling of the game and how it takes place in the past rather than nowadays, or in the future. It isn't like the other XCOM games, which is a welcome change. I like the leveling up system, and that you can customize Carter and your squadmates, though more customization options would have been nice.

The combat feels like Mass Effect, and has its own charm to it. I like the action mixed with having to use tactics. Battle focus is a neat thing as well if you want to know more about your enemies. Though sometimes the AI behavior can make combat a bit frustrating. It's pretty silly when I want to flank an enemy and I see my squadmate running towards me through the middle of the battlefield.

The characters and missions are, to my mind, interesting. The information you get through the dialogues and documents adds lore to the XCOM universe. And I actually really enjoyed the main story. It had a neat twist. I liked the occasional choices you could make, even though they were quite insignificant, it did make some difference in a few aspects.

I'd recommend this to anyone who is a fan of XCOM and doesn't mind the different approach!

reviewText:
I'm a huge fan of the X-COM franchise since the beginning and was very satisfied with the remake 2K published in 2012.

When The Bureau was announced as part of this franchise and the first pics were shown, I couldn't wait to see its release. But several things (mainly the third-person-perspective and the combat mechanism) kept me from buying it then.

But thanks to the latest summer sale I decided to buy it and all of its DLC.

Easy part first: the DLCs aren't worth it. One gives you an extra alien weapon, one gives you a short extra mission and the Hangar 6 R&D gives you a bit of a pre-story to the main game and some new - only (!) in that DLC available - weapons to fight through some simple 'survival' levels.

A bit complicated is the main game. While in many other cases I have problems with the third-person-perspective, it worked well in this game. Also the combat system is working good and most time satisfying, but way to simple to fullfill the tactical needs of an old X-COM veteran.

The graphic, the sounds and the characters really helps to create the right atmosphere for the game and also the different settings for the missions making it fun to play, even with a too much repetitive gameplay. And that gameplay is also the biggest issue of the game. You walk trhough the 'tunnel' maps knowing nothing will happen, until you come to a 'battlefield' (easily identified thanks to the huge amount of cover for your men and the aliens), where you fight some waves of enemies and then continue to the next 'battlefield'.

The only thing that keeps me playing was the story, which had some weird twist and gets very unsatisfying in the end. But for me, the game was worth money and I didn't regret it any minute to have bought it.

reviewText:
Feels like a disappointment, especially when compared to X-Com: Enemy Unknown. The controls are clunky. The maps are incredibly linear. The weapons and squadmates seem to have zero balance. The graphics feel really dated yet my comp is more overheated than when playing Crysis 3.

The game just feels unpolished.

*update*
I just finished this and if this is an X-Com reboot, it is a horrible one. Its basically a 3rd person shooter with almost zero elements of RPG that the original X-Com was known for. As stated before the maps are incredibly linear, the other weapon options dont' show up until the end of the game, the story is slapped together with almost no believeability with multiple major and minor inconsistencies.

The X-Com series is about capturing live aliens, researching their tech and building your own before their tech superiority overwhelms you but this game just seems to completely drop those aspects. It would have helped to plug the plotholes.

The end is just complete stupid non-sensical garbage. It always makes me rage when writers get lazy and dumb down the main characters just for the sake of furthering the plot.

reviewText:
This game is a little bit of a mixed bag

One one side you've got a very one dimensional gameplay feel a lot of the time where you end up doing the same thing over and over but the deeper you look the better the game actually gets. You can find little side missions by just looking around the main base which adds a very slight amount of things to do and the little notes and reports dotted around add to the story.

The missions themselves are also mixed, the gameplay is actually pretty intense sometimes where you actually have to plan out what you want to do next and how you want to approach a level. This is good and the squad is a good idea, I get a similar attachment to my soldiers in the actual X-COM games. The friendly AI can be beyond stupid sometimes however and just move randomly without orders into enemy fire and create loads of problems.

Going back to squads this is an element of the game I enjoy, being able to customise them (although limited) gives the soliders individuality and it's a small touch but changing their weapons and backpacks adds a little bit more strategy to an otherwise normal shooter.

Overall the game's a bit generic in its gameplay but the styling is good and it certainly has its moments, I recommend this on sale to anyone who likes shooters and also the idea of the X-COM series. Maybe for someone who likes the look of X-COM but is intimidated by the strategy of that game.

reviewText:
The Bureau – XCom Declassified was announced before XCom – Enemy Unknown and so – as many other all-time fans of the XCom/UFO-series - I was quite disappointed that 2K is going to make the sequel of one of the milestones of turn-based strategy games a shooter. With XCom – Enemy Unknown released and being a worthy successor to the series my initial rage faded away. So now that I don't have to treat The Bureau as a sequel but rather a spin-off, curiosity made me buy this title. And to my surprise I was quite pleased with the approach 2K took on the theme – at first.

The XCom setting is transferred into the late 1950ies with the USA suffering from anti-communist paranoia. The first abductions, alien attacks and UFO sightings are misinterpreted as a soviet invasion by authorities.

If you played any XCom titles you will get familiar with your enemies, weapons and abilities quickly. Also in the XCom-HQ, which you can roam and explore between field missions, you will find all the well-known departments like Engineering, R&D, Hangars and Infirmary. Merging the 1950ies with the XCom theme breathes new life into the franchise and works quite well. I liked to see my sniper wearing a vest and tie while aiming for a hostile commander or my Tech/Engineer wearing some ordinary janitor jumpsuit while blasting Sectoids into smithereens.

During missions you control your own character and via the command interface, which significantly slows down the time and allows to scan the surroundings, you can issue orders to two additional agents. Even though it's a 3rd person view you will use well-known tactics you would use in the strategy games as hide and cover, flank the enemies and focus fire. Success heavily relies on the use of those tactics as well as yours and your agents special abilities like mind-control, critical strike and deploying additional equipment as turrets, mines and drones. So The Bureau actually is a tactical shooter and run and gun will get you killed.

Unfortunately the game constantly prevents you from using these tactics. The missions are (as the whole game) heavily scripted and linear. Approaching a hostile encounter is always announced by a checkpoint save and a cliff, high boxes or another obstacle you have to jump off down into the battlearena. In the first half of the game these battlearenas are so small and the provided possibilities for cover so few, that you don't have much choice where to deploy agents and what tactics to use. In fact it feels like a longwinded tutorial.
In the second half of the game the battlearenas get much larger and you have a lot of possibilities to flank enemies and can diversify your tactics. Unfortunately your character has a very restricted area of command. So I have my heavy gear guy flank the enemy on the right side while sending my sniper to a vantage point. But as soon as I move my character and any of my agents aren't covered by the area of command anymore, they start closing in to me ignoring any enemies or any order given beforehand.

The poor technical optimization is the second major annoyance. Even though I have a decent gaming rig, I wasn't able to play with DX11 but had to turn down to DX9 and even then I had <30fps until I turned off the PhysX features. This game devours system resources without giving much back.

But even more annoying than the above-mentioned are all the inconsistencies of the plot. You will find dialogues missing, making some answers given by NPCs meaningless. And despite the story has a nice twist in the later part of the game, you will feel there are parts missing and obviously the world and the plot were meant to be more fleshed out in the first place. At least the german voice acting is quite good.
First playthrough ~20hrs.

reviewText:
Inept AI, consolitis, contrived level designed ruined what could have been a fun casual shooter.

Positives:
- Looks pretty nice.
- Voice work very well done overall.
- Decent/interesting story.

Negatives:
- Suffers greatly from consolitis: sprint, take/leave cover, jump obstacle and more toggled by a single button. This means you might just enter cover instead of sprinting, getting you killed.
- AI which drives you up the wall, constantly running into fire and never hitting anything.
- Limited command radius amplifies the above issue 10x.
- Poor level design significantly limits options during fights.

reviewText:
6.5/10

Great look and feel, fun gameplay, a bunch of fun characters and a storyline that’s gritty at times and campy at times. Overall I enjoyed the game, but unfortunately The Bureau keeps teasing so much more that it doesn’t deliver on. I was constantly left in a state of feeling mislead and disappointed (spoilery examples below).

I recomend this game if:
1. You liked the combat mechanics of Mass Effect
2. Didn't like it in Mass Effect when your decisions impacted the storyline
2b. Can convince yourself this is a sort of retro Mass Effect DLC
3. Like watching Facilities and Operations personnel do their jobs.
4. You really enjoyed watching Super 8
5. You think smoking is cool.

--MILD SPOILERS and WITTY CRITICISMS ahead—

Me: Hey game, you really nailed that 1960’s look and feel. You’d think nobody could look tough in 1960’s tweed pants and sweaters, but boy! My character looks tough as nails!  And I love how you contrast the quintessential, idyllic setting of small-town america against the cold gruesome architecture of the invading aliens.
Game: Why thank you! Did you notice how I even touch on some of the social tensions of the 1960s? Like racial issues, sexism, and the paranoia inherent in McCarthyism?
Me: I did! It’s maybe a little heavy-handed at times, but no biggie; I’m still really excited to see how these social issues are explored as the game progresses.
Game: I’m glad you noticed! Because soon enough these concepts will all just fade into the background and even though you’ll want to discuss them with NPCs, it’ll never come up as an option!
Me: Oh… okay.

----

Game: Hey, look at all these unique NPCs, each with thier own unique personality. You know, if the combat reminds you of Mass Effect, then I bet it's just as important to invest in these characters like you do in Mass Effect. After all, I stress SUPER HARD that this game is about collaboration and teamwork under pressure. And the dialogue mechanics are eerily similar to Mass Effect!
Me: I liked that about Mass Effect, Mr. Game, so I'll totally spend as much time interacting with NPCs between missions as I spend on the missions themselves. Plus, as I talk with them I learn more about my own characters' personality and grizzled past. I want to know more about the mysterious, hard-headed protagonist than just about any of the other characters.
Game: Good idea! Dig up his story as much as you can. That way, you totally won't expect how that “I’m difficult to work with, but always get the job done Clint Eastwood-style protagonist totally loses his effin marbles at the end and you have the play the last chapter as some omnipotent alien puppet-master taking possession of characters you never really care about.
Me: I'm sorry
recommended: in that last chapter where are all those folks I spent the whole game learning about? The ones I DID care about?\nGame: I’m sorry

who?

reviewText:
So, let's ignore that this isn't an XCOM Game.  Let's ignore that there is no strategic overview, no internal economy, no research trees, manufacturing, UFO combat, or any continuity in the new XCOM EU universe.

This game is, at its core, a bland cover shooter.  There are three hallways in this game that you fight in: Main Street USA, Rural USA, and Generic Gray-Blue Spaceship corridor.   Fighting in deep space, on an alien planet, or on an Earthbound Alien base?  Gray-Blue Corridor.  Travel 600 light years to an alien satellite?  Gray Blue Corridor.  Head into earth orbit on a spaceship that should really be called the Firestorm?  Gray-Blue Corridors.   That's all this game is - walk down a hallway, crouch behind cover, and shoot aliens while trying to keep your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ AI team mates alive.

While it seems there is the potential for some deep tactical action in your engagements, the extremely short leashes that your teammates are kept on interferes with their ability to flank the enemy.  You can try to set up a recon agent to shoot from an elevated position, but if you move forward to get in range of your shotgun, the short leash that your teammates are on simply means they will move up to the front lines with you.

When you boil it all down, the game is just dreadfully boring.  The combat gets old dreadfully fast when you have to spend most of your time just keeping your AI alive on the higher difficulties and outside of picking one of three ending narrations you get, no other choice you make throughout the game has ANY impact.

reviewText: The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a 3rd-person tactical shooter that takes place during the 1960's and absolutely nails its setting. reviewText:
It's quite a fun game and yeah, it totally nails the cool B-movie 50's aesthetic - it looks really pretty, too. I actually enjoy the story, and you get to even wander around the base and talk to people and meet some crazy scientists and help them with stuff. Really, if it hadn't had the XCOM name attached to it The Bureau would've been (aside from the preconceived 3rd person shooter notions that are wrong) pretty decently received. Because it's actually a nice game.

Let me explain.

The thing about The Bureau is that in order to enjoy any sort of victory, you'll HAVE to constantly be controlling your team mates. You can think of it in terms of babysitting (as some have who didn't like it) or you can treat the game as turn-based that happens to play out in near real-time (with pause).

What I mean by that is that in a turn-based game you have to control each of your characters, telling them where to go and what to do each move" instead of letting them do the Mass Effect thing of allowing them their own agency while occasionally ordering them to do a specific action. Also
date: this is not a game where you can hunker down behind a wall and peek out to snipe at enemies - anyone who tries that will get killed quick
recommended: you or your teammates (or the enemies). Always be moving.\n\nBecause of the real-time(with pause) gameplay mixing with the third person shooter aesthetic it can be initially confusing to try and mesh the strategy of one with the mechanics of the other
hoursPlayed: but so far it's been pretty darn cool. And hard. Mutons are no joke; tactical withdrawls while trying to flank a giant armored

votesTotal: enemies occasionally try and get around you

commentsCount: but you generally have options in battle
column16: which is nice
column17: and it's usually a challenge.\n\nJust to reiterate
column18: people want to play it like ME3 or Gears of War or some other third person shooter with some partner AI
column19: while it should instead be played more like a legitimate strategic/tactical game where you're not a main character
column20: but directly controlling all three on your team. If you rely on the partner AI to do anything for you strategically you're going to watch them fail and you're going to repeatedly lose - and then hate the game. You need to be treating it as a realtime w/ pause game of action chess or something to get anywhere with it. The gameplay might not be for you

reviewText:
Positives: Wonderful setting, competent shooting mechanics, cool concept, beautiful art, functional music.

Negatives: Frustrating AI, inconsistent characterisation, apparently baffling story (although I personally didn't get that far), an unlikable protagonist, other tiny problems with combat (described below).

If you go into this expecting a game like Mass Effect rather than X-COM, you won't feel particularly cheated, but the gameplay just isn't as solid as a Mass Effect game.

I wanted so badly to love this game - I loved the setting, I loved the concept, and I thought it was really wonderful that the developers were trying a bunch of new things. However, while this game isn't broken and it isn't terrible, there are just so many flaws that drag it into mediocre territory. After about 3 hours, I lost interest, and I simply wasn't having fun.

The biggest thing that frustrated me was the inconsistent characterisation on display, especially from the protagonist. He's painted as a noir-like loose cannon that gets the job done, but this is just frustrating - he  bafflingly switches from treating characters with respect to ignoring orders just because, and seems seriously shaken up by the loss of a character he's just met despite being grumbly and disaffected about everything. It's as if the writers couldn't decide who they wanted him to be.

I also have a few issues with the combat which were individually not deal-breakers but were frustrating when added together:
- Control is often taken away from the player for unplayable cut-scenes which add absolutely nothing to the game
- Weapons lack impact, many enemies take a frustrating amount of damage to put down
- Combat scenes feel like they drag on too long consistently, additional spawning enemies feel frustrating
- Because there is no crosshair outside of aiming, bringing up the sniper scope doesn't necessarily point it at the enemy you were looking at. Add this to the insane amounts of time between shots and for reloading the sniper rifle, and one of the most satisfying weapons becomes one of the most frustrating
- Cover mechanics more complicated than they need to be when it comes to rounding corners or leaving cover
- Team mate AI is often bad. Engineers stand in front of their own turrets taking damage without moving. Your squadmates mindlessly hang around detonating mines. And they never seem to do any damage - they seem to fulfill more of a babysitting role. I understand that this is to make the player feel empowered but I'd at least like my team of crack professionals to be competent!

The tone of the game switches frequently - an audio log found in a university plays a professor reproaching his assistant for 'not following his intuition and relying on evidence'. Because that's what being a scientist is like....? And I seriously have to question why an institution that's meant to be the best of the best is so full of 'loose cannons who don't play by the rules'. If this is meant to tie in to any sort of X-Com canon, I've never considered my squaddies in other games to be dismissed alcoholics or police with a criminal history. It's a pity that this little thought was put into the setting and characterisation because the artwork is convincing and consistently impressive.

I would have loved for this game to be so much more. I'd pick it up on sale if the above issues don't bother you much.

reviewText: In general, there’s little to recommend as far as The Bureau goes. The game essentially tries so hard to be 60s Mass Effect, but really only succeeds on the former front, in that it’s 60s as hell. Seriously, it’s the sole shining point here; The Bureau is inundated with shirt-tie-and-vest combos, classic cars, transistor tube radios, and chrome as far as the eye can see, which really injects the proceedings with a much-needed sense of atmosphere. Unfortunately, everything else solidly falls within the realm of mediocrity; the blandly-written protagonist is your typical gruff “tormented past, seeks redemption through fighting the new threat” archetype, and the gameplay that you experience through him is a weird, somewhat tedious fusion of third-person shooter and XCOM-style strategy.\n\nDon’t get me wrong, the visuals and effects of the abilities themselves are quite cool (especially in the late game, where you get access to turrets and airstrikes), but you have to hand-hold the inept AI that utilizes them so much that, in the end, you’re gonna be spending 50% of the time shepherding them through every action via Battle Focus (this game’s tactical view), and the other 50% running around and reviving them because they’re so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed fragile. Seriously, does the COM in XCOM stand for “Clothes Only, Men”? … (I’m so, so sorry.) Anyway, as a result there is a sort of franticness to the combat in that regard, but unlike its sister game Enemy Unknown, the management of lives is more frustrating than heart-poundingly tense due to the increased repetition and frequency at which “getting downed” occurs. In any case, if you end up purchasing this game (I personally wouldn’t unless it’s less than 7ish dollars), play on “Squaddie” difficulty or below, as there is less a focus on team micro-management, and more an emphasis on blasting aliens with space magic.

reviewText:
I did not expect to enjoy this game. My first reaction to hearing about it was to scream, in Spoony's words, BETRAYAL! But to my surprise, I ended up really liking it.

There's no doubt that this game could be so much more. It should be bigger, and more complex. Some of its ideas deserve fleshing out far more. Sometimes the plot skips ahead in ways it shouldn't. And yet... I was engrossed. I liked the characters, the style, the atmosphere; I liked the writing, too. In a way it felt much more human and engaging than XCOM: Enemy Unknown. (At least the German scientist made sense!)

And the combat? What can I say, I thought it was a lot of fun. I could actually imagine playing a proper X-Com game in this style. To be perfectly honest, I think I enjoyed it more than its successful strategic sibling, but that's probably because I couldn't quite get into XCOM:EU's weird mix of detail and streamlining, which I know other people loved. (My personal favourite is X-Com: Apocalypse, so maybe I'm just weird.)

It's almost certainly not a game for everyone, but it's not a disaster, either. If you're in the right mood, it's a very solid experience. I don't regret playing it.

reviewText:
It's a nice game when you are a fan of X-com, you get some more story behind everything and the atmosphere is spot on. The game itself is fun at the beginning, at least I could stomach it for a while, but it gets tedious after a few missions.

It's the typical corridor shooter you expect these days, but this time you can predict exactly when you run into enemies. Encounter a group, run through some hallways, drop down and have another encounter... rinse and repeat.

The management of your crew is shallow and it gets old after a few battles, so before half the game I didn't bother much with it. Other games do a far better job at it. For me the ammo scarcity was also a problem, having to find the right ammo type during each battle felt like a gimmick just to get me out deeper into the battlefield rather than hanging back. A little bit more capacity would have done the trick for me.

The last two hours I had to force myself to finish the game, just because it was so repetitive.

I'd still recommend this game, but... at a highly reduced price, and only if you are a fan of X-com.

reviewText:
As someone who enjoys the difficulty associated with the unforgiving nature of strategic, turn-based combat that is the hallmark of previous games under the XCOM title, all I can do is be honest and say that this game did not live up to that, even on harder difficulties.

The bullet-time planning mode, while convenient if anything unexpected happened, was otherwise unnecessary, besides combat being fairly linear and predictable anyway: For the majority of battles, you can simply sit behind cover and murder anyone who pops their head up to try and shoot you. Every major combat area provides more than enough ammo to restock anything you would have used. Using abilities serves only to finish a particular battle a few seconds quicker and conserve a clip or two.

You can ignore your teammates entirely since they deal substantially less damage over time than you and their AI's are remarkably self-sufficient, plus they never run out of ammo and will revive each other unless otherwise ordered by you.

Without leaking spoilers, it can at least be said that the plot is forced and the ending anti-climactic. Plus the achievements offer essentially no challenge, most of which I unlocked by accident without even trying.

The only conceivable highlight about the game, the one that kept me playing, was the variance in settings, which was enjoyable. Still, about mid-game it becomes clearly noticeable that the basic layout of all maps is the same, especially in combat areas, and it is only the appearance of the obstacles and backgrounds that differentiates them.

All-in-all, a disappointing experience that I would not recommend to any sincere XCOM fan, and not one I would replay even to 100% for the few achievements I managed to miss.

reviewText:
The 3rd person combat is fluid and fast paced, and strategic maneouvers using squad members gives a good amount of control over how you want to play out engagements. Higher difficulties demonstrate this extremely well.

The story is quite alright. If you decide to play out each choice in the dialog wheel however, you might find yourself listening to ALOT of talking. They give good information about situations, but can be quite a hassle if you're not a big fan of this. Some parts of the story feel a bit rushed or lack context, but flows nicely.

It plays similar to Mass Effect; dialog wheels, a mass effect 3rd person combat feel, and having a sci-fi/alien atmosphere to it.

XCOM DECLASSIFIED IS A PRETTY NEAT GAME.

8.5/10

reviewText:
It's been awhile since I've played Gears of War...

For those that have played Enemy Unknown, this is NOT the same thing. There are the obvious surface similarities - squad based, aliens, and obviously, the brand name. Beyond that, this is a different ballpark entirely. Instead of a table top strategy game, pushing units around, and dealing in percentages with a combat system reminiscent of old school Fallout, now the game runs in real time, with a third person over the shoulder view for what is really another shooter. The movement and cover system is akin to the Gears combat movement system. In fact, I'd call it a Gears clone if it didn't have the obviously superior ability to issue orders to your squad - something that franchise sorely lacked. Playing this, parallels to the Uncharted franchise also come to mind, especially regarding things like ammo management and having to scout around the battlefield for reloads. Other parallels can be drawn to Mass Effect, as many others have here.

This is NOT Enemy Unknown. It certainly isn't up to the level of difficult brutality that Enemy Unknown is.

Will I keep playing it and finish the campaign? Sure.

Is it fun? Yeah.

Would I drop 20 bucks on it? No.

Coming from Enemy Unknown to this, I can understand how people would be a bit disappointed.

Pick it up on sale, or get it bundled in with some other XCOM games.

6.5/10

reviewText: This game was simply pretty fun. A lot of the negative reviews come talk about the bad AI, but I never had huge problems with that. Sure, occasionally they'd leave cover for no reason or do other stupid positioning things, but it was never anything game-breaking, just an occasional minor annoyance. My one main problem with the game was that when you go into tactical mode where you're giving orders to your team, it doesn't paus the action, just puts it in slow-motion. This can lead to issues with trying to set up combos or time certain things correctly, because by the time you're done giving orders, the enemy might have moved or your first operative will have already started doing their action. But once you get used to the timing, it stops being really noticable. The story was pretty good, and I enjoyed getting to choose which classes to take into the field, therefore completely changing up how you fight in battles. This isn't anything like the other XCOM games, but if you go into it knowing that, then it's a fine game on its own.\n\nSo my conclusion is, this was a decent game that doesn't deserve all the negativity it got. I don't know if I would have paid full price for it (and I didn't, because of reading the negative reviews), but if you can catch it on sale, it's definitely worth it if you enjoy third-person, squad-based shooters.

reviewText:
I think this is an example of a game which has poor reviews for the wrong reasons. Like many, I'd just finished playing XCOM - Enemy Unknown and was hungry for a continuation of that. While still set in the XCOM 'universe', it's a very different style of game and many of the negative reviews will be because of that, which is unfair to what is actually a pretty good game. They've made a brave attempt at making a game which isn't a guaranteed money maker, and I think they've done a pretty good job. I love it when developers don't paint by numbers.

It's a third-person shooter not dissimilar in gameplay to Mass Effect, though set in the swinging 60's (with a very 50's feel), you have 2 squadmates who you give commands to during Battle Focus (slo-mo), as you work your way through linear mission levels. Personally I'm not fussed by linear levels - I'll take them over non-linear ones which just give the illusion of choice to fill out gameplay time.

The game itself is fairly short if you just go through the main missions, though if you're a completionist doing all the side missions and exploring the base properly, and going after achievements, you'll get roughly triple the game time to about 20-25 hours.

The graphics are good, and the scenery and level design excellent. They've clearly put alot of work into quality over quantity, and I actually feel bad about not standing around too long to just look at what's been put into it, especially mid to late game. However, if your computer's falling behind on the ol' hardware department, you might find your framerate dropping noticeably in areas.

Aliens are what you would expect from an xcom game, and I found the later game to get a bit easy due to a strong compliment of abilities. Still, I enjoyed all the combat, and if you're having trouble with your agents chasing after you when you try to flank the enemy, just manually move them to cover first so they aren't in follow mode.

This game's not for everyone. Some will find the pace a bit slow, especially in the base, but honestly the game is 80% off at the time of writing this review (£2.99 ..$4.43 at current rate), which is an absolute steal for the work that's gone into it. If people reviewed the game removing both their expectations, and personal preference for what games they like, and instead based it on the quality of the game itself for its genre (which is what reviews should be based on, not personal taste), then it would be somewhere in the positives for sure.

reviewText:
The Bureau: XCOM Declassified hasn't been given the best reviews and there are reasons for that. It has a lot of the right parts to be a good game, unfortunately I feel they missed the mark on making it excellent and instead ended up making a slightly less than average game. Only worth it if you want the experience and if you get it for a discount.

Combat:

- It is difficult at times to place your abilities such as mines and turrets, especially when the height changes.

- The shift key controls your sprint and also ducking into and around cover which can get finicky at times.

- While in the tactical command screen it is sensitive and swaps between characters a little too easily.

Story:

- Not much to it.

- They don't emotionally pull you in or make you feel connected to any characters.

- Your choices don't seem to matter at all.

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game! It pushes several of my happy buttons, from the XCOM branding, to the Cold War paranoia, to the retrofuturistic aesthetic. This could have been the ambitious first entry in a new spin-off franchise... but unfortunately, nearly everything in the game is marred by a clear lack of polish.

I could write about the outdated interface (no mission objectives onscreen or all the other nice little UI touches we've come to expect over the last 20 years), the poor level design (lots of railroading and impassable waist-high obstacles), or several other issues, but by far the worst offender is the combat system. Instead of a fluid, enjoyable experience like Mass Effect 2 or 3, the tactical squad combat is clunky, poorly explained, and extremely unforgiving. It's the heart of the game, and it simply isn't fun.

Overall, The Bureau: XCOM Declassified isn't a bad game... just a mediocre one. It does nothing terribly, but nothing particularly well, either. I found myself simply grinding through each little combat set-piece in the hopes that I could reach a more rewarding part of the game, but eventually I just gave up -- my leisure hours are limited, and there are simply more entertaining ways to spend them.

reviewText:
The Bureau is a professionally-developed ‘prequel’ to arguably the best series of PC games ever developed. It attempts bring the infamous tactical combat series to the console with Mass Effect inspired squad-based real-time battles. It utterly fails as a PC game and shames the XCOM title.

Writers attempted to push the envelope in a few areas: two major characters include a gay Australian medical doctor and a senior female agent who struggles with the patriarchy of the era. Unfortunately, there is still the trope German scientists and the uncreatively written, guilt-driven by typical lost-love protagonist. The main quest develops much too fast, introducing new characters and pivots before the lead agent has sufficiently investigated the story or the player can understand justification for the last plot twist. The non-combat ‘investigation’ missions teased early on in development were never realized.

Checkpoint saves, specifically before [skip-able] cutscenes break the games flow. For large battles, this is very demoralizing as failure to defeat a large end-boss means playing through waves of weak enemies ramping up to the climax that you've already seen several times. Combat is at its best when it clones gameplay that we've already seen in BioWare games. Special abilities distributed amongst your always-leveling squad are over-powered compared to level design which teases tactical flanking but is never effective at harder difficulties.

Several weapons and items are under-powered and the player has no motivation to explore strategies with them, others (e.g. the blaster launcher) are all-but-required for taking down large enemies. The 'equipment pack' modifier to soldier abilities doesn’t hold a candle to mother XCOM’s soldier customization options. A total conversion of the XCOM:EU for the 60s era would suffice better than this poorly executed attempt at a prequel. Not only would I recommend not buying this, I'd avoid playing it too.

reviewText:
What a surprise. I read many nay-saying reviews about this one but picked it out of the sale with all DLC for under a fiver on a whim. It was well worth it!

General tactical game mechanic is almost exactly the same as Mass Effect 2/3, slightly better actually. 2 team members to order about, picked from a roster of crew that you can customise to suit your play style, the typical classes like engineer, sniper, support etc - its by no means perfect, you can't strip out its console friendly interface roots but its generally okay.

As with any tactical shooter as soon as your AI team mates think for themselves your like WTF are you doing? and when they are not thinking for themselves your like WTF are you doing? Dammed if they do or don't pretty much all the time, baby sit them, go here-stay there. I didn't have any huge problems with the AI other than them running into enemy fire and randomly jumping out of cover to smash a window or something. Mass Effect 2/3 covery-style system and err... 'powers' like lift, push are almost plagiaristic but acceptible given the way they are presented. Certian commands appear to be missing, such as if you would like a squad member to fall in but leave another one on a position, the command simply doesn't exist. There is no 'hold fire' and there isn't any automatic use of 'powers' option for AI, you have to think for everyone, all the time in battle.

There is a big problem with the issuing of orders, when in tactical mode you become sort of like a ghost and everything is in bullet time. You are able to issue orders to your squad but in this mode however you are still restrained by walls and barriers. So to place a mine or call a fire mission in to that critical location you have to 'move' there as a human would, like down some stairs and around the wall... you can't just move the cursor there and click go. Its definitely to do with this title being a console port and you can work around it but its very, very annoying.

Voice acting, plot, atmosphere - authentic and brilliant, its XCom but probably not as you know it. You don't really need to be a fan of the series to play this, its a bit off piste - The Xcom theme is there with some alien name drops, tech name drops and a bit of background but its heavily diluted. The plot at the end it gets a bit... erm, out of hand probably the best way to say it - still hugely enjoyable but not quite what I thought.

As I got it under a fiver in the sale with all DLC I suspect it'll be there again, next time its there I'd get it if you're looking for a pretty decent story to sink into for a bit with a few tactical elements thrown in.

[EDIT] Hanger 6 DLC
You get to play DeSilva which is a character in the main story that unfortunately isn't built in enough, but this DLC changes that. Worth it if its 'included' probably adds about 2-2.5 hours if your embracing  all the dialogue and reading all the documents as well as the missions. Some good firefights here.

reviewText:
I got this game cheap from the Humble Bundle so I can't really complain too much. Overall, it's not a bad game, but I felt that I should warn anyone considering picking this game up. Best way I can describe this game is, it's like playing Mass Effect 2 with the first game's horrible horrible AI companion. I've had them randomly get up and run straight at the enemies or get out of cover for no reason. The combat areas are pretty well designed (some pretty big) giving you a chance to flank the enemies however, there seems to be a leash between you and your squad which makes it hard to set up some strategy because they'll randomly get ported to your location and sometime in the middle of the battle out of cover.

Two things I liked about the combat in this game, and I hope we see it in future games like this, is the ability to tell your squad exactly where to go and the ability to queue up actions. Once you start unlocking more abilities for your squad, the game defnitely gets better. There are some cool interaction between different class' abilities. If you can put up with the horrible AI, you might enjoy the game.

reviewText: Don't let the phrase X-Com in the title fool you, this is nothing like Enemy Unknown, in style, quality, or replayability. I had such high hopes for this game that I preordered it, picturing tactical combat against all the classic X-Com enemies. Basically, I wanted to be the soldiers I was sending to their doooms in Enemy Unknown. What I got was basically all the most boring parts of Mass Effect's combat system, and a story that couldn't be more forgettable. Combat isn't tactics, it's patience. It is incredibly hard to die, and if you do your completely replaecable squadmates will usually be able to revive you. Enemies take forever to die, most boss fights devolving into you running around looking for ammo as your teammates slowly tick down their gigantic health bars. The ability to customize your companions is very limited, you can only change their guns and add an enhancement item that reduces damage, cooldowns, etc. Oh, and you can change the color of their suits.\nThe story doesn't make you feel any sort of emotion, it's just Mission X and Agent Y, mixed with a 60's thematic and sci-fi cliches. The X-Com headquarters is kind of neat, but once you realize there is nothing to do there it loses some charm. Maybe it gets better in the last third of the game, but I have a hard time believing dessert will be excellent after spooning down so much gruel.\nAs I said, I was very high on this game based on the trailers and the excellence of its strategy counterpart, but there is nothing in the execution of this title that backed up that promise. Of my 6 hours, I don't think I had fun for more than 5-10 minutes, and I don't think I will ever play it again. I bought it at ~50 dollars, and a month later it was on sale for 19.99.   That is not an accident.

reviewText:
Definitely would not recommend it above $10.

Pros:  It has a interesting retro 50s feel to it.   Story seemed to be going okay, as far as I played.

Cons: Just about everything else.  Notably the AI is absolutely terrible.   The game is designed around you controlling two partners that are supposed to help you fight.  They don't.   They simply disobey your orders at every conceivable opportunity and are mega-suicidal to boot, often breaking cover to run TOWARD the grenade.    Also notably bad is the UI.  Clearly was intended to be another badly ported game made only for controllers.   The UI to give commands requires you to navigate a checkpoint around obstacles and through mazes for every command, even when its not a line of sight action.    Frustrating is the best word for it when you can't even pause the game entirely to issue the orders.

Just doesn't work.   After watching my 10th squad member in a row, move away from where I told him to set up cover, I finally uninstalled it and dropped it into the trash category.    What exactly is the point of a squad level tactical game, when the AI refuses to do as its told?

If it hits a steam sale at some point, maybe it might be worth it then, just don't set you expectation beyond terrible".    A game should be meant to be challenging because of the content
date: not because the player is fighting with the game mechanics."

reviewText:
Let me preface this by saying that I got this game in a Humble Bundle, and it was in the lowest tier of that Humble Bundle. Ostensibly I paid less than a dollar for this game. So it's hard for me to make a judgement call on value with this, since even the worst game that you play for two hours and only cost you 33 cents, well... you've got your money's worth.

Let me continue by saying that this game is a steaming pile of dog ♥♥♥♥. The controls are rubbish, the graphics options are nearly non-existant, constant fps problems, the animations are laughably bad (the lip syncing is actually pretty hilarious, It's like watching a poorly dubbed movie), and to cap it all off... The most egregious problem.... It's boring.

It had such a promising premise. 1950's alien attack conspiracy government shizzwa, capped with an rpg system over shooter controls. But it's clunky. Everything works but it feels incomplete. Floaty movement, bad AI, shooting that doesn't care where your crosshairs are situated, and the constant stream of dialogue that makes you stop in your tracks while you listen to them talk about stuff that you already know (because you were there when it happened).

I can forgive a game that doesn't have a great story but plays well. I can even love a game with a wonderful story and sub-par gameplay. The fact that this game feels like they weren't even trying? It's sad really, because it has the bones of a successful story and decent gameplay. Pure execution failure.

reviewText: This corridor shooter is based heavily on tactical movement with your squad. The problem is that controlling your squad members is like herding cats. They will frequently run to places you didn't tell them to go, fail to shoot at anything, and even flee from shielded areas you just told them to place. That's fine in a game like Mass Effect 2, where your squad just gets up after combat, but in The Bureau, they die permanently.\n\nI like the world and story that the game creates, but when I spend more than half my time in combat trying to save my soldiers from their own stupid AI, then it's a bad time.

reviewText:
Definitely would not recommend it above $10.

Pros:  It has a interesting retro 50s feel to it.   Story seemed to be going okay, as far as I played.

Cons: Just about everything else.  Notably the AI is absolutely terrible.   The game is designed around you controlling two partners that are supposed to help you fight.  They don't.   They simply disobey your orders at every conceivable opportunity and are mega-suicidal to boot, often breaking cover to run TOWARD the grenade.    Also notably bad is the UI.  Clearly was intended to be another badly ported game made only for controllers.   The UI to give commands requires you to navigate a checkpoint around obstacles and through mazes for every command, even when its not a line of sight action.    Frustrating is the best word for it when you can't even pause the game entirely to issue the orders.

Just doesn't work.   After watching my 10th squad member in a row, move away from where I told him to set up cover, I finally uninstalled it and dropped it into the trash category.    What exactly is the point of a squad level tactical game, when the AI refuses to do as its told?

If it hits a steam sale at some point, maybe it might be worth it then, just don't set you expectation beyond terrible".    A game should be meant to be challenging because of the content
date: not because the player is fighting with the game mechanics."

reviewText:
Let me preface this by saying that I got this game in a Humble Bundle, and it was in the lowest tier of that Humble Bundle. Ostensibly I paid less than a dollar for this game. So it's hard for me to make a judgement call on value with this, since even the worst game that you play for two hours and only cost you 33 cents, well... you've got your money's worth.

Let me continue by saying that this game is a steaming pile of dog ♥♥♥♥. The controls are rubbish, the graphics options are nearly non-existant, constant fps problems, the animations are laughably bad (the lip syncing is actually pretty hilarious, It's like watching a poorly dubbed movie), and to cap it all off... The most egregious problem.... It's boring.

It had such a promising premise. 1950's alien attack conspiracy government shizzwa, capped with an rpg system over shooter controls. But it's clunky. Everything works but it feels incomplete. Floaty movement, bad AI, shooting that doesn't care where your crosshairs are situated, and the constant stream of dialogue that makes you stop in your tracks while you listen to them talk about stuff that you already know (because you were there when it happened).

I can forgive a game that doesn't have a great story but plays well. I can even love a game with a wonderful story and sub-par gameplay. The fact that this game feels like they weren't even trying? It's sad really, because it has the bones of a successful story and decent gameplay. Pure execution failure.

reviewText:
This game could have been so much fun....

Artwork, atmosphere, sound - it's all been done really good. But the game has a serious flaw in gameplay. No matter what you order your soldiers to do, 4 seconds later they do again what they want. And doing what they want is mostly running directly into the open field and die in enemy fire. Even if they don't do that, you'll be constantly wondering, where your soldiers are, because 1 second after your ordered them somewhere, they run off to some stupid place.

That reduces all tactical gameplay to absurdity, you'll end up repeatedly playing every level over and over again until you occasionally beat the enemy or until you get tired of giving your soldiers new orders about every second to prevent them running off and dying.

The statistics reflect the problem, kills by me: 45, kills by my soldiers: 2.

Hey developers, did you ever test this game before you released it? Hilarious.

reviewText:
In an alternate timeline: The year is 1950. Donald Draper never joined Sterling Cooper to work as an ad man, he remained in the army and rose through the ranks. Eventually recruited by the CIA, he becomes involved with The Bureau, and helps fight off an alien invasion of Earth. Thats this game in a nutshell: Donald Draper shooting aliens.

The gameplay is fun, at first. The Third person shooter + squad combat is neat on the first mission, when you get agents with all their abilities unlocked. But then it takes that away and you have to -slowly- level them up again. Gameplay is largely the same, fighting the same 2 aliens over and over again, except when they occasionally throw in a muton or sectopod battle. Also, one of the big bosses froze up on me and just sat there as my squad gunned it down. Long set peices showing off the devestated cities lead up to cover based combat sections in a predictable pattern. For some reason, there's more ammo than you can carry in the areas without enemies.

The characters suffer from a bad case of rubber face, and the shot-reverse-shot dialogue trees become tedious very fast. Which sucks, because apparently a bunch of content is hidden in the speech you go through in the base.

It's a cool game in premise, but it doesnt quite live up to what it could have been. A few tweaks and a little more though into varying gameplay would have gone very far in making this better. Although it is a totally different game, XCOM Enemy Unknown does a better job at Squad based alien killin fun. I got this in the Humble Bundle, so its okay for the price, but I wouldnt recommend buying this game straight up, unless it's on sale.

reviewText:
I think a lot of reviews for this game were unfair - perhaps written by people expecting a reboot of the earlier games with their turn-based gameplay.

I bought this game as a cheap diversion in one of the sales. I've played and completed the turn-based predecessors in the XCOM series but I started this game with an open mind and really enjoyed playing it.

Yes, bits of the story annoyed the hell out of me (particularly the turn of events towards the end of the game) but you know what? I think 2K did a really good job of melding turn-based combat with FPS action and I really enjoyed playing it to the end.

It didn't take long to complete - 20 hours in total (and that was to get some achievements) so it's not a patch on Borderlands in terms of longevity but good while it lasted.
