reviewText:
I never read a review of this game until after I had beaten it.  I wasn't terribly interested in buying it based on the poor review scores it received.  I decided to pick it up on a weekend sale based on a friend telling me they enjoyed playing it.  All I can say is that I'm glad I did.  While I understand where a lot of the reviews are coming from, the story at the end goes batshit very quickly, especially with unexpected and uncharacteristic responses from the main character due to what's happening in the story.  Also the mechanic where you get punished more for partial success than for failure in that if an agent dies and you succeed, he stays dead.  But if he dies and you fail, you start up at the last checkpoint.

That being said, the combat is pretty awesome.  It feels like it's taking a page from Mass Effect 2/3 combat but also combining it with a bunch of X-COM: Enemy Unknown's tactics/aesthetics.  It's a pretty game, although my computer struggled with DX11 a little bit, so I ran standard.

I plan on playing it again on a more difficult setting.  On normal it was an alright challenge.  I managed to finish the game without losing any agents, though there were times that I'd fail encounters outright multiple times before completing them due to managing my team better.

SPOILER(ish)
The one thing I did and also very much did not like about the story, all at the same time is that very near the end they give a very good explanation for the 3rd person perspective and the slow down time mechanic of battle tactics.  If you played it, you'll definitely understand what I'm getting at.

I definitely recommend this game to fans of Mass Effect 2/3 combat.  For X-COM purists, I hear it's a tough pill to swallow regarding canon, so take it with a grain of salt perhaps?

reviewText:
The Bureau: XCOM Declassified was not well received by mainstream reviewers, but I personally enjoyed it a lot. Overall, it feels like a stripped down version of Mass Effect, but the combat stands out above other cover shooters. The game has a lot of flaws, but I encountered no bugs in the core game. The Hangar 6 DLC, however, would freeze briefly every few seconds and rendered the game nearly unplayable.

The Bureau's combat puts you in control of William Carter, a rather generic protagonist with a gravelly voice. Conversations in the game are carried out with a radial menu lifted directly from Mass Effect. The dialogue isn't terribly interesting, and some of the characters facial animations appeared to not actually be finished. Their mouths move with odd robotic motions, and their eyes look eerily dead. Carter himself, and some of the other core characters have much better, albeit repetitive animations. The story is forgettable overall, but moves the game on well enough. It doesn't come anywhere close to the likes of Mass Effect though, and the fact that the developers chose to base their game design so heavily on Mass Effect is unfortunate given the weak story. Even still, the combat made the experience worthwhile.

Combat in the Bureau is at it's core a cover shooter in the vein of Mass Effect or Gears of War. It also gives you a pair of squadmates and allows you to give direct orders to them. The rookies you start with only have one or two abilities, as well as a command to focus on a specific target, and move to a location. Choosing where to move your squadmates is where the game gets a lot of it's strategic depth. You have to take into account how long they'll be exposed for, how far the nearest ally is if they need a revive, where the enemies are, how much protection the cover offers, and how easily they can use their abilities from their location. Overall it makes for a far more interesting experience than your standard cover shooter. Abilities range from dropping mines, shield domes, artillery strikes, and others.

The combat isn't perfect though. Your squadmates seem to move into stupid locations occasionally, either exposing themselves to unnecessary fire, going down somewhere difficult to revive them, or both. It's not quite clear why this happens, but it doesn't happen very often at least. The encounters feel somewhat repetitive, but they ramp up in difficulty at a good rate. The weapons are fairly standard for a cover shooter; human and alien variations of the standard rifle, pistol, sniper and so on. Enemies on the other hand provide a bit more variety, healing their allies, granting them shields, spawning new enemies, or even mind controlling your squadmates.

The graphics generally look good, with a variety of scenes ranging from idyllic small towns to metallic alien structures. Some elements though stand out like a sore thumb. An ugly low res skybox in one of the first scenes of the game is jarringly bad to look at in stark contrast to the cutscene that precedes it. Other elements like a destroyed tank with an ugly texture and a low poly model, or the abyss below an alien tower filled with an ugly brown fog that would have been acceptable years ago, but looks disappointing today. The rest of the game, however, especially the weapon reload animations look and sound good.

The Bureau's worst offense however, is sure to be a dealbreaker for some fans of the mainstream XCOM games. The only thing The Bureau has in common with XCOM itself is the aliens and the weapon types. Unlocking new weapons is done merely by picking them up off the ground rather than researching them. Dying only puts you back to the latest checkpoint, and while you can lose squadmates permanently if they bleed out in some difficulty settings, I'm fairly sure if you die yourself they'll be back with you at the last checkpoint.

By removing research, permadeath, and forcing the player down a linear path, I'm sure some players will deem the game unworthy of the XCOM title. While these issues did grate on me at first, it was the combat that kept me playing and enjoying every minute of it. Even though the story is just average, it isn't particularly time consuming like it is in Mass Effect. While I feel the game could have played more to it's strengths, it was still well worth the time and money while on sale. I wouldn't hesitate to reccomend this game to fans of Mass Effect, though fans of the classic XCOM games or Enemy Unknown will not enjoy it unless they also enjoy a good cover shooter.

reviewText:
A Paladin’s Review: The Bureau: XCOM Declassified. It's Really Not That Bad, For What It IsGenre: 3rd Person Tactical Shooter
Developed & Published by: 2K Marin and 2K Games
Platform support: Windows, PS3 and Xbox 360
Business Model: Base Game
Copy purchased by myselfRead the full and unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]

Preamble
The Bureau has had a troubled history. It spent a long time in development hell, changing studios and the game’s design multiple times. Though its 1960s aesthetic was the only thing that stayed consistent during this process. It was originally titled “XCOM”, a first person shooter with some tactical play. It was originally intended to be the focal point of the series’ reboot. The reboot of a beloved turn-based strategy game with mechanics that had become legendary by this point and time. (Yeah, it doesn’t take a genius to see where 2K might have gone wrong). The response to “XCOM” was severe dislike, leading to the game to be pushed back into the shadows of the public eye. Instead, XCOM: Enemy Unknown was released by a different development team and became really successful. Potentially leading the series to a new and bright future. The FPS “XCOM” wasn’t anywhere to be seen and there was much rejoicing. A year later, The Bureau: XCOM Declassified stepped from the shadows. In all of it’s glorious 1962 aesthetic, 3rd person tactical squad based action. It largely got mixed or negative reception. So, the question becomes: did The Bureau justify that reception? Well, let’s find out.

Turn-Based Tactics Combat System
There’s no turn-based strategy here. There is a tactical commander’s view that let’s you order your squadmates where to go, when to use abilities and on which alien/enemy targets. A large chunk of your game time will be spent going from combat spot to combat spot. As a whole, the combat is simply ok and it works. It has its satisfying moments now and again but it’s not the most exciting. Especially if you’ve played games in this genre before. However, one thing that I did like were some of combos you could make with different classes. Though I felt like they barely scratched the surface with class synergy and I’d like to see more useful combos in the future. Oh, I didn’t mention this but there are four classes in the game. Commandos (your bruisers), Engineers (deploy turrets and mines), Recon (Snipers) and Supports (medics). Each class has their own distinctive abilities and weapons. The weapons are reasonably weighty with a good amount of impact and firepower to make them all enjoyable to use. The cover system is a bit sticky and unwieldy at times. Far too often, I’d find myself trapped in a spot with no good way out. Or my agents would often find themselves in similar situations.

Story and Characters
If there is one thing I can say about The Bureau, it’s a story of conveniences. Somehow I’m supposed to believe that an alien invasion of this size would be kept secret from the public. The only reason I can buy this is that it’s the 1960s and communication was severely hampered. That somehow, I’m supposed to believe that an alien we captured becomes our ally in a quick heartbeat. Somehow, I’m supposed to believe that we can capture alien weapons and items with the “Venn Brace”. Which I can only assume is a magical tool we carry on our arms. (Where did that Venn Brace come from again?). A lot of this is either swept under the rug or just goes by you so quickly I think they’re hoping you won’t notice because SHINY.

DLC Thoughts
I didn’t play the DLC and from what I can see, they don’t seem worth paying or plaything them. One is a gun pack, the other two are short uninspiring missions. I can’t help but feel like these were possibly cut from the final product to be sold as DLC. I didn't feel any particular compulsion to pick these up.

PC Settings & Optimization
The Bureau has a lot of graphical settings. There’s a reasonable amount of screen resolutions to choose from. Windowed mode, v-sync and film grain that can be turned off and on. It also supports up to 120FPS if you’re wanting that. Field-of-view is supported from 65-100 degrees. Any larger changes have to be made in a .ini file. PhysX is featured in the particles & clothing and can be disabled. You’ve got texture, world, shadow and effect detail sliders as well as anti-aliasing, anisotropic filtering, decal persistence, ambient occlusion and screen space reflection sliders. For the most part it’s a pretty decently optimized game. Though I did have several areas of combat situations where the framerate dropped pretty hard. A DX11 mode also exists that makes the game look somewhat better. However, it’s an incredibly costly mode for not a lot of gain which I couldn’t get it to run at a stable framerate.

Final Thoughts
It’s a good thing that 2K didn’t lead their reboot of the XCOM series with The Bureau: XCOM Declassified. Not to knock too harshly on the developers, but this would have killed the franchise dead. Now? I actually kinda want a sequel to this. A good sequel that stays with these developers, doesn’t get passed between multiple teams and doesn’t go through development hell. I think they have a good foundation started, but could use some more work to flesh everything out.

As for XCOM Declassified currently, well, it’s just not that bad. It’s got a pretty good story and a decent enough combat system. It does try to be XCOM though it does lack many of the features of XCOM. There’s no research, no base(s) management, you can only command two other squadmates, it’s got less customization and less of the XCOM experience than it should. But for a 1960s take on the XCOM universe from a different perspective, I still kinda like it. It’s got a story with some pretty unique twists and turns, a pretty diverse cast of characters and seventeen hours of enjoyment.

Read this review and others on A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]

reviewText:
I think it's an excellent, fun, accessible game and a great low-impact X-Com game to boot. It definitely takes the franchise in a different fork (more mission and story driven than strategy) but the strategic aspects aren't completely absent and at later levels if you have the difficulty up you actually need to control your agents and position them if you're going to survive.

This is coming from someone who played X-COM and Terror From the Deep on the Amiga back in the day and loved the hell out of them, and I can honestly say I've thoroughly enjoyed the game. It has an LA Noire sense to it, with intrigue and loads of sideplots and stuff you can do if you wander the base and talk to people. I didn't particularly care for any of the X-Coms after Terror From the Deep aside from the X-Com remake, so if you're like me and you like the first two X-Coms and don't necessarily need a heavy squad-management and base builder sim, give it a try.

My only lament is that any gear you want you must discover in missions, some of them completely optional. There is no 'research' beyond what the storyline demands, so the game loses some of the greatness of being able to research and retrofit the alien tech as you recover corpses and such. While it's something I missed in the game, the fact that once you salvage alien technology in the field X-Com can reproduce it for all of your agents is cool.

I'd like to see a sequel to this game made with some more rpg elements like more skill branching, more skill levels, and research and development. Everything else I found to be quite refreshing, especially the timeline which hearkens back to good old Cold War era paranoia, Area 51 and 'the end of innocence'.

reviewText:
A Paladin’s Review: The Bureau: XCOM Declassified. It's Really Not That Bad, For What It IsGenre: 3rd Person Tactical Shooter
Developed & Published by: 2K Marin and 2K Games
Platform support: Windows, PS3 and Xbox 360
Business Model: Base Game
Copy purchased by myselfRead the full and unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]

Preamble
The Bureau has had a troubled history. It spent a long time in development hell, changing studios and the game’s design multiple times. Though its 1960s aesthetic was the only thing that stayed consistent during this process. It was originally titled “XCOM”, a first person shooter with some tactical play. It was originally intended to be the focal point of the series’ reboot. The reboot of a beloved turn-based strategy game with mechanics that had become legendary by this point and time. (Yeah, it doesn’t take a genius to see where 2K might have gone wrong). The response to “XCOM” was severe dislike, leading to the game to be pushed back into the shadows of the public eye. Instead, XCOM: Enemy Unknown was released by a different development team and became really successful. Potentially leading the series to a new and bright future. The FPS “XCOM” wasn’t anywhere to be seen and there was much rejoicing. A year later, The Bureau: XCOM Declassified stepped from the shadows. In all of it’s glorious 1962 aesthetic, 3rd person tactical squad based action. It largely got mixed or negative reception. So, the question becomes: did The Bureau justify that reception? Well, let’s find out.

Turn-Based Tactics Combat System
There’s no turn-based strategy here. There is a tactical commander’s view that let’s you order your squadmates where to go, when to use abilities and on which alien/enemy targets. A large chunk of your game time will be spent going from combat spot to combat spot. As a whole, the combat is simply ok and it works. It has its satisfying moments now and again but it’s not the most exciting. Especially if you’ve played games in this genre before. However, one thing that I did like were some of combos you could make with different classes. Though I felt like they barely scratched the surface with class synergy and I’d like to see more useful combos in the future. Oh, I didn’t mention this but there are four classes in the game. Commandos (your bruisers), Engineers (deploy turrets and mines), Recon (Snipers) and Supports (medics). Each class has their own distinctive abilities and weapons. The weapons are reasonably weighty with a good amount of impact and firepower to make them all enjoyable to use. The cover system is a bit sticky and unwieldy at times. Far too often, I’d find myself trapped in a spot with no good way out. Or my agents would often find themselves in similar situations.

Story and Characters
If there is one thing I can say about The Bureau, it’s a story of conveniences. Somehow I’m supposed to believe that an alien invasion of this size would be kept secret from the public. The only reason I can buy this is that it’s the 1960s and communication was severely hampered. That somehow, I’m supposed to believe that an alien we captured becomes our ally in a quick heartbeat. Somehow, I’m supposed to believe that we can capture alien weapons and items with the “Venn Brace”. Which I can only assume is a magical tool we carry on our arms. (Where did that Venn Brace come from again?). A lot of this is either swept under the rug or just goes by you so quickly I think they’re hoping you won’t notice because SHINY.

DLC Thoughts
I didn’t play the DLC and from what I can see, they don’t seem worth paying or plaything them. One is a gun pack, the other two are short uninspiring missions. I can’t help but feel like these were possibly cut from the final product to be sold as DLC. I didn't feel any particular compulsion to pick these up.

PC Settings & Optimization
The Bureau has a lot of graphical settings. There’s a reasonable amount of screen resolutions to choose from. Windowed mode, v-sync and film grain that can be turned off and on. It also supports up to 120FPS if you’re wanting that. Field-of-view is supported from 65-100 degrees. Any larger changes have to be made in a .ini file. PhysX is featured in the particles & clothing and can be disabled. You’ve got texture, world, shadow and effect detail sliders as well as anti-aliasing, anisotropic filtering, decal persistence, ambient occlusion and screen space reflection sliders. For the most part it’s a pretty decently optimized game. Though I did have several areas of combat situations where the framerate dropped pretty hard. A DX11 mode also exists that makes the game look somewhat better. However, it’s an incredibly costly mode for not a lot of gain which I couldn’t get it to run at a stable framerate.

Final Thoughts
It’s a good thing that 2K didn’t lead their reboot of the XCOM series with The Bureau: XCOM Declassified. Not to knock too harshly on the developers, but this would have killed the franchise dead. Now? I actually kinda want a sequel to this. A good sequel that stays with these developers, doesn’t get passed between multiple teams and doesn’t go through development hell. I think they have a good foundation started, but could use some more work to flesh everything out.

As for XCOM Declassified currently, well, it’s just not that bad. It’s got a pretty good story and a decent enough combat system. It does try to be XCOM though it does lack many of the features of XCOM. There’s no research, no base(s) management, you can only command two other squadmates, it’s got less customization and less of the XCOM experience than it should. But for a 1960s take on the XCOM universe from a different perspective, I still kinda like it. It’s got a story with some pretty unique twists and turns, a pretty diverse cast of characters and seventeen hours of enjoyment.

Read this review and others on A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]

reviewText:
The Bureau is a very different take on the XCOM universe... it was set in 1960's, height of cold war, when a jamming wave blanketed the nation, and aliens invaded Earth. With comm blackout, information is slow to trickle in, but it appears the nation's military had been crippled, and only XCOM, a command setup to take control in case of full war, is mankind's last hope.

At its heart Bureau is a tactical shooter where you control two other agents to deploy where you want them as well as deploy their special abilities, such as sniper hit, deploy turret, and so on. As the senior agent, you have abilities too, and you'll get more as time go on.

Graphics are quite good and the desolation in the middle of 1960's America is quite evocative. Agents were wearing suits and appropriate hairstyles, esp. the ladies.

There is also quite a bit of dialog, with choices you have to make (and they will affect the outcome, at least a little) a bit like Mass Effect series. Talk to other people in the base, for additional clues, expositions, notes, and whatnot that tells you more about the people you meet. Characterization is quite nice.

Managing the agents during a sort of Matrix-like super-slo-mo" mode known as "Battle Focus" is the key here
date: where you place the agents at vantage points so they can engage the enemy effectively is key. Flanking is often the best way
recommended: as are using the environment such as explosive barrels (yes
hoursPlayed: that too).  As agents gain "rank" they also gain special abilities they can deploy. The key is to deploy them at the right place at the right time

reviewText:
I think it's an excellent, fun, accessible game and a great low-impact X-Com game to boot. It definitely takes the franchise in a different fork (more mission and story driven than strategy) but the strategic aspects aren't completely absent and at later levels if you have the difficulty up you actually need to control your agents and position them if you're going to survive.

This is coming from someone who played X-COM and Terror From the Deep on the Amiga back in the day and loved the hell out of them, and I can honestly say I've thoroughly enjoyed the game. It has an LA Noire sense to it, with intrigue and loads of sideplots and stuff you can do if you wander the base and talk to people. I didn't particularly care for any of the X-Coms after Terror From the Deep aside from the X-Com remake, so if you're like me and you like the first two X-Coms and don't necessarily need a heavy squad-management and base builder sim, give it a try.

My only lament is that any gear you want you must discover in missions, some of them completely optional. There is no 'research' beyond what the storyline demands, so the game loses some of the greatness of being able to research and retrofit the alien tech as you recover corpses and such. While it's something I missed in the game, the fact that once you salvage alien technology in the field X-Com can reproduce it for all of your agents is cool.

I'd like to see a sequel to this game made with some more rpg elements like more skill branching, more skill levels, and research and development. Everything else I found to be quite refreshing, especially the timeline which hearkens back to good old Cold War era paranoia, Area 51 and 'the end of innocence'.

reviewText:
This is a game that (we) X-Com fans wanted to love, but just couldn't. But I believe it has enough to be liked.

The first thing that the game has going for it is the noir theme, such an amazing atmosphere, and good voice acting (although the face animations are not up to par with the dialogues). The setting, 1963 IIRC, is spectacularly used to breathe fresh air to the game. There are a lot of little details that really help to build the X-Com world. Also, those are the key elements that save The Bureau from being just a complete rip-off of the first Mass Effect.

The whole squad tactical FPS combat is not as bad (some combo between abilities are actually really fun and easy to pull off) as long as you don't mind micromanaging (pausing all the time to give instructions to your teammates). Even so, your teammates will do stupid things, like ignore cover orders and never use their abilities. It's not terrible, but it is frustrating. In fact, you can argue that by the end those AI mistakes are the real difficult level, since by the end of the game you become really powerful and destroy your enemies by using just a little bit of tactical awareness.

In general, the plot is well handled, the atmosphere is amazing and everything else is Mass Effect 1 with some minor changes. I loved ME 1. This game? I liked it just ok.

If you ignore expectations built up from playing other 3PS games (it is not pure 3PS, rather it is sort of halfway between the turn-based isometric XCOM games and a tactical command 3PS), and suspend your disbelief, allowing yourself to get immersed into this great backstory to the XCOM storyline, it's actually fairly enjoyable.  At the risk of comparing the two games (beause TB:XD is in a totally different league to X:E), I see the poor reaction to The Bureau: XCOM Declassified" as somewhat similar to that of "XCOM: Enforcer

reviewText:
I knew The Bureau had some poor reviews, but the Xcom reboot was one of my favourite games of 2012, so I decided to take a chance. I wasn't expecting a great game, but I hoped the Xcom theme could provide some entertainment. I regret my decision.

There are some moments when The Bureau feels like it has the potential to be a good game. There are a wide range of classes and abilities to choose for your squad members, which lays the groundwork for deep tactical combat. You have some freedom to choose which order to play side missions. Most of the familiar Xcom aliens appear, and the campaign lasts an impressive 15 hours.

However, all this is completely undermined by some of the worst friendly AI I've seen for a long time, which prevents the combat from being enjoyable. In theory, you can slow down combat at any time and give orders to your two squadmates. In practice, they don't care about your orders. They will run away from cover at random times, leaving themselves vulnerable to attack, frequently resulting in them getting incapacitated. The player then has to quickly revive them before they bleed out and die permanently, which of course means you take massive damage trying to save them. The poorly placed checkpoint only save system didn't help my frustration.

Even when they are alive, your squadmates rarely do anything useful. I refer to my screenshot where on one mission I got 95 of 104 kills. Every mission had a similar theme. I only started to feel comfortable when I'd got some squadmates up to level 4 (max level is 5), and gained powerful abilities like the laser turret and the hologram decoy. Plus every level up increases health, so the AI would stay alive a bit longer. But that is a case of too little, too late.

I might recommend a game with poor gameplay if the story was entertaining, but the Bureau fails this too. Its a prequel set in the 1960's, but the continuity doesn't even make sense. During the course of the game you'll gain access to laser and plasma weapons, flying drones and psionic abilities. Meanwhile you'll encounter Sectoids, Mutons, Sectopods and Ethereals. But when the present day Xcom strategy game starts we don't have information about any of those things, and this is never justified.

Furthermore, the dialogue is poor. Sentences feel like disconnected lines, instead of flowing like a natural conversation, more a fault of the script writers than the voice actors. Lip syncing during in-engine cutscenes is awful and distracting.

My advice would be to skip The Bureau and just replay the other Xcom game(s) again.

reviewText:
The Bureau is an uninspired, and standardised third-person shooter in the vein of Gears of War, with little hints of the 'tactical' play of Mass Effect thrown in for flavour. Set in a parallel 1950s america, with many levels seeming to take place in the stereotypical midwest small towns popularised in so many UFO abduction stories, the player takes the role of a Secret Service agent tasked with delivering a mysterious artefact to the head of 'The Bureau', an unknown and oft-ridiculed section of the US government.

Attempting to provide history for the X-COM project as present in the firaxis game, The Bureau toys with themes of sexism in organisations, loyalty, and the importance of self...all with the ham-fisted bashing on a keyboard one would expect of most popular shooters. It takes itself and it's cheesy encironment with far too much seriousness and not enough self-awareness to really make the slightly B-movie plotline work.

I was actually impressed with the announce trailers for the original 'XCOM' first person shooter, and thought that while not an 'X-COM' game, it could have been an entertaining and uniue exploration of clandestine UFO investigation from the point of view of a squaddie or corporal. The numerous rewrites and alterations of the project's lifespan, and the apparent dusting under the rug after the success of Firaxis' 'XCOM; Enemy Unknown' have hurt this title.

If the pre-order bonuses were still available, I would suggest buying this game only for the X-Com complete pack as a pre-order bonus. Unfortunately, without that particular enticement, I can only suggest to avoid this game unless you feel an unhealthy urge to open plot holes and experience painfully obvious twists in storytelling.

reviewText: ♥♥♥♥ Tracy meets the best of the X-Com franchise and fails miserably.  The environment they create is excellent until the characters speak.  Dialog tends to run on about less than important information.  Base management is virtually non-existant and the gameplay itself in tactical mode is mostly redundant and boring.  This game fails to create strategic value or tactical tension that is the hallmark of the X-Com series.  This is indie developer quality at best and worse, indie games tend to be more fun! Nothing about this game is great other than the environment and I would argue the gameplay actually takes away from that heavily.  The other thing is the game runs heavy on even high end systems for no discernable reason.  It is likely that the time to properly optimize this game was never made.  The best correlation to system demand is X-Rebirth which is simulating an entire universe of things happening per frame.  How The Bureau requires and equal amount of processing power is beyond me.  The AI isn't good at all.  Bypass this title entirely.  Even on sale for 10$ it isn't worth it.  Buy some DLC for XCom: Enemy Unknown or Within and have hours of entertainment.  Even the original release of Sword of the Stars II didn't have me wishing for a return policy with STEAM so badly.\n\nMy Score: 3/10

reviewText:
A cover-based shooter trying to blend itself with the tactical features of its strategy forefathers. Despite its messy development history it's now a decent game for a decent price. As long as you remember that The Bureau is an action spinoff you will have your fun.

Pros
* Managing your agents is cool and their capacities will make a difference considering you are not given enough ammo to work alone
* The story lay down the foundations for the modern XCOM organization with a nice '60s twist
* The underground base is quite alive (as long as you visit it once per main mission) with plenty of dialogs and little animations

Cons
* The gameplay is not varied and you will often yawn at seeing predictable chest-high walls and meeting the same enemies just with more and more health points
* The IA of your teammates is pretty bad and will require you to micromanage them, but is overall tolerable if you stick to the Squaddie difficulty
* The RPG elements are light with the game itself being rather linear

Some polish would have been a welcome improvement but you can still see in the details that much love was poured into the game. It is also pretty easy to get most, if not all of the achievements!

reviewText:
The negative reviews for this game are mainly exaggerated and dumb. Many journalists and fans discredited the game BEFORE IT WAS EVEN RELEASED with the great argument:' A third-person-shooter for the XCOM-Franchise can't.' If most people hadn't be so prejudiced with this game, it would have gotten way better ratings.

I admit the graphics of the game aren't good.
I admit the story is kiiiind of weak and lacks pace and thrill.
I admit the gameplay is a bit to easy for XCOM-Fanboys and Fangirls.


BUT: It's still a nice game. The story is still okay, the gameplay is nice and easy to learn. THE GRAPHICS AREN'T SUCH A DISASTER. You can still have fun with this game, the atmosphere is nice and the 60s feeling is nice and a cool setting and variation. Especially the background in some levels look just hilarious.
I have to mention that the atmosphere in the first introductionary level is F***ING INTENSE. The Cold War provides an awesome setting, but I'd would have liked a cooler soundtrack, with more epic or Rock n Roll songs in it.
Another positive aspect of this game are the little investigations in the base of XCOM. They are little, easy and short missions, but they unlock sidemissions in the 'outside world', which is an awesome idea.

So: If you don't want to pay 20€, wait until a sale. This game is really okay.

reviewText: I went into this game expecting to hate it. I really wanted to hate it because of the name it carried and the fact it had departed so much from what the core of the series was actually about. But I just couldn't. It reminded me of all of those B-list sci-fi shows that were on television in re-run when I was younger and I'm a sucker for that era of science fiction. My one complaint as I began to play the game was laughably that I felt that they had a better design for the aliens before they tried to incorperate elements of the usual X-com lineup into the game. Back when they were stark and strange and unknowable. Shapes and blobs and infiltrations. Dark noises in the middle of the night and having to fight things you'd never hope to understand. That -- is what I wish this game would've kept more of.  That said? I enjoyed it. Friendly AI is . . . frustratingly bad, but it never really impeded my progress any. Voice acting was pretty good. Story was fantastic, with the one complaint I mentioned above.\n\nBuy it on a sale. It's seriously not a bad game, for what it is.

reviewText:
It's like Mass Effect except with awful writing, voice acting and AI, plus a distinct lack of choices and any incentive to stray from the narrow linear path.

Here is an example of how broken it is. When a team member goes down, they can be revived by a colleague. During this process, the healer is completely immune from damage. They can be getting blasted and smashed by all manner of enemies, but won't be hurt. Of course, once they have finished reviving their colleague, they can be promptly killed - and now the former patient can become invulnerable healer. It's utter nonsense and terrible design.

As for having the same button to run, take cover and leap over said cover - well, it just screams console port.

Oddly enough, the game improves quite a bit in the late stages. The story finally starts to get a bit interesting, if uninspired, and gameplay actually becomes quite frenetic and challenging. It requires battling through mediocrity to get there, though.

reviewText:
This game is a bit of a black sheep amongst the XCOM family. It bears the name, deals with alien invasions and you;re part of a top secret government agency tasked with fighting them... but that's about as far as the similarities go.

The Bureau is a 3rd person squad-based cover shooter, and that's what turns a lot of people off to it. XCOM traditionally is a turn-based isometric game. Does it not being like the previous XCOMs make it a bad game? No, not really. That's not to say it's great, but it's not bad either.

The Bureau has its faults; The squad controls are clunky on both KB/m and controller, the UI looks like it was designed only for consoles in a lot of places, your squad mates will sometimes switch cover when they shouldn't... the list goes on, and much of it is just minor things.

As I said, the game isn't the greatest, but it's good enough at what it does to get a passing mark.

reviewText: I recommend this game at a good price (less than $10). It was a bit shorter than I expected but still fun. There are many missions you can select from back at HQ but each mission is very linear with one route to follow. When you meet up with the aliens then it opens into an arena type area to move around.  Having to run around inside HQ to meet up with different folks was was much more irritating that just selecting the part of the base you wanted to visit. I also found myself skipping a lot of the dialog as it went on for too long but at least you have the option to do that. Overall I'd give it a 6 out 10 rating. Nothing special, very little re-playability, but I enjoyed it enough my first play through to feel I did not waste my $10.

reviewText:
If you liked Mass Effect style of play with an XCOM theme and many of its own play styles, you will really enjoy this game immensely!

Not sure why all the negative reviews, if they were expecting XCOM set in the 50's, they must have misunderstood the game description. Although the game IS XCOM set in the 50's, it uses its own unique style of play. It really is a very well made game, a few things bother me but not enough to kill the game for me, on the contrary, its been a lot of fun and I just love that the game is in the XCOM universe. The design style is really impressive, they did a great job capturing the feel of the times, very impressed.

Its too bad its sales seemed flat, the creators of this game really deserved a hit for what they delivered. A fun, well designed game that uses Mass Effect style play as its combat foundation along with many of XCOMS weapons, skills and overall charm.

Its definately worth getting. If you're just looking for another XCOM game, this is not it, its much more.

reviewText:
Contrary to most other reviews, I think this game is amazing. I agree that it shouldn't have the XCOM name, as it is far from the strategical gameplay of Enemy Unknown, but it really is a good TPS. It's probably not worth the current $30, but I got Enemy Unknown and this for $8 during the summer sale and it is definitely worth that.
PROS
- Great gameplay
- In my opinion, a great team control system
- Decent storyline
- How it has some of the same aliens as other XCOM games

CONS
- Short campaign, could have been made longer and better
- Strange conversation system
- How you cannot go back to this base after finishing the game (to do side missions)

VERDICT

If it goes on sale for under $15, I would say get it.
8/10.

reviewText:
There's a special place in hell for people who manage to take a limitlessly interesting IP and turn it into an incredibly mediocre experience: that's what The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is - mediocre. It's boring, not bad; uninteresting, not unplayable; dull, not unpolished.

Considering that everyone would have been very happy with a 1950-60's reskin of Enemy Unknown, it's mind boggling why they would instead try to make a 2-weapon cover-shooter with boss battles and Gruff White Male Tough Guy protagonist.

I bought this game for 5 bucks on sale. I got my time's worth out of it, sure, but I feel bad for having financially supported the creators of this.

reviewText: This is a squad-based action game similar to Mass Effect so if you expect it to be just like XCOM: Enemy Unknown you may be disappointed, it is not turn-based tactics on a grid. That said, it is a good game in its own right and focuses much more heavily on the story and character development than its tactics counterpart. There are still different classes and a leveling system of sorts in which you can choose bonuses or upgrades similar to the leveling in Enemy Unknown. The story reveals a lot more about the background of XCOM but don't expect all your questions to be answered either.\n\nHangar 6 R&D - Definitely worth the cost, you get several extra missions to play as DaSilva and take on some more aliens. If you completed the main story and are looking for some more of the same then I recommend this. Don't expect a lot of new content or anything though, it's the same weapons and aliens. The only really new things are the missions and story, and DaSilva's perks are kind of a mix but mostly familiar. This campaign runs entirely separate from the regular campaign (you start a whole new file) so it won't interfere or matter where you are in the regular story.

reviewText: Excellent story telling from the XCOM-verse as usual, not only is the change in gear from turn based strategy to third person shooter refreshing, its also gripping. Even my daughter is intrigued and wants to know how Carter (the protagonist) will deal with the next alien threat. I got this as a Christmas present so from an unbiased (no pennies spent) point of view this gets a thumbs up! I have played some 15+ hours already and honestly, I'm finding it hard to put this down. I just hope that the developers look at this style of gameplay and apply it to their other titles. I'd love to see the modern XCOM series take on the third person shooter styling.

reviewText:
Animations: 5/10
Graphics: 8.5/10
Storyline: 10/10
Gameplay: 9/10

Overall: 8.1/10

In this game you play as Ex Agent Carter during the year 1962, in the starting wake of an alien invasion which leads to the formation of an organization known as the Bureau.

For being in production since late 2006 i belive this game could have been a bit better asthetically and functionally than it is.

The A.I. used for the NPC Teammates is rather scetchy at best as you find yourself having to babysit them 99% of the battle, on the plus side they do come with various abilities and classes as well as weapons which if used properly can easily beat enemy encounters.

Graphically this game is above top notch. being released during the end of last gen and including the Nvidia PhysX particle effects it really reaches the bar set by others. though it does take a pretty decent PC to run everything maxed out with DX11.

Animations during in game scenes (and some out game scenes) could have been brushed up on. Characters seem too chopy at some points, and too stiff at others. Aside from this if animations don't really bug you too much the dialog and V.O.s were done rather nicely and do set some justice to in game cinimatics.

Gameplay is rather tricky to get the hang of if you aren't into Tactical TPS games. you controll your two NPCs as well as yourself and must utilize all the teams abilities and each classes strengths and weaknesses to guide them to victory. that being said by themselfs the NPC's are rather useless as stated earlier. but given you can practically controll their every move it makes for interesting game. Another mechanic that's rather interesting is agents, you must keep a roster" stocked of agents all starting at level 1 and choose weather to rotate them
date: send some on npc only missions
recommended: or pick favorites and take only them at all times
hoursPlayed: as a tactics based game though you are also given multiple classes to used based on the missions and can even swap them out mid mission as needed. adding to the system is deaths
voteText: a consiquence to not coordinating your agents and keeping them alive is once an agent is down
helpfulPercent: he is gone. reguardless of level and abilities thus leaving you only to choose another agent to take his place.\n\nStoryline to this game is rather immersive. you can find info on NPC's and current situations laying around
votesHelpful: and get side missions. The main missions all of course tie in as any storyline based game should. but getting into it is rather touch and go. they start by throwing you right into the start of the invasion and piece the events before it as you go along. but after getting past the beginning it smoothens out as you play through the rest.\n\nOverall though I belive this installment to the XCOM series was done rather nicely. given the time they had i belive it could have been slightly better but as it stands is a pretty strong release and in personal opinion a great game to play. I would deffinately recommend giving this game a shot if you're into Tactical TPS'."

reviewText:
Was really suprised that this game was good! I actually enjoyed it a hell of a lot.

My first experience with the XCOM franchise was the 2012 game, which I also enjoyed a whole lot. I would say that The Bureau is a fairly accurate translation of XCOM into a 3rd person shooter. You can give commands on the field, cover is very much essential as is position on the battle field. Even the way missions are seperated into side missions and main story missions, giving the game a similar pace to XCOM (shorter missions taking anywhere from 10 minutes to 30 minutes, and the longer ones up to over an hour). Of course in depth this game differs from XCOM in that you will not be maintaining the base yourself, doing research, your boss does that. You simply go out and shoot dudes and command the field and ♥♥♥♥.

The games weaknesses mostly revolve around the plot in my opinion. It's suprisingly good in parts, but does get ridiculous at times. It crosses the suspension of disbelief line a few to manty times.

But the game has a lot of strengths that I don't think it was given enough credit for. The shooting feels great, the weapons are really cool, and the field commands just make you feel powerful and responsible for your squad. The setting is also fantastic, a really slick Mad Men" vibe.

So give this game a chance. It is the XCOM experience for people who might not be into hardcore strategy games
date: and that's ok. Get it on sale!\n\nAlso: It works on Nvidia Shield"

reviewText:
This game is a bit of a black sheep amongst the XCOM family. It bears the name, deals with alien invasions and you;re part of a top secret government agency tasked with fighting them... but that's about as far as the similarities go.

The Bureau is a 3rd person squad-based cover shooter, and that's what turns a lot of people off to it. XCOM traditionally is a turn-based isometric game. Does it not being like the previous XCOMs make it a bad game? No, not really. That's not to say it's great, but it's not bad either.

The Bureau has its faults; The squad controls are clunky on both KB/m and controller, the UI looks like it was designed only for consoles in a lot of places, your squad mates will sometimes switch cover when they shouldn't... the list goes on, and much of it is just minor things.

As I said, the game isn't the greatest, but it's good enough at what it does to get a passing mark.

reviewText:
If you liked Mass Effect style of play with an XCOM theme and many of its own play styles, you will really enjoy this game immensely!

Not sure why all the negative reviews, if they were expecting XCOM set in the 50's, they must have misunderstood the game description. Although the game IS XCOM set in the 50's, it uses its own unique style of play. It really is a very well made game, a few things bother me but not enough to kill the game for me, on the contrary, its been a lot of fun and I just love that the game is in the XCOM universe. The design style is really impressive, they did a great job capturing the feel of the times, very impressed.

Its too bad its sales seemed flat, the creators of this game really deserved a hit for what they delivered. A fun, well designed game that uses Mass Effect style play as its combat foundation along with many of XCOMS weapons, skills and overall charm.

Its definately worth getting. If you're just looking for another XCOM game, this is not it, its much more.

reviewText:
Other critics called-out the The Bureau’s plot-holes and how similar it plays to Mass Effect. But Mass Effect’s pause “tactics” never gets very tactical. And honestly, when was the last time a videogame’s story didn’t have plot holes? Who cares about the cost of tea on the Normandy. We’ve got, slow-mo running gunning survival tactics with sci-fi powers in The Bureau: XCOM Declassified.

Overcoming horrible odds with careful tactics makes us very happy.

Best slow-mo action tactics I've played.

reviewText: Incredibly under-rated game. Sure it's not the best game ever made in the 3rd person shooter genre but it's obvious that a lot of time and effort went into making this game authentic looking to fit the 1950's style retro sci-fi theme.  It's got a nice easy to use command system and the battles are satisfying. The visuals are the games best asset and for that alone it warrants the games purchase. I bought it at full price when it first came out and have played through it twice. No regrets for paying full price either! The insane sales this game has seen would be FOOLISH to pass up. The only thing I really wish it had was multiplayer specifically co-op... Co-op would've been an awesome addition to this already fun game. Well the game tanked and we'll never see another which is too bad so I highly recommend you give this one a shot, you really can't go wroing with the price. I'd give it a 7.5 out of 10.

reviewText:
There's a lot of promise here but unfortuanately The Bureau fails to excel in any area and trips over itself into mediocrity.

The Good
+Maintaining and leveling up squad agents is fun and adds stakes to making sure everyone comes back from a mission alive.
+Lots of different abilities to change how encounters can play.
+The story was fairly interesting and had some fun turns.

The Disappointing
-Terrible Squad AI; frequent pathing issues and breaking cover during firefights.
-The Bureau makes very poor use of its setting and fails to make anything feel like it's taking place in the 50's.

reviewText:
Bought it for $4 - not even worth that. 4/10

Really, I think the best way to describe it is that the game is  Mass Effect 2, but with mediocre combat that is a boring slog from the first sequence, a completely uninteresting story, characters with no personality, no exploration, and the base does little to breathe life into the game - basically nothing to actually made Mass Effect 2 good. Every now and then, the game threatens to pique your curiousity with its story, but that generally gets dropped quite quickly, lost among the extremely padded gameplay.

There's only really three positive things I think I can say about the game. The first, not many of the OBLIGATORY OBLIGATORY OBLIGATORY action sequences that we've all played in a dozen different games, and really the worst are wave-survival segments and boss segments. The game, aside from the boring third-person shooting and waist-high wall clinging, generally does its own thing. Additionally, at first, the game seems to have drawn a lot of inspiration from Cold War thriller novels and films, and create an identity for it. The third is that the game seems to tie into XCOM: Enemy Unknown much more than it needed to, although much of this is shallow. Unfortunately, the game uses neither of these positives very much, and contributes very little to the experience.

I must mention the major bugs and technical problems I also experienced. Sometimes, when you go through doorways, the floor hasn't spawned yet, and you fall under the map. Yes, THE FLOOR DOESN'T SPAWN, and it happened during every mission I played after the first one, and quite frequently at the base. Similarly, issues like doors not opening when they're scripted to (because heaven forbid they trust the player to open a door), or entire combat sequences being skipped over because the enemies don't even spawn. The game is fortunate to have a good checkpoint system, because you're going to be doing it often for how often these bugs occur. As for other technical issues, the game runs really quite poorly, embarrassingly so, with the framerate often tanking to below 10 FPS, whereas my system can run games that are significantly better looking without experiencing the same issues. Audio cuts out occassionally, especially during cutscenes. Many of the key commands have inconsistent responsiveness.

Just don't even bother playing this game. Its not even a game that is spectacularly bad that you can get entertainment from it that way. Its just a woefully boring, padded slog of mediocre third-person shooting that every now and then a more interesting game comes to the surface for about a minute and then disappears for another hour. The only reason anybody remembers that the game exists is because XCOM" was attached to the title. This is 12 GB of memory that can be put to better use elsewhere."

reviewText:
Another disaster of a game. I honestly can't believe people pay 50 or 60$ for titles like this. And this game is yet another example of why buying a new game is a bad idea these days. They are usually disappointing at best and garbage at worst. Then <6 months later they'll be -50% off anyway. This one has been out no more than 1 year and it's 1$ on a Humble Bundle right now, which is exactly how I got my copy. I'll admit that I didn't even want this, I wanted Darkness 2, but I thought I'd give this a fair shot since the developers downright handed me this game. So I started playing it. At first I thought this game was merely mediocre, but after playing it for a good hour and a half, I realized in just how many ways this game isn't something I should have ever bothered with. I should have just given the key away to some stupid kid on the forum that'll desperately play anything he can get his hands on. This is a game people will no doubt fight over like starving hungry bums on Steamgifts now while the rest of us sip our tea and play better games.(Or my case, waste time reviewing it)

But I was actually surprised about a few things with this title. Shockingly enough, the camera for third person is actually in the middle of the screen. Despite getting almost everything else wrong(including right stick invert turned off by default), they got this correct. So why can't everyone else? You can actually use cover and see around it very well, because the damn camera is where it's supposed to be. Also I was shocked to actually see partners THAT CAN DIE. Ya. Wow. And they do damage to enemies. Why is that other games can't do these very simple things? All of these are things I complain about in other reviews. I also liked the fact that you wear a fedora hat in the game. It takes place during the 60s, when people actually wore suits and decent hats. Since I'm the only Human on Earth that wears one of these in this age of silly baseball caps, I find it amusing to see these kinds of things. I love historic eras, it's as close as you'll ever get to time traveling. Now if only I could get myself a nice round car...

But that's where the list of things the game had going for it ends. There's plenty of glitches or bugs to find. Animation is weak, characters are stiff, voice acting doesn't do the game any favors(Carter sounds like Batman for some reason), and I can't say the story is anything special. Environments are acceptable, but that's it, nothing special, especially when they are extremely linear. You only ever have 1 tight path to take through a level, with every other route clearly blocked, which I always find boring. They then glow things like doors, as if you could ever get lost in a game where there is only ONE possible path forward. I feel like a rat being herded through a table maze that only has one path to the end.

The main reason to do this(linear game) is to make the game very immersive or have a lot of scripted events... but the game doesn't have much of either. Not much happens other than you running into another pack of aliens. Speaking of lack of immersion, there isn't much to be had when characters are expendable card board cut outs that will regularly die and be replaced. Rather than focus on a cast of selectable crew that could have had unique personalities, dialogue, or stories... they opted for the route of having every squad member being nearly identical except in class and gun. So the immersion of being with a squad just isn't there. You can actually edit their name and face too, which buries immersion as much as possible, I'd say. So they aren't people, they're just units. It would have made a lot more sense to have real crew, rather than units, with them unable to permanently die as to prevent you from running out. Or maybe they get injured if they die in a mission then you have to wait for them to heal? Enemy Unknown has the same problem with units and counterproductive excessive customization, but that's an RTS, where you play an imaginary commander from overhead, not an actual character in the game. I found it more acceptable in that game to be able to make your dream team. But this is not the same kind of game, and you can only run with 2 partners, so I question why they copy what was already a detriment to a previous game into their newer one where it makes even less sense.

What really kills this game though is the partner system. In my mere 1 1/2 hours of gametime, I've seen them do some of the most stupid things I could imagine. They dive into enemy formations for no apparent reason(then die), refuse to use any special abilities without being directly told(uh, why?), and most notebly, stand around being shot rather than adapt or move. They are VERY stupid, not acting at all like the trained or experienced soldiers they are supposed to be. They tend to deliberately die in the worst possible areas, as if to make you fail because trying to revive them there is suicide.

Having good partner A.I. for a squad combat system really could have sold this game... but it's not here, so the exact opposite is what we got. Aliens have the same problems, but they are expendable units of limited intellect not even their owners care about, not people with intellect, like your partners. In other words, for enemy monsters, zerglings, robots, or whatever, dummy A.I. doesn't really matter. They're expendable, they come off an assembly line with numbers, no one cares if they die or not. They win purely by outnumbering you, and their owners will simply keep sending more until you lose. But with actual Human soldiers, you expect some kind of brain cells or independant thought, which you don't get with the partners you are burdened with in this game. They expect to just go willy nilly like a complet tart in battle, to hell with the consequences, then when they die, it's your problem. They are nothing but a frustrating chore to have, almost making you wish you could just Bioshock 2 this game as a Big Daddy and run it solo. I still stand by the fact that partners SHOULD be able to die, but don't get me wrong, that doesn't mean they can then get by with garbage A.I. - Partners in Gears of War from 2006 were better than this. Just thought I'd mention that, 2013 game.

I do not recommend this game. If you really want it, go get it for 1$ off the Humble Bundle or some other really cheap sale. This really is a lazy sloppy title no one cared about, abysmal, basically shovelwared onto the market. Enemy Unknown is at 20$ tier on Humble Bundle, while this NEWER game is at the 1$ tier, not even a year after its release. What does that tell you? I don't personally know how well this game released, but seeing it now, I assume it got panned pretty hard and is now in a lot of trash cans. It is now going to mine as I am uninstalling after posting this review. I seriously doubt I will touch this again anytime soon.

reviewText:
An excellent third person tactical shooter where there's a lot of emphasis on giving the right orders at the right time to your agents.
You play as William Carter who at the start of the game is delivering a very important briefcase to the director of the Bureau of Operations and Command, Myron Faulke, at Groom Range when he is suddenly attacked in the room he was given while waiting to go inside the facility by a female officer who starts discharging a strange black substance from her eyes before she turns her attention to the briefcase that then explodes in a blinding white light that completely and utterly incinerates the infected female officer and knocks Carter out, who later wakes up with the gun wound he sustained inexplicably healed.
But that is only the start of Carter's problems as an unknown enemy force has attacked the facility and now he must try and get to Faulke and find out just what is going on.
This game doesn't go easy on you, even on the easiest setting, as the enemies are extremely relentless and cunning as they will attempt to flank you, toss grenades to flush you out of cover and many other tactics to eliminate you.
You can also send your agents out on dispatch missions that can give you access to new technology, a new recruit and other things that can turn the tide of this secret war in your favor.
There's also several documents and photos scattered about the base and mission areas that can provide a bit more backstory aside from talking to the agents and personal.
The Bureau borrows a lot of elements from the Mass Effect games, especially when it comes to how you give orders to the agents, the various powers that you will unlock and many others, but I feel like its done a bit better here then in the Mass Effect games, especially considering the setting of the game itself.
This is without a doubt one of the most interesting and fun tactical shooters for quite sometime to be released on home computers and consoles alike and I highly recommend it, especially to those who are fans of the XCOM series.

reviewText:
First off: It's not a bad game. It's solid for what it does - mostly being a Cover Shooter.
But it feels lackluster in every regard.

The main discipline, the actual tactical shooting doesn't feel very tactical unless late in the game. The AI is unreliable at best, the options are limited to targeting a specific enemy, moving to a position and a very limited set of active abilities which almost all offer some kind of damage output increase instead of supporting utility. The enemies feel very bullet spongy even on lower difficulties and only pose a challenge through their masses combined with the team-AI running into open field, especially in the second half of the game.
Customizationwise the game doesn't offer much. A handful of weapons in the archetypes of assault rifle, shotgun, sniper rifle, sidearm and heavy arms divided into three ammunition types. Bullets against unarmored, Laser against shields and plasma with a damage over time effect, though the difference doesn't matter much in the field and your basically limited to whatever you find during the missions anyway. The skill trees offer some choices which again don't account for much, just as the backpacks. It all feels like more was planned but eventually cut.
All of this makes the game play like a generic cover shooter for a long time.

The level design offers some pretty nice scenary and fantastic atmosphere at times but with large gaps filled with generic corridors and obstacles (and some invisible walls) conviniently placed to only allow a narrow path. Whenever you see a wider area, be assured to have enemies incoming. Since the linear design doesn't allow much exploration, it is surprising that the paths branching left and right of the main path are often pointless and empty or give a new backpack schematic at best - which you can mostly also get from the dispatch side missions.

The story is based on the older (50s - 60s) SciFi movies with slight horror mixed in between. Think of 'Invasion of the Body Snatchers' or similar - or Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons which has basically the same premise ;)
Again it feels cut on every end. There are some illogical jumps in character behaviour, descissions which don't matter at all, dialogue which repeats itself or is even nonsensical and the campaign feels very rushed with various Dei ex machina. The writing also does a very good job of making the main character as unlikeable as humanly possibile, throwing out oneliners like Duke Nukem which drip from pathos and stupidity.
The whole XCOM feeling from the classic games or the remake is barely there apart from the alien names - you're only fighting on US American soil, with US Americans and have no contact to or intel about any other nation. Even the mission map is limited to mainland USA, making the whole global invasion a very US-centric thing.

There are also some very annonying design decissions in the game:
Firstly it's Checkpoints only. Died in the 3rd wave of a shootout? Feel lucky if it places you right at the beginning of the fight instead of some rooms prior. It doesn't even allow free saving outside the missions during exploring the base.
Placement of team members or deployable abilities makes you basically move them along the physical path in the same 3rd person view instead of ignoring obstacles, stairs or maybe giving you more of a bird's eye view. All while the battle doesn't pause but only slows down, which means moving a mortally wounded squad mate out of the danger zone may end up with him being shot during the command giving.
Having sprint on the same button as taking cover leads to some strange positioning sometimes, especially since you can't stear during sprinting.
During the first part of the game you will open doors, having a short scene of your character securing the room with raised weapon through which he is uncontrollable and which is always pointless since there are never enemies behing those doors. Nor anything other to speak of. Later in the game this suddenly stops but is replaced with long empty corridors and elevator rides during which nothing happens.

reviewText:
TL;DR Get this game on sale, but spend no more than $10

Now that thats out of the way, i will start by saying this game was OK. Not great, but not bad either. The gameplay reminds me of Dragon Age: Origins (in terms of the squad command) mixed with a cover-to-cover 3PS. Its fun for a while, but ordering around your squad can be a nuisance. They like to run to random places and get cut off, then go into bleedout. Not a big deal on lower difficulties, but on higher difficulties, if they die, they die for good. Gameplay score 8/10

The story is interesting. It was pretty good up until the final few missions, then it took a nose dive. The very end brought it back a little, but the fact remained that the twist at the end made no sense with the rest of the story. I won't spoil it any more than that. Story score 7/10

The graphics are really good. Better than XCOM: Enemy Unknown. Not top notch, but still very good. Graphics score 9/10

Overall, I'd give this game a solid 7/10, mainly because of the stupid plot twist. If it had actually progressed the way it should have, i'd have given the game 8.5/10.

reviewText: While this game departs sharply from the turn based mechanics found in the pervious XCOM games, I found it to be a compitantly excuted experience for a real time squad based strategy game. While this game is by no means original, borrowing from other games like Assassin Creed: Brotherhood and Mass Effect, it doesn't attempt anything it is uncapable of executing. There are some story line based elements, such as characters not facing the people they intend on talking to in what intends to be an immotional scene, one would think that this detracted from the experience. It only did so minorly. The mechancis of this game carry it. Only at the end when they throw you in a room with wave after wave of enemy did I ever feel that the game was being unfair, however I only wiped once. Any time I had died prior It had been my own tactical fault for playing the game for what is is not: A FPS. As the game proceeds, I found more and more fault with the team pathing AI, and sometimes in the later levels where the terriegn is more complex, I found I needed to baby sit thier movements, but the majority of of the time they handled fine.\n\nIn Summary I would recomend this game, especially at the price it is at present.

reviewText:
First off, I have absolutely no experience with the XCOM franchise, so I can't say how the plot stands with the other games, or how faithful the universe is.
Besides, I haven't played a tactical TPS in a long time, which means that I may overlook some aspects that avid players of the genre look forward to.

But here are my general thoughts. I'll try not to be too detailed, since AAAs have such a bigger scale compared to what I'm used to playing.

So. The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a tactical third person shooter, set in the 60's, in the first alien invasion of Earth. The best of the best are united in the XCOM to fight this invasion, and cover it up to protect the population.
You'll go through several missions (some minor, some major), and you'll get to know the people you're working with between each, in the base.

You have a squad of 3 people (you, and 2 AI partners), that you have some control over, during the fights. There are different classes in the game, and with each come different skills to aid you in battle. Some are support focused (providing shields, damage buffs, etc.), engineers (focus on tech, turrets, etc.), artillery (with long range deadly shots), you get the drill.
Each of them can be leveled up to rank 5, and you go as far as rank 10. With each rank you choose 1 of 2 perks (sometimes, 1 of 1... tough choice, there).


Let's start with the presentation.
It's a AAA game, and that's very clear. Everything looks really nice, and it felt the theme surprisingly well, with the lighting effects giving the game an old sci-fi feel! Other parts of the game looked more generic, unfortunately. But overall, it certainly looked great, with good particle effects, lighting, and physics.

The music also fit the theme very well, both the 60's feel, and the sci-fi. Unfortunately, it was very far apart. I don't feel like they've used the music very effectively, specially in the tense and emotional moments, the music in those was simply underwhelming.

Overall, it didn't really feel as unique as it could have. As a AAA, it did very little to standout, despite being pretty good aside from that.
One thing it did well in the beginning, was portraying the time setting well, using posters, and even the conversations with the different people.

Moving on.
The gameplay started out pretty good, but the probems soon started to reveal themselves. I chose to play in Commander Difficulty at first. The problem with that, was the friendly AI. They died within 4 seconds of the start of the fight. And I'm not exaggerating!
If I sent someone to revive them, they'd just stand in the middle of the shots and would die as well. And that was pretty much the experience. That kind of challenge wasn't welcome at all. I spent way more time trying to keep my squad alive than fighting!
So... after about 5 missions I decided I had enough with it, and turned it to Veteran. I died twice in the whole game after that. Once in the last mission, with throws wave after wave of enemies after you.
There's just such a big discrepancy between Hard and Very Hard... that's not a very good balance, in my opinion.

Commander mode could have been really strategic and tense, if the AI was worth something.       Unfortunately, it was really bad. And you could see in the end, comparing their kills to yours. You alone did about 95% of the job, so yeah...

Other than that, it wasn't bad. You had several different weapons at your disposal, different enemies had to be taken out in different ways (not too different, but a bit different nonetheless), the skills lead to some nice teamwork... I wasn't bad!
It was not spectacular, but I was fairly enjoyable.

As I said before, between missions, you'll be in the Hub Area. Here, you can talk to the scientists, engineers, pretty much everyone, and get their view on the invasion. You'll also know why they're there, and what they're working on. That was cool. It didn't blow my mind, but it's good that it's there, if you feel like exploring a bit more.
There are also Notes, Photos, and AudioLogs" spread out
date: during the breaks between battles. These also give you a bit more insight into the world
recommended: which is always good!\n\nSomething that really bothered me though
hoursPlayed: was the Audio Logs. You had to stand near to listen to it. ... Why? The whole point of audio logs is to keep the player exploring
voteText: while being presented with the backstory. And they managed to screw it up

and have you stop your playing to listen to it... It makes no sense! Might as well give you a note instead of an audio log... I don't understand.

reviewText:
The Bureau XCOM Declassified isn’t bad game as people say it is (especially XCOM hardcore fans).

I know that it isn’t a classic XCOM game and that it struggles to find its place in the XCOM-series. But it provides a solid experience if you´re a person who likes 3rd person shooters and sometimes meaningless shooting.

The story is quite intriguing.  The combat is decent and the AI of the enemies is surprisingly good. The command system works remarkably well because you have to constantly issue new orders to your NPCs.

Things that I disliked was that the combats weren’t that strategic as the other XCOM games, sometimes it was just too much meaningless shooting.  The world felt like the game Resistance, and it felt really empty which made the game a little boring time to time. The DLC that the game has to offer is just not worth is because it does not add anything new. If you want the DLC buy it when the game is on sale.

I give this game a solid 7.5/10.

reviewText: Decent premise, but ultimately less enjoyable than a root canal. The whole game is pretty much cutscene after endless cutscene, half of which suffer from some bug in the sound so you get to watch but have no idea what is going on. And you finish one cutscene just to be thrown into another, absolutely no gaming required. Just watch a cartoon. The whole thing is on rails, so you move through mazes of landscape just to get to, you guessed it, another cutscene. In between moving from cutscene area to cutscene area, you do come across nice little rooms with aliens, and you get to take a few shots, throw a few grenades, issue some orders to your NPC allies, but wait; they tend to either ignore your orders or follow them and then do their own thing, getting killed. And yet you can still survive the encounter, to get to the next group of cutscenes.\n\nIf you waste money on this trash you'll get a buggy cartoon made up of cutscenes. Move across the bridge, click on the radio, and yes, a cutscene. After that, move to the next room, and bam another cutscene. garbage garbage garbage.

reviewText:
This is NOTHING like xcom. Don't go in expecting anything similar. They'd be as well just removing XCOM from the name.
If you can get it for 10 euro, it's worth it. Otherwise, there are games with far better gameplay out there.
If you do buy it, buy the plasma pistol as well it's a massive help to get past the initial boring bits.

The game is quite polished and isn't outright BAD but falls down with:


- The AI. It's dumb as hell. If you tell them to stand somewhere, and you yourself move, they will often run to keep close to you - making flanking irritating to impossible
- some of the encounters will cause you to die out of just bad luck and sheer number of enemies spamming grenades at you. With no mid level saves it's a pain to do an entire segment again.
- reloading will wipe any buffs, so you have to spend a while reshielding or rebuffing
- there's nothing tactical about it. It's cluster frack management.
- there no explanation why half your guys have magic" abilities at the start. They just do.
- reference to the gear on your arm is made at several points. It's not explained why you have it or where it came from
- the base segments are irritatingly slow to navigate as you cannot sprint
- when your team mate's abilities are on cooldown
date: they are essentially useless.\n- the engineer can only have a shotgun for about 80% of the game
recommended: and the shotgun is severely pointless. yes
hoursPlayed: they can place a turret but they can't keep the turret up themselves so if it died he'll mince about doing very little\n- combat is unsatisfying\n- stats of each backpack (character modifier) aren't clear
voteText: so it's not really obvious what will be better.\n- light plasma pistol is a must. the enemy has a massive upperhand early on really dragging the "bad" part of the game on.\n- and on that note
helpfulPercent: the game doesn't really get remotely fun till your guys start hitting level 4 or 5.\n- some ammo capacities are overly restrictive making some weapons not really feel like an upgrade when they should\n- inexplicably you cannot have female followers
votesHelpful: despite the animations clearly being available given that the female agent weaver joins you to provide fire support"

reviewText:
This game combines my love of shooters, with tactics and strategy and some skill building from the classic Xcom games.

This is not turn based but full on real time 3 squad combat. It's hard, it's fun and combines the futuristic tech with perfectly recreated 1960's earth tech. Making for a rather gorgeous looking game.

Storywise its your basic alien invasion, set in the Xcom world, expect larger then life stuff.

I don't see why so many hate on it. I absolutely am enjoying this game.

reviewText:
Awesome game!

Take it as a third person shooter in wich you issue commands to 2 npc companions. Just feels great syncronizing skills in slow motion, flanking the enemy for that extra damage...
You get to choose wich weapons your squad will be using, perks, etc...Be careful not letting them die, or you'll have to get new recruits.

Story is linear, but it was at a good pace and made sense. I liked the gritty and dark alien theme.
Also , i used my gamepad.... felt more natural to command and play.
Was fun while it lasted!

reviewText: Basically this entire game is starting a mission, walk 5 feet, battle, talk, battle, battle, battle. You go back to base where you can't do anything except listen to a couple people with no actual impact on the game. You then select your next mission and just battle your way through it. There seems to be no actual point to this game. Your NPC team mates can't hit the broad side of a barn, leaving you to do 90% of the damage even when you have control of what they are doing. No research to be done, nothing cool whatsoever. Fight after fight after fight. Such a crazy disappointment.\n\nIf you liked any of the XCOM games, don't bother with this one. I wouldn't pay more than 5$ for this. Thank god I bought it on sale.
