reviewText:
The Bureau XCOM Declassified isn’t bad game as people say it is (especially XCOM hardcore fans).

I know that it isn’t a classic XCOM game and that it struggles to find its place in the XCOM-series. But it provides a solid experience if you´re a person who likes 3rd person shooters and sometimes meaningless shooting.

The story is quite intriguing.  The combat is decent and the AI of the enemies is surprisingly good. The command system works remarkably well because you have to constantly issue new orders to your NPCs.

Things that I disliked was that the combats weren’t that strategic as the other XCOM games, sometimes it was just too much meaningless shooting.  The world felt like the game Resistance, and it felt really empty which made the game a little boring time to time. The DLC that the game has to offer is just not worth is because it does not add anything new. If you want the DLC buy it when the game is on sale.

I give this game a solid 7.5/10.

reviewText: Decent premise, but ultimately less enjoyable than a root canal. The whole game is pretty much cutscene after endless cutscene, half of which suffer from some bug in the sound so you get to watch but have no idea what is going on. And you finish one cutscene just to be thrown into another, absolutely no gaming required. Just watch a cartoon. The whole thing is on rails, so you move through mazes of landscape just to get to, you guessed it, another cutscene. In between moving from cutscene area to cutscene area, you do come across nice little rooms with aliens, and you get to take a few shots, throw a few grenades, issue some orders to your NPC allies, but wait; they tend to either ignore your orders or follow them and then do their own thing, getting killed. And yet you can still survive the encounter, to get to the next group of cutscenes.\n\nIf you waste money on this trash you'll get a buggy cartoon made up of cutscenes. Move across the bridge, click on the radio, and yes, a cutscene. After that, move to the next room, and bam another cutscene. garbage garbage garbage.

reviewText: Jumpy story with no cohesion.  Couldn't even bother to put in the graphics during cut scenes of what suit you were wearing or gun you were holding.  Very rushed and not well thought out difficulty ramping.  One of the first 4 backpacks you get is the tactical, or tactics, yeah those are two seperate backpacks, and it increases range of abilities and damage of weapons.  It has no drawback, where the others are, less damage for more ability uses.  Destroy armor on armored targets, but less range of ability.  Disable enemy shields, but less ammo.  They are just pointless to use any other backpack.  There aren't enough armoured enemies to make them actually a challenge and there is always a rocket launcher convenently placed. Also, the plasma pistol DLC is basically a hand held cannon, no  point in usung anything else till late game, even then...  Shield enemies are easy to take out, there was no real challenge to the game.  You and your guys become immoirtal when reviving somebody, which them getting knocked down isn't all that often.\nOne cut scene had you get knocked out, only to be picked up by the ehad scientist and the leader.  (Another thing, none of these characters are memorable)  Your two people following you, just decided to leave and let the commander and a scientist come save you and carry you back.  Nothing made any sense about being dropped off or picked up after battles, and the poor attempt at having dialogue between fights is so poor and they are so far apart it seems it is done just to add play time. Having to walk all the way down to the lab for.. nothing that impacts gameplay.  Help a scientist test out a pulse gun... which you don't get, why, not enough mooks sitting arund 3 feet away from you to pull the trigger for you??\nI am sorry i wasted money on this game, glad I bought it suring the 2K sale.

reviewText:
I really wanted to love this game. I'm a huge fan of both the XCOM series and FPS games. It seemed like an awesome blending of things I love set in an awesome time period. However, the game just isn't polished. Your AI team mates make terrible decisions, forcing you to micromanage them which derails the pace of the game. The interface is clunky and the game crashes frequently.

They want the game to be semi-tactical but they don't give you any options to do that outside of issuing orders. None of the gear you get has stats in any meaningful way. I.E. you'll get one piece of gear that says it increases critical hit damage, but then gives no clue as to how much compared to another piece of gear that does the same thing. You also lose all of the cool meta play of how XCOM is run except for in a few forced ways.

*****Possible Spoilers*****
Probably the worst part of the game is the writing. The voice acting is fine but the dialogue is cliche after cliche. The characters act inconsistently. In one scene you'll go rogue and in the next chew someone out for doing the same, then support someone else for going rogue in the scene after. The choices people make are unbelievable, including allowing agent after agent to disobey orders.

The internal logic of the game is busted. For example in the opening mission you're paired with a guy who can throw out laser turrets even though XCOM hasn't gotten that technology yet. The game is constantly throwing out situations/abilities/technology that don't make any sense or follow the XCOM universe's rules.

column29: you're presented with a big, steaming pile of a squad command system.  The Bureau has you giving commands to your agents, not too unlike Enemy Unknown did - apart from the fact that you *are* also one of the agents.  What you end up with, then, is a game where you play a real-time, but dumbed-down version of XCOM: Enemy Unknown, in between bouts of playing an okay-but-not-amazing third-person shooter game, using a clumsier version of the dynamic pause squad-command system from the Mass Effect trilogy.\n\nSo, if you *liked* XCOM: Enemy Unknown, or the Mass Effect trilogy... don't play this.  If you like the XCOM series enough that you simply must at least *try* The Bureau, do yourself a favour and at least wait for a sale, which will reduce the sting if you end up being as disappointed as I was.

reviewText:
This is NOTHING like xcom. Don't go in expecting anything similar. They'd be as well just removing XCOM from the name.
If you can get it for 10 euro, it's worth it. Otherwise, there are games with far better gameplay out there.
If you do buy it, buy the plasma pistol as well it's a massive help to get past the initial boring bits.

The game is quite polished and isn't outright BAD but falls down with:


- The AI. It's dumb as hell. If you tell them to stand somewhere, and you yourself move, they will often run to keep close to you - making flanking irritating to impossible
- some of the encounters will cause you to die out of just bad luck and sheer number of enemies spamming grenades at you. With no mid level saves it's a pain to do an entire segment again.

reviewText:
First off: It's not a bad game. It's solid for what it does - mostly being a Cover Shooter.
But it feels lackluster in every regard.

The main discipline, the actual tactical shooting doesn't feel very tactical unless late in the game. The AI is unreliable at best, the options are limited to targeting a specific enemy, moving to a position and a very limited set of active abilities which almost all offer some kind of damage output increase instead of supporting utility. The enemies feel very bullet spongy even on lower difficulties and only pose a challenge through their masses combined with the team-AI running into open field, especially in the second half of the game.
Customizationwise the game doesn't offer much. A handful of weapons in the archetypes of assault rifle, shotgun, sniper rifle, sidearm and heavy arms divided into three ammunition types. Bullets against unarmored, Laser against shields and plasma with a damage over time effect, though the difference doesn't matter much in the field and your basically limited to whatever you find during the missions anyway. The skill trees offer some choices which again don't account for much, just as the backpacks. It all feels like more was planned but eventually cut.
All of this makes the game play like a generic cover shooter for a long time.

The level design offers some pretty nice scenary and fantastic atmosphere at times but with large gaps filled with generic corridors and obstacles (and some invisible walls) conviniently placed to only allow a narrow path. Whenever you see a wider area, be assured to have enemies incoming. Since the linear design doesn't allow much exploration, it is surprising that the paths branching left and right of the main path are often pointless and empty or give a new backpack schematic at best - which you can mostly also get from the dispatch side missions.

The story is based on the older (50s - 60s) SciFi movies with slight horror mixed in between. Think of 'Invasion of the Body Snatchers' or similar - or Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons which has basically the same premise ;)
Again it feels cut on every end. There are some illogical jumps in character behaviour, descissions which don't matter at all, dialogue which repeats itself or is even nonsensical and the campaign feels very rushed with various Dei ex machina. The writing also does a very good job of making the main character as unlikeable as humanly possibile, throwing out oneliners like Duke Nukem which drip from pathos and stupidity.
The whole XCOM feeling from the classic games or the remake is barely there apart from the alien names - you're only fighting on US American soil, with US Americans and have no contact to or intel about any other nation. Even the mission map is limited to mainland USA, making the whole global invasion a very US-centric thing.

There are also some very annonying design decissions in the game:
Firstly it's Checkpoints only. Died in the 3rd wave of a shootout? Feel lucky if it places you right at the beginning of the fight instead of some rooms prior. It doesn't even allow free saving outside the missions during exploring the base.
Placement of team members or deployable abilities makes you basically move them along the physical path in the same 3rd person view instead of ignoring obstacles, stairs or maybe giving you more of a bird's eye view. All while the battle doesn't pause but only slows down, which means moving a mortally wounded squad mate out of the danger zone may end up with him being shot during the command giving.
Having sprint on the same button as taking cover leads to some strange positioning sometimes, especially since you can't stear during sprinting.
During the first part of the game you will open doors, having a short scene of your character securing the room with raised weapon through which he is uncontrollable and which is always pointless since there are never enemies behing those doors. Nor anything other to speak of. Later in the game this suddenly stops but is replaced with long empty corridors and elevator rides during which nothing happens.

reviewText:
I have played all of the XCOM games and love the series, so being able to play a third-position shooter take on the XCOM universe was very nice and refreshing.

If you like the series, alien themes, third-person action shooters, and squad-based tactics, you will really enjoy this game.

The aesthetics are fantastic with lots of special effects in the form of mutons (mutations taken from the alien technology). The music fits very well with the theme and setting - it is appropriately intense whenever the action calls for it.

The controls are fairly straightforward, and the tutorial mission is great at helping you understand both the controls and how to issue orders to your squad without being too long or too boring. The learning curve is moderate, however, the game can be extremely unforgiven in the commander (hardest) difficulty. There is permanent death if your squad members are downed and not revived in time on commander difficulty; furthermore, reviving them only stabilizes them - meaning they are out of combat until the instance is cleared of all enemies. I am playing on this difficulty, and have had many situations where I had to slow-play and defeat all the enemies on my own. Your squad members are heavily reliant on your orders, especially in the harder difficulties.

The story is pretty good, and there is a lot of extras provided in the form of audio recordings and files if you choose to look for them.

The gameplay reminded me a lot of Mass Effect, down to the very first muton power you unlock for your character - lift. The feedback is very good, showing the enemy's health at the top center of the screen, and having large grenade icons warning you of the blast radius. During battles, you can go into battle focus, which slows down time to a crawl and allows you to issue your orders. There is a range where you can order your squadmates to move/do actions, which I found to be very nice. You can have two weapons equipped at a time, and you will slowly unlock new equipment (the first being a bag that increases your headshot damage). You may have only 2 other active squad members at a time.

Cover is extremely important, as the enemy will try to actively flank you and can become very aggressive. Most combat instances will have a few ammo drops to refill your weapons, and explosive barrels are littered in many areas to help you kill mobs of enemies quickly.

As you gain experience, you will level up and can choose different perks for both you and your teammates. There is a decent variety of customization - you can change every agent's clothing color (pretty basic), and their background changes the type of perks that can be unlocked. You can recruit new agents, and when you do this you will be given an option to choose both their class and their background (ex: engineer class with technical expertise, leading to faster cooldowns on abilities).

The XCOM base is not as explorable as I'd like, but it is still fun to walk around and talk to people - or read the extra content like agent dossiers.

There are a number of side missions for you to play and unlock more mutons. Completing these help you gain levels and increase your psychic arsenal to defeat the alien invaders.

Very good game, especially if you are a fan of the series.

Definitely recommend!
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I don't know if I'm the only person in the world who still remembers them, but The Bureau is a lot like Gearbox's old Brothers in Arms series: it's a third person, tactical squad shooter where you're expected to win by ordering your men to flank and use their special abilities rather than killing everything yourself. A more recent comparison, and this is fairly obvious based on the UI and such, is Mass Effect 2/3's combat (but again, with less focus on the protagonist killing everything himself).

It's a pretty good-looking game (it's UE3 with fairly pretty lighting, and a really solid aesthetic direction), and I've only run into a couple of minor bugs (a flying enemy got stuck under the level a couple of times because they were spawning behind a tall wall and attempting to go under it) - performance and stability are solid on my system. It's a good port, too, with lots of video options and a good FoV slider (it's dumb to have to mention this, but hey, modern gaming).

I really don't get why it got the review scores it did. It's a really polished, fun title in what is admittedly a fairly niche genre, and to cap things off, it has one of the more intelligent war plots I've seen in video games (yes, despite being a game about the 1950s FBI fighting little grey men). It's also fun seeing what are basically levels from XCOM: Enemy Unknown translated to third person.

All in all, if you're a fan of tactical third-person shooters, I can only recommend this. It's great.

reviewText:
Insanely underrated game. Those who expect a sequel to XCOM Enemy Unknown/Within, will be extraordinarily disappointed with The Bureau: XCOM Declassified.

This is not a turn-based strategy game. This is a squad-based third person shooter. There is definitely strategy involved with selecting the proper soldiers (two squadmates to assist you at a time) with the appropriate weapons and knowing how to manage their abilities in order to conserve the most ammo, maximize opportunities for kills, etc.; but it's incredibly different from the previous entry to the XCOM series.

But change is not a bad thing, anyone interested in the (albeit fairly cliche at this point in time) concept of an alien invasion in the midst of a futuristic-styled 60's era, will enjoy The Bureau's story. It throws a few interesting twists to keep it from being entirely cliche, and overall executes the concept it goes for, perfectly.

While XCOM Declassified is definitely not for everyone, fans of alien sci-fi with an open mind to change for a series, who are willing to learn how to properly manage their soldiers (there is a bit of a learning curve and frustration in the beginning), will certainly enjoy this game. Especially on its frequent dirt-cheap sales, it's impossible to go wrong. Buy this game.

reviewText:
I'm going to say this. It is not a terrible game, HOWEVER it is not worth $30, maybe $10 - $15. I luckily got it in a Xcom bundle for a good price.

The game has it's ups and downs with a nice leveling system (however limited it may be) and the choice of what two allies you bring with you is cool (Engi, medic, sniper, ect). The game is a nice 1960's Mass Effect third person strategy game. You give commands to your team members while also taking to the field and shooting aliens.

The story is good, you're escorting an item when things go wrong and an alien invasion starts. You join up with a secret military group and fight back in an interesting dispatch soldiers to some missions while fighting in other missions. Without giving away too much I will just say that the game has a fantastic mind blowing twist towards the end that I did not see coming.

One negative I found with the game is the friendly AI that you bring with you. I started on the highest difficulty and at first had no issues as I was able to give basic orders to my allies, ie take cover and support me, but you need to be very specific with where you want your allies to go and what path you want them to take. If you are not you will end up seeing your ally run right through the crossfire being mowed down in seconds. Also sometimes though it seemed random, your allies would run back to you after completing a task, very infuriating when you're taking on a spider machine with 5+ aliens and you're waiting for your ally to complete their flanking order you gave them only to find them standing next to you. I ended up toning down the difficulty so I could complete the game while still enjoying it.

I also ended up just bringing two engi allies with me because i found being able to deploy two turrets and two land mines very useful and effective. Moreso than the other classes with my playstyle.

I do believe you should buy this game, just at a lower price.

Good gameplay
Enjoyable story
Fun leveling and side quests
Decent length (didn't drag on)
Nice variety in weapons

Annoying AI
Could do with more enemy variety (only about 5)

reviewText:
All in all it was well worth the bundled price with the predecessors of the series. I love enemy unknown and grew up on terror from the deep. This is nothing like these, expect a cover tactical shooter that is driven by a narrative akin to the series. Life forms from somewhere else have arrived, and they are terribly aggressive and we apes (sorry creationists), being the busy little warriors we are are now tasked with overcoming a dominant invasion force by doing what we love--killing stuff with noisy things.

This is a story-driven XCOM shooter. It was refreshing to play as the agents themselves and the story was good enough to keep the player going. Fighting enemies in real and slowed time makes mutons much more menacing. You also can't count on a team of snipers as your squad will always be three people. Fights are exciting as maps are well arranged to encourage scattering your team to flank, support, or divert enemies. I would recommend keeping the difficulty up high as lower levels allow for easily exploitable AI. At one point I was dropping teams of five monsters in a couple seconds mainly through well placed powers and team members.

Unfortunately, there isn't much in the way of variation in outcomes so don't expect anything quite so dynamic.

Worth a single run through but I do not feel compelled to replay it.

I'd give it a 6.5 out of 10, fun but borrows too much to stand out.

reviewText:
This game was a blast to play. It isn't a hardcore FPS, so don't go into it expecting those sorts of mechanics. It has the basic FPS down and some interesting progression-based abilities. It's more of an interactive story, than a true FPS.

The kitschy, historical feel of the game is spot on; you feel like you are in a 50's/60's sci-fi movie. The story is well-written, even if some choices are a bit one-sided in the outcome. However, there are a few places the story can turn so sharply from a single choice I was surprised.

I feel this game has gotten a bad rap. There are far too many bad reviews with derogatory comments that are not deserved. I had originally skipped this game and only received it as part of a combo sale some time later and I can say I am so glad that I had the chance to play it.

This is well incorporated into the shooter setting by the bullet time" like slow down during which you can give orders to your squad.

All in all I really liked playing this game and can recommend it to everybody who likes the XCOM setting or has a nick for tactical 3rd person shooters."

reviewText:
XCOM Declassified
Some secrets to hold onto for forever...


I heard from several reviewers and friends that this game was absolutely horrible and to an extent I agree with them. Declassified I found was much more interesting when I first read about it in a gaming magazine. It WAS supposed to be a pulp sci-fi suspense story played in First-Person, however several happenings in 2K forced its re-purposing into the 3rd Person shooter we have here.

The game does manage to hold onto the pulp 60's sci-fi style, unfortunately it quickly gets buried under all the shooting and with that becomes almost irrelevant. A sad thing, in my opinion. For I enjoyed the early previews of the original project, even IF it being an FPS. I did hope that the writers would have managed to create a good suspenseful story to cover the somewhat generic feel of the FPS, it was a bit naive to think that in retrospect. Since the only thing that runs the games industry these days is the AAA's and they only care about money and I could argue that the game is partly bad because of that.


However, to the game.

Sadly under performing and uninteresting, I did not hold much hope for it. Given what I've heard about it, but to finally see and play it.. Urgh. The game is a good example of a good concept ruined, it does manage to be a decent enough precursor to the XCOM series as a whole, but it does it so badly. It's almost not worth mentioning.

The games story managed to underwhelm me and I now understand why that certain mission ended rather abruptly, the pop a cap in ye  ♥♥♥  " part

hoursPlayed: they might walk right to the enemy and get downed. Most of my crew died due to that fatal flaw in their brain development. Otherwise the fighting is O.K and that's pretty much it
voteText: I can't for the life of me tell you a good combat mission the game had.\n\nI feel like my time has been wasted

Gameplay

This game is a decent 3rd person shooter. your companion AI is pretty bad they will do stuff like take cover in stupid positions where everyone can shoot them.  but if you give them orders they are pretty usefull at times. i see where they were trying to go with the xcom side of things but i wish you had more control over your squad like an xcom game.  If its gonna have the xcom branding i expect to be able to tell my squad to hunker down so they shoot less and go into defensive mode.

Story

Story is full of plot holes. Theres a plot twist near the end of the game that dosent have a ton of impact. The dlc missions that add to the story provide more plotholes than fill them. The main cast overall is just not very memoriable.


Final thoughts

Not worth 20 bucks maybe 10 or 5 get it if its on sale.

reviewText:
The Bureau is a solid squad based cover shooter with tactical and RPG elements.  You must fight off an alien invasion to 1960ies earth and unravel the mysterious forces at work.  You command a squad of agents with different specialties and you and your agents can be leveled up with different abilities and buffs as the game progress.  You can control your 2 allies on the field (very similar combat to Mass Effect 2 & 3) by placing them in different positions and assign powers to use.  The powers are fun and vary from bio and machine allies, bombs, turrets, mind control, levitation and more!  Combat is fluid and fun and the best part of the game.

The setting feels like 1960ies America, or at least what the movies describe as 60ies America, and I really enjoyed the ambiance from the visual appeal of a town, college or rural area.  There are lots of aesthetics thrown in like old TV screens, lab equipment, diners, cars,  etc that really capture the feel of 60ies living.  Unfortunately your squad and other characters you interact with are wooden and bland.   However you are able to make choices in conversation and there are a few interesting twists near the end that your choice will have some impact on the story.  For a sci-fi invasion angle, I enjoyed the story, it’s just that the wooden NPC’s drag it down and take away some of the immersion created by the set pieces and combat.

I hate to review a game in the context of another, but my advice is if you have played Mass Effect 2 & 3 and loved it, you need to play The Bureau as it’s the closest thing to more Mass Effect.  On its own the Bureau has enjoyable gameplay, solid atmosphere with a fun campy story that is brought down by bland characters but is still a worthwhile light RPG experience, plays great with a gamepad.

FYI – if you have an AMD graphics card turn the physics options off to have a high frame rate.  Otherwise X-com Declassified is a looker even on mid-level machines.
voteText: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you like tactical RPG shooting games, mainly Mass Effect, then you'll find this game to be an enjoyable, yet not amazing or incredible, game.

The story is alright, you defend 1950's-60's America from alien invaders who have better technology and numbers than you. It isn't as good as others in the genre but with a few twists here and there it doesn't drag down the enjoyment. The characters, an important part of these kinds of games since you will be talking to them so much, are only passingly enjoyable and many of them don't have enough going for them to make them memorable. Some of the main characters are fine but they aren't as good as the ones in other games.

The setting is a refreshing change from the norm of today's shooters. The clash between olden day America and the futuristic alien architecture is pleasing to look at as you see the destruction between the two. I liked the clash so much that I was a little disappointed when it changed to primarily alien bases later on in the game.

The graphics are nice, using the unreal engine 3 to a great extent. Character models look nice and the effects are fun to look at. The game has additional Physx support and so cloth and particles flow smoothly. I have AMD so I couldn't really use it. The graphics aren't spectacular to look at, but I enjoyed what I saw.

Gameplay is fun and challenges you to direct your team to victory. I played on the hardest difficulty, commander, and it wasn't too difficult once I got a handle on things. You can't take too much damage in this game, and unlike other games health doesn't really regenerate and you can't heal too often. This forces you to use your squad to its fullest capacity instead of going Rambo and doing everything yourself. The abilities are useful and directing your team in slow motion, since the game doesn't pause when you plan out your actions, is engaging and enjoyable.

The enemies are a little boring as many of them are just humanoid soldiers that don't act any different than any other game. The bosses, on the other hand, are fun and challenge you in tough fights. Things like Mutons, Sectopods, and Gunships become even scarier as they soak up damage and force you to rely on your team's abilities to slow down, damage, and distract the enemy. It really gives you an accomplished feeling when you can plan and take one down without anyone getting really hurt.

In the end, I enjoyed this game and recommend it to anyone on the fence on getting it during a sale like I did. It may not be the best of its kind in the genre, but you won't really have a bad time while playing it.

reviewText:
This is not a bad game as reviewers claim it to be, its not the greatest game ever made, but it has its upsides and downsides. Its not a traditional xcom game, but more of a Mass Effect simmilare game. Defenetly worth playing it, enjoyed this game more than some of the recent FPS games i played.

+ The strategy part in this is okey, it was abit difficult at start to give orders, but once you get into it, its pretty sweet.
+ Intressting level design, events that happen within them, places to see, keeps you wanting more.

Negativ

- Alot in the story didnt make any sence or was poorly explained.
- The AI agents can be pretty useless if you dont give them orders or keep track of what they are up to.
- Very limited customization.

Completed the whole game and all the DLC material. I thought it was pretty entertaining despite its flaws, if you get the chance to pick this game up, do it.

reviewText:
XCOM Declassified is a third person cover shooter with a somewhat turn based combat (its not really turn based but the game slowed down when you bring up the squad menu). Think of Mass Effect in XCOM universe but not that polished. The AI is somewhat dumb and you have to ordered it most of the time.

The first part of the game is annoying because of your squad's AI, many times I almost gave up on the game and thought to bury it in my backlog. But once you finished a mission or two and you leveled up a bit, the game kinda grow on you. I suggest that you turn down the difficulty to easy in the first part of the game then just turn it up again when you leveled up a bit and got some laser/plasma weapon.

Overall, its an ok game. Not great but not bad either. IMO, its worth the time that I spent on it finishing up the game and the 3.99 euro that I paid for it.

reviewText:
The game is clunky, the squadmate A.I. is suicidal in a game with perma-death and gear for your soldiers along with traits is badly explained and nebulous on what it does. There is no research or capturing for upgrades, though there is a leveling system that gives you access to more abilities as you go.

Back to the game's clunkiness, guns have obscene amounts of recoil and if you don't use a mouse and keyboard you can't aim worth a damn. However the movement is also clunky and only really manageable with a controller. Enemies are massive bullet sponges as well.

Had potential to be great, it's sub-par at best. Maybe good for a few hours at the current sales price.

reviewText:
I'm just going to clerify this now. I love the original XCOM games. The ones that were hard as hell, and made everything into a exceedingly one sided game of Russian Roulette.

That being said, I can't honestly recommend The Bureau. While it is an XCOM game, it just lacks the feeling of XCOM. The chance to hit doesn't mean anything like it did in the old games, and as long as you have line of sight it's almost always a hit. There is strategy in it, and I do appreciate their attempt to make height and range a factor in battle. But the skills that your units gain from combat make it too easy to bulldoze through the aliens.

On the other hand, it does have a very interesting story. One that shows history in a stranger light, and almost seems like it came from a tabloid magazine or some conspiracy theorist's mind. It's interesting, but could have been so much more. XCOM is known as a world organization, yet in this game is only shown as a United States one. Yes, there is reasoning for it in the story, but that doesn't mean that you have to limit the game map to just the US. What about Canada? Or Mexico? Maybe Europe or Asia? What happened there? How did they fight? Did they fight?

Maybe thats just me asking too many questions. But there are plot holes that could have been filled. Overall, it is ok. Not good enough for me to recommend it to anyone, but still stable enough to be played and enjoyed by some. Graphicly, it looked nice. Explosions and blood was somewhat realistic, and the details in the aliens was nice. Gameplay wise, it could have been stronger, and less formulated like most 3rd person shooters.

I'd honestly give it a 3/5 rating, with a strong warning to anyone who wants to buy it.

reviewText:
I'm a fan of the XCom franchise, but I went into this one very skeptical due to its more action oriented design than the traditional titles. Once I started play tho I was pleasantly surprised. The game is obviously very visually amazing but they didn't waste all their time on that and leave you with a shallow piece of crap.

The plot is very well written and engaging and better thought out, imo, than the one used for XCOM Enemy Unknown. While there is no grand strategy element to this, the way you handle your 3 man teams has an excellent amount of tactical play to it. The time dilation used keeps the game going but allows you a certain level of precision for giving orders and using special abilities.

Despite the fact that the overall plot will remain the same, there are numerous choices within the game that will affect how events play out. This gives the game a surprising amount of replay value. I also recommend the Hangar 6 DLC which gives even more life to the game and fleshes out the story even more.

I don't care about reviews much and you shouldn't, this game is not a RTS or well not what a true X-COM game is BUT, that doesn't mean you should pass on it. The review scores have been unfair to this gem, its worth having for a few reasons,

its a hybrid RTS so that will turn people off a bit, its a shooter, with stats like fallout and you give orders to squadmates to use abilities and skills like you do in mass effect, they still can fight on their own but its all about tactics.

the game takes place in retro 50s land, a great change from the futureish style seen today, classic weapons, with aliens lasers make up your equip, and backpacks are kinda like your magic, the more backpacks you find the better skills you can get, one back may give you better armor attack, others may help you take damage.

story is pretty good, i wish it was more in detail but still good enough, you have a base that changes as you progress threw the game, areas change as they are used, you can read files, listen to audio records etc.

if you want to know the game is kinda like mass effect, spec ops the line,ressistance, a bit of killzone, and rainbow six all at once, its not a easy" game

reviewText: I wish I would have given The Bureau: XCOM Declassified the time of day a while ago. Having played it now, I can see that I was wrong to judge it based solely on it’s cover. The Bureau is a fantastic game. Once they can figure out how to work A.I. a bit smarter without creating a robotic uprising ending in the near extinction of humanity, games like this will get drastically better. Not having your allies shove their faces into bullets will be a great addition to most games. The cursor thing is still my biggest gripe though. I know you can increase the range of abilities, but that only partially fixes the problem. The cursor movement in this game needed a bit more love. The looks, sounds, and most of the voice acting were all great to experience if you just weren’t ripped back into reality when your cursor wouldn’t do something properly. Having the live action fights and a 3rd person shooter aspect were a nice way to change up the XCOM series. I hope we see a sequel someday.\n\nFull Review: TheVideogameBacklog.com

reviewText: This game is nothing like XCOM: Enemy Unknown. I was expecting a strategy game, instead I got a first person shooter with awkward controls and an AI that couldn't fight it's way out of a paper bag. The cinematics and the conversations are well done, and the game looks good, but it lacks the polish of a properly finished game. The characters can only level up to level 5, and their new skills underwhelm. The game is a cover based shooter, but I find myself stuck to the cover as I try to leave due to the awkward controls. They don't explain why the main character gets the ability to lift people at level 2, I think they put it in there to copy Mass Effect. And what's this with the DLC weapons? The game basically gives you weapons, there is no R&D. An there is really only a couple different weapons in the game without DLC. The DLC is an obvious cash grab, not something that adds to the game, but something that should have been included in the first place! The game is still entertaining, but definitely not a blockbuster hit.

reviewText:
This game combines good third-person shooter with the field strategy elements in the original xcom games. It has a really nice combat system making you think each of your moves before excuting them. While fun for the first half of the game, I quickly got bored because of the repetitive gameplay. It is basically moving to an area, killing a bunch of ailens, and then move to another area, kill more ailens, etc. and finally get the objective. It gets really boring espicially witout the base-management system in the traditional xcom game.

The enemy AI is really good espically if you play on the harder difficulties; however, the friendly AI are really bad. In my play through, my agents got stuck in corners and wouldn't move when I tell them to regroup; they constantly ran into gernades; sometimes stand still for minutes before moving to their assigned location. My most memerable experience was when I got shot down right beside one of my agents. I ordered him to revive me, while the other agent taunts the enemy. But the agent kept on shooting, even after I commanded him several more times to revive me, leading me to die and reload the last checkpoint.

As for the story and the interactions between you and the other characters, it is well made and indepth. The characters are intresting and you can read their files to find out more about them. Each characters have different personalities making it very intresting to talk with them.

In conclusion, the game is repetitive and sometimes frustrating witht he glitchy friendly AI, however the challenging enemy AI and the intresting story made up for it. I would give it a 5/10 if there was a rating system.

On the other hand it is hampered by messy glitches, which are usually only fixable with restarting from a save from at least 10 minutes ago, because some scripted sequence refused to start. I would still recommend it to people who love XCOM, because of the storyline. Personally, I am biased towards the game, because it somehow really pulled me in. So, subjectively 9/10, if I am trying to be more objective, than 6,5/10.

reviewText:
I'm about to finish TBXD and I can recommend it, despite flaws.

Mostly pros:
The cinematographic visual style is very well done (down to film grain and complex lens flares) yet subtle.
Gameplay is repetitive, but challenging and stays interesting enough.
The 50s look and feel is well researched and executed. Too bad we don't get to roam around in the hood for some time before the SHTF.
Story fits into the ISO standard X-COM setting with an interesting twist and builds upon it well.
Level design is outstanding, both 1950s American towns, the XCOM base, outdoors and alien installations are nice to look at.
Mostly cons:
It is very obvious the script was re-written several times. Some dialogs contain references to things/events cut from the final game, some responses are out of place, and so on.
The dialog system is rough around the edges, facial animation is a decade behind the times, characters have one talking" animation that just loops no matter what they say they're doing.
Some logical errors that slipped past testing are remarkably game-breaking: for example
date: it is possible to call in artillery fire missions inside buildings

reviewText:
The Bureau was a joyless game. The characters were flat and stiff, as was the story. The combat is a watered-down version of Mass Effect, also devoid of any real fun. Easily a third, if not more, of the game play time is spent simply running from room to room in your base; tedious and dull. I never felt really rewarded for any of the missions, it was just and endless progression towards the end. Even when you unlock the UFO, your combat sessions still begin by showing you arrive in the same old copter from the beginning of the game. The game simply refuses to give you any memorable moments, almost spitefully pulling you forward on a short leash.

The combat works, but feels more like an initial draft and not a fully fleshed out system. Since the rest of the game is simply running from room to room on your base endlessly, you'd think they would have crafted a deep, engaging combat system. You would be wrong. It's relatively fast paced, ammo is limited which forces you to scavenge the levels for weapons. I can see how they intended this to keep players from nesting in secure spots for very long. Your party has abilities, several of them directly taken from ME's biotic powers, it's just nowhere near as enjoyable. Even though the maps change throughout the game, the combat itself begins to feel repetitive very early on.

Even at the end, which I won't spoil for those who feel they must play this game, you are asked to make a choice between characters from the story, characters you have no reason to care for one way or the other. It's as if they felt suddenly at the end you must face a terrible decision and arbitrarily shoehorned one in. The ending was terrible and left me very unsatisfied. I did complete it. At 17 hours it's barely a few evenings worth of play, which is a good thing. By that point I was ready to be done.

reviewText:
Flawed game in almost every aspects. To put it bluntly, The Bureau is a Mass Effect clone, but done poorly. Think I would've preferred 2k Marin to keep up with the aledged XCOM FPS game in the works long ago before scrapping it all to give us this lame XCOM game.

PROS:
+The '60s environment is well done both in visual and audio styles.
+Character models are decent looking (in DX11 that is).
+Reminiscent of the Mass Effect tactical combat style.
+Story twist at a certain point.
+Tier 3 unlocked on the Steam preorder... meaning having all XCOM games w/ The Bureau.

CONS:
-Shoddy port running on POOR performance in DX11 (the game stutters A LOT).
-Weak combat system.
-Stiff character movement with bad controls.
-Weak friendly A.I. is one of the worst I have ever seen in gaming. Always need you to babysit them, constantly! VERY ANNOYING!
-Nonsense plot (you're handled new tech at certain points in the game without ANY explanation... just like some poor unlock excuse!).
-Permadeath on your companions is worst than just reloading your previous checkpoint. It seems to punish you more until you die, then reload checkpoint!
-Voice acting is forced. Lip synch is, out of synch!

OVERALL:
My final thoughts... the game does have more faults than positive aspects. I had some enjoyment at times but many frustrations too. Game is VERY UNSTABLE under DirectX 11. Can't take any screenshots in that DX11 and the game doesn't seem tested much on that mode. Worst, I had a few crashes and lots of stuttering, screen tearing, in DX11.

A gamebreaking bug I've experienced: At some minor mission (one where you see a massive modified" satellite dish)
date:
I just couldn't continue my game unless I switched back to DX9; that way I could finish the mission then switchback to DX11 afterwards. Nasty bug I tell you!

RECOMMEND?
Only if you're an XCOM hardcore fan or if you're new to XCOM franchise
recommended: pick this game once its on a sweet deal. At 40$
hoursPlayed:
its quite pricy for all the faults and cons this game have. So wait up for a drastic discount!

Sad that it took many years of development to get this result!

RATING:
5.5 / 10"

reviewText:
When I saw all the early previews for what they wanted this game to be I was excited. It was creepy, it was tense, it was dangerous, and it looked fun.

This is not that game.
This is a third person shooter with a stilted plotline, meaningless choices, and hours of walking down a straight path shooting at aliens from behind a chest high wall.
At one point in the game you are told that your forces are doing terribly against the aliens. I was never sure how that could be as I was killing hundreds of them each level.

The problem was that they were trying to build up the tension of putting you in a world where you were outgunned, outmanned, and pretty much screwed. And then put you into a third person shooter which requires you to shoot and defeat enemies left right and center for it to be fun.
The combination doesn't work well.

There's no unlocking weapons, technology, or anything else. You will recieve weapons when you pass levels, and you will gain equipment when your people level up. There's no sense in reall changing loadouts because they'll all feel the same in the end.
Your allies will be remarkably usless at doing anything other than getting themselves killed. I can not remember a single time they pulled me out of a dangerous situation, even when they had the single remaining enemy flanked.

And the choices you can make are rendered moot by the end game. I fought to save one character. Did it make a difference? Maybe, depends on the ME3 Which button did you choose" ending. Anything before that? Never gets mentioned.

There are better third person shooters
date: dont' waste your time or money on this one. It just never lived up to it's potential."

reviewText:
It's an XCOM game, alright. At least more than Enforcer ever was.

Battles can get hectic, so staying in cover and ordering your teammates do the work for you is vital. But that's what XCOM is all about: hiding in bushes and commanding people to their death. And every death hurts you deep inside, even if not as much as in Enemy Unknown, but still. You just get fond to your teammates.

Only thing missing are the redshirds you send to suicide runs to flush out stinky aliens from their holes, but two squad mates are enough, as witnessed by many other 3rd Person Shooters. Any more teammates just would make the battles even more cluttered.

Was it worth it? To me: yes!  With a mindblowing scifi plot, where gameplay mechanics were well integrated, and 60's themed environments I can recommend it. Last level especially is something beautiful.

reviewText:
First things first.
1, Forget about metascore (currently around 6.5), this game is far better than this.
2, This is not a strategy, it´s a tactical TPS.
3, I am not hardcore XCOM fan (I played only XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Within - and I love those games)
4, I´m fat and I have a bad haircut. Deal with it.

When The Bureau was announced, I was super excited, because the trailer looked amazing, the premise of alien attack situated in the USA in 60s as FPS with some tactical elements seemed great. We all know that there were some problems during the development and that the game was reworked many times. That sounds like a bad thing ( *cough* Colonial Marines *cough*), eh? Well it is NOT.
GRAPHICS are stunning (I played on DX11). Seriously, I´ve never seen a game with better lightning of a scene. I often caught myself just staring on the scene and taking screenshots, because it simply looked beautiful. It required a decent hardware though on HIGH setting, I played on MID-HIGH. No cons. 10/10
GAMEPLAY The main part of the game are fights of course. Ever played Mass Effect? Imagine that, but better ( HERESY!). Far better. Yea, I said that. Here is the thing. On a mission, you can take two agents with you. Each agent can have one of four classes (Engineer, Recon, Commando, Support). I´ve ended up using Support and Engineer (Engineer can put a turret or mines on the battlefield, Support creates a shield, can give a stims to the whole team etc). You have a special class, called Agent. You can Heal, do some kind telekinetics, put a drone on a battlefield, and at level 9 out 10, you can use a mind control ( yea, those are not the agents you are looking for). You can give the commands to your team via command list (imagine KOTOR). When you press SPACE key, it will put you in slow motion mod and you have lot of time to think (not that much though, the game is not completely freezed). At the beginning of the game you will not use it that much, but when the ♥♥♥♥ hit the fan (that means when Sectopod or Muton introduce themselves on a scene), you will beg for mercy and most of the time, you will end up planning what to do, where to put your agents, and wondering how the ♥♥♥♥ you are supposed to kill them all. This game is challenging on a first walkthrough. Not THAT hard, but decently hard.
The weaponry of this game is not too big ( Colt 1911, M14, Springfield,  then laser and plasma variations, grenades), but nothing to complain, the main power of this game is within the abilities/perks of the team).
One thing bothered me though. A.I. of the squadmates. There are not dumb, not really, but they are not shooting much when no order is given to them, and they do not roll out when a ♥♥♥♥ing grenade is under them! That was the only thing that was frustrating me. 8.5/10
STORY is decent, nothing original of course, but it drives you towards the end, because you will want to know what the hell is happening here (or ... well, THERE). The main character, William Carter, is and old school badass agent with some serious issues from the past, but when the ♥♥♥♥ needs to be done, he is called for duty.  I do not want to spoil anything, so let´s just say that story is kinda mass-effectish". 7/10

FINAL VERDICT
I enjoyed this game very much

reviewText: Despite what the professional reviewers may say about this game, it is a solid third-person shooter. The game mechanics borrow heavily from Mass Effect 1, since you can give orders to squad mates, use alien powers such as lift or summon a friendly blob, and talk to NPC's between missions. Even the dialogue uses the multiple answer wheel from the game. The story is deserving of the XCOM title, contrary to what others may say. I'm not an XCOM elitest, so the fact that this game wasn't an RTS didn't bother me. Enemy Unknown was a great game, and to me The Bureau can proudly call itself an XCOM game as well. The final act has an interesting twist and the post-finale voiceover has a cool nod to EU. The game is not perfect though. Your squad mates are far from intelligent. Alyx Vance or Elizabeth, they are not. They are not completely useless either. Give them an order and they follow it just fine. The problem is that major baby-sitting is required. There are some graphical issues, such as ties clipping through the characters chest, or textures taking some time to load in. As well, there is a base hub you can walk around in-between missions to explore for documents, but there's not much in it. As I said already, The Bureau is a solid third-person shooter with an interesting story, good voice acting, and amazing looking locales. If it's on sale, give it a buy. As for the DLC, it can probably be left alone. Code breakers is a side mission that takes all of 10-15 minutes, the pistol is just that, a pistol, and Hangar 6 is a horde mode style game type that provides some background information on the game's plot. Overall I give The Bureau a  7/10.

This game was very enjoyable. The setting was great and the story was pretty good, although i didn't care for the choice the main character had to make about 3/4 of the way in.

All in all this game is worth a play through.

reviewText:
I followed the wandering development of The Bureau: Xcom Declassified for a number of years. Patiently I observed as it transitioned from FPS to 3rd person hoping that it would not suffer in it’s long development cycle. I’m sorry to say that despite some rather nice visuals it suffers from serious design bloat. As teams changed, development laboured and it seems as they moved onward they continuing to tack on new fresh ideas. Perhaps this was done to show progression and relevancy for upper management. But it comes across as a series of continuously muddled concepts that were never truly flushed out.

Combat jumps between uninspired to slightly broken. Agents can take shots through some obstacles or take excessive damage sitting flush against walls. The sparks of laserfire can be seen clipping through various barriers and my snipers can shoot through several layers of walls. Grenades are a bit off. The enemies can seem to toss them across the stage while my weak human arms can only lobe a grenade a few feet further than a effective shotgun blast. I bet the enemies can lobe grenades a bit further if they were to throw them towards me. Rather they throw the grenade upwards and vaguely in my direction. I’ve been counting the number of seconds from when a enemy throws a grenade and when it lands on my feet. On average I’m aware of a grenade is on it’s way for 4-6 seconds. Then another 4-5 seconds before it detonation I could be half way across the map before it goes off. Not a very effective weapon, at least for them.

Speaking of ineffective you learn quickly that as your allies are made of paper and the close combat of the shotgun, and alien equivalent shotgun are the most useless weapons in the game and I can not think of a single instance where close combat would be recommend unless you want to kill you allies. But they seem to do that quite well on their own. They are eager to jump into the action early in the game, but while I enjoy their eagerness to prove who can go down in a fight the fastest its recommend you keep them out of harms way until they prove themselves to be useful in a couple of levels.

Although being a powerhouse can be fun overtime the missions are tedious. Pop all skills and target the biggest enemy. Rinse and repeat. It's rare to jump between cover with a few expections during the last few missions. Other than a single boss battle all combat mission play out the same. The variety of enemy types is varied but can nearly all be destroyed with the same tactics again and again. But enough about the combat because that’s the best part of the game. While it’s a bit too easy, too-linear, and mostly uninhabited hot" zones  there are far worse offenders.

In the brilliant 2012 X-Com the time spent at your bunker was filled with activities to improve all your stats build new areas etc...Let’s not dwell too long in comparisons as it’s simply not fair. The return to your bunker goes between serviceable to unbearable. The conversations you have with the members of X:Com are done with dialog trees. Perhaps showing it’s influence from mass effect a bit too much! But the conversations are pointless. Full of false choices or at their best tedium to unlock a extra mission you can’t participate in. The nuggets exploring this area are banal conversations
date: in-active NPC’s & and fetch quests. Most of them can be skipped or simply forgotten. Some of these conversations will lead you to a mini game where you scan an area by holding L (360 controller) where you can see objects that need your attention a-la detective mode. These seem totally optional and only open paths for your extra team mates to go explore and level while you are following the main story.\n\nFrankly I’m having an ok time with it. I don’t want to throw it under the bus

reviewText:
This is a good game in essence but in execution its not. The Bureau is a butchered console port that crashes every 5 meters you travel in game. I have tried multiple solutions such as windowed mode, running it in compatiblity mode and disabling PhysX, none of these things fix the crashes, making the game unplayable. This is the main reason for the negative review.

If not for this issue, I would give the game a yes recommendation for how bad the plot is but for how good the actual gameplay is. Yes there are issues with sqaddies running into crossfires and dying, or not taking cover whilst being shot at but the gunplay works well when you are controlling Carter. Unfortunately, I have not been able to see more then about 15 mins of gameplay as the game constantly crashes for no reason.

Also if you are looking for an XCOM/X-COM game, this is not it. This is its own game. If you want XCOM that does not crash and is an RTS, stick with the original trilogy or the remake of the original X-COM.

reviewText: I wish I would have given The Bureau: XCOM Declassified the time of day a while ago. Having played it now, I can see that I was wrong to judge it based solely on it’s cover. The Bureau is a fantastic game. Once they can figure out how to work A.I. a bit smarter without creating a robotic uprising ending in the near extinction of humanity, games like this will get drastically better. Not having your allies shove their faces into bullets will be a great addition to most games. The cursor thing is still my biggest gripe though. I know you can increase the range of abilities, but that only partially fixes the problem. The cursor movement in this game needed a bit more love. The looks, sounds, and most of the voice acting were all great to experience if you just weren’t ripped back into reality when your cursor wouldn’t do something properly. Having the live action fights and a 3rd person shooter aspect were a nice way to change up the XCOM series. I hope we see a sequel someday.\n\nFull Review: TheVideogameBacklog.com

reviewText:
I tried this game at a friends for a couple of hours, loved it, then bought it. I quickly noticed it isn't worth more than $15 due to one main thing: the intelligence of your teammates. If it weren't for your teammates doing bonehead things often, like instead of, when ordered, relocating to behind a wall they go in front of it and get ♥♥♥♥ing shot down instantly, this game probably would have gotten much higher scores from critics. So far, in only the second mission that I have played, the sound glitched out half way through a mission and I could weirdly only hear a few sound effects and the sound kept doing a static glitch in and out that I have never heard before in a game. Even after restarting the game, the mission was still sound-bugged. Thankfully, the next two missions I did were not. The auto-save function during play is done kinda poorly. Whenever it autosaves, which is often, it does a hard lag-lock stutter for a second. Something else that is very annoying, sometimes my graphics settings revert back to default when I launch and I have to change them back and restart the game.

The Difficulty - There is no middle ground in the difficulty, there are four choices. It's like do I want to play just above noob mode or just below get murdered instantly mode? No medium difficulty is inexcusable in any game. especially this one, and here is why:
Your ♥♥♥♥ing teammate AI is some of the dumbest AI I have ever seen in a game. On the 3rd difficulty, veteran, they just get downed instantly in fights forcing you to go pick them up and then YOU get downed. But you have no choice because if you lose a guy that is a high rank that you have been working on for a long time, he is gone for good. And even if you command them to go to a certain spot, they will still eventually randomly reposition, meaning they stand up and take massive dmg from enemy fire while taking the stupidest route possible to their next cover, ignoring the cover they could be using to get there. But this does not always happen, thankfully. If I had known that when your teammates die they are dead permanently, I would have seriously rethought buying this game. There is nothing on this earth more frustrating than losing something you worked hard for because of the AI being the dumbest AI I have seen in a very long time in a game. Why even have perma-death when it would be stupid to accept it when it is a far superior idea to just reload a checkpoint? The only way to combat this is by setting the difficulty to level 2 out of 4. If you tell your teammate to reposition, they do not always do it intelligently. I told my guy to move to a new spot and assumed he would use the provided cover, which there was plenty of, to work his way to the spot. No. He stood up and ran across the middle of the battlefield, took massive dmg, then was downed at his new spot instantly. Having literally no choice but to run and pick him up so he didn't die and I lose him for good, I ran to pick him up and was also downed because while reviving you are exposed, and it was mission fail, restart at checkpoint.

To be fair, playing on veteran mode is entirely possible, it is just not fun at all because of how the developers decided to make your teammates ♥♥♥♥ing stupid bags of sh-t. And when it is time to gear up before a mission, there is zero point whatsoever in taking more than two seconds to know what backpacks to have your teammates wear since they are stupid as f-ck and will be often taking dmg when they should not be: A PACK THAT REDUCES ALL ENEMY DMG like the Guardian Pack! The fact that they give you the option to give them other packs is a slap in the face when you can/should only choose the one I said. And their skill trees have choices, lol. Again, if you have any brains, you will choose the skills in their trees that are going to best help them survive longer, and if they have none of those, choose skills that aim to help support you in whatever way possible or get a different squad mate.

Besides all of this ignorant programming done by blindfolded starved caged confused monkeys headbutting/jumping on typewriters, the game is actually really fun provided you are playing on squaddie" difficulty and nothing higher

reviewText:
As I wasn't expecting a typical X-COM strategy game, I could really enjoy this third person tactical shooter. It has a great, well-written story, taking place in a very detailed and atmospheric US 60's world. Even though at first the protagonists of the game seemed to be very clyche (the smoking, drinking, I-don't-give-a-♥♥♥♥ anti hero, the I-have-to-do-what-has-to-be-done commander, the ice queen female agent and, oh, don't forget the immigrated Nazi scientist), during the story they appear to be diverse and deep characters, with their own past, problems and motivations. Due to their interactions, the story holds some big surprises during the last third of the game...

Another big plus are the battles: All missions are unique, with scripted events, discoveries, ambushes, some horror atmosphere and a great design. I enjoyed them much more than the unpersonal, repeating missions of X:COM Enemey Within. Nevertheless, this is a subject to your own preferences. You also have to use a lot of tactic in this game, however, the action is much more intense, as your squad is right in the middle, while explosions, bullets and laser beams are flying right around you. The agents have interesting abilities, and even the developing super powers of the main protagonist are logicallay explained during the game.

A lot of people critizise that the research part and the autopsies  are held very simple in the game. Well, you are playing a SENIOR AGENT, not the BASE COMMANDER, so personally I would have wondered if I would have decided what research comes next, which alien we will cut first wide open to look after his bowel and so on. Therefore, you can talk with the scientists in the lab about their progress, watch them testing and developing new weapons (with some hilarious scenes) and interogate an outsider personally, having the chance to build up some sort of personal relationship with him (or you can beat the ♥♥♥♥ out of him).

To make a long story short: If you are looking for another turn-based X:COM strategy game, with all the typical elements of this series, like research, base building, autopsies, and all other base commander's responsibilities, you will not be happy with this game.

But if you want to enjoy the beginning of X:COM through the view of a senior agent, if you are happy to play through an intense and well-written story, if you want to interact with interesting characters and you like action, though tactical battles, and all that in a very authentic 60's setup, you really should give this game a try!

reviewText:
The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a third-person tactical shooter set in the 1960's and allows the player to take control of Agent William Carter, a washed up agent with a haunted past. This game is different to the other entries in the XCOM series in that the game does not play like an RTS game or feature an isometric view, and is instead played as a standard cover shooter with an over the shoulder view. Does this make it a good game? Yes.
While hardcore fans will of XCOM will find this change of formula jarring, I personally found this formula to be a unique technique and a fresh flavour specific to the XCOM series. While the game plays a bit more like Mass Effect this time around (you can pause the game and command your team mates via a command screen, such as ordering them to move or use special abilities, etc) , it still feels like XCOM, as you still have to take strategic care in how you enter combat situations. I liked how you had to be strategic in how you placed your team mates, and how you must constantly adapt to combat as enemies flank you and draw you out of cover. This made for a tense and enjoyable gameplay experience, and is definitely a must on the harder difficulties. Unfortunately, the AI of your squadmates leaves a lot to be desired, and you will definitely get frustrated by their lack of competence.
You will also get frustrated by the generic and often boring characters as well as the lacklustre plotline; this is standard alien-invasion fare, and anyone else looking for a riveting science fiction story will need to look elsewhere. I rarely find moments of the plot interesting, except for the rare dialogue encounters with the aliens themselves, which were a joy to behold. However, none of the other characters offered much in the way of development and voice acting, and I found them bland and uninteresting.
The graphics are quite nice, and lots of love and care have been dedicated to the lighting and detailed environments in the game. Many of the details in this game are quite nice, and this game looks extremely good when cranked up to max settings whilst running on DX11.
In short? The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a unique yet unusual entry in the XCOM franchise, and is a reward to fans of tactical shooters in general. Despite the occassional stumble in gameplay, incompetent team-mate AI and a lacklustre story, The Bureau is a solid game and I recommend it highly despite its flaws. I give this game a 7.5 / 10.

reviewText:
This game combines good third-person shooter with the field strategy elements in the original xcom games. It has a really nice combat system making you think each of your moves before excuting them. While fun for the first half of the game, I quickly got bored because of the repetitive gameplay. It is basically moving to an area, killing a bunch of ailens, and then move to another area, kill more ailens, etc. and finally get the objective. It gets really boring espicially witout the base-management system in the traditional xcom game.

The enemy AI is really good espically if you play on the harder difficulties; however, the friendly AI are really bad. In my play through, my agents got stuck in corners and wouldn't move when I tell them to regroup; they constantly ran into gernades; sometimes stand still for minutes before moving to their assigned location. My most memerable experience was when I got shot down right beside one of my agents. I ordered him to revive me, while the other agent taunts the enemy. But the agent kept on shooting, even after I commanded him several more times to revive me, leading me to die and reload the last checkpoint.

As for the story and the interactions between you and the other characters, it is well made and indepth. The characters are intresting and you can read their files to find out more about them. Each characters have different personalities making it very intresting to talk with them.

In conclusion, the game is repetitive and sometimes frustrating witht he glitchy friendly AI, however the challenging enemy AI and the intresting story made up for it. I would give it a 5/10 if there was a rating system.

reviewText:
NOTE: Reviewer's game difficulty was set to Commander, finishing the game with no deaths.

The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a squad-based third-person tactical shooter not unlike the Mass Effect Series. Although it does not quite reach the heights of Bioware's Magna Opera, it still delivers moments of greatness throughout its 10-hour campaign.
--
CAMPAIGN

The storytelling is well-paced, although some cutscenes can use some work with regards to its fluidity. These cutscenes attempt a more filmic look, but it transitions poorly once control is handed to the player. The characters themselves could have had a more fleshed-out backgroud, but as it stands, most of the them fall under recognizable tropes.

Lore can be found scattered throughout the world, and they greatly contribute to the atmosphere of the game. Of course they don't directly contribute to the game itself, but for players who enjoy getting themselves immersed in such world-building, they are certainly a neat touch. The locations for each level are also highly varied and colorful. Hyper-modern games have a tendency to look really brown or greyish, but The Bureau breaks away from the pack and surprisingly manages to convey a sense of desperation even amid the richness of the color palette. The developers could have certainly put more effort into the battle areas though--an organic and subtle approach would have gone a long way into keeping the player engaged. Boxes and railings suddenly take on a symmetrical form, walls and cars inexplicably appear in positions that don't make much sense except as cover. Still, it is only a minor gripe and it doesn't take away from the presentation of the game.
--
MECHANICS

The gameplay is akin to many third person cover-based shooters. It patterns itself closer to Mass Effect--one button is highly contextualized, from sticking to cover to sprinting, or vaulting objects. It works for the most part, although having individual buttons for different things could have allowed the game to be more precise.

The shooting aspect is enjoyable, and the ability to issue commands to your squad is an exercise of thinking. Running and gunning is not a viable option, especially on higher difficulties. As such, patience and a quick mind is integral to the success of your team. Each encounter is similar to a puzzle begging to be solved: do you distract the enemy with a diversion and plant a mine behind them? Or should you force them to scatter and pick them off one by one? Nothing is binary within a firefight. Everything is dynamic, and it is the player's responsibility to constantly assess and reassess the situation. Friendly AI could definitely use some tuning though (mainly on autonomous cover choices), but it does not detract from the overall usefulness of the squad AI.

RPG aficionados also have some options in tinkering with their squad composition. Differing playstyles can easily be accomodated by the game, with each agent being highly customizable from their perks right down to their equipments , although changeable outfits would have been a welcome inclusion in the game.
--
CONCLUSION

All in all, The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a welcome addition the XCOM franchise. It may not be on the same level as the Mass Effect Series (which it seems to have patterned itself to) but it is definitely an enjoyable game. Critics and naysayers alike have been too quick to dismiss the game without actually paying attention to it, just because of the silly notion that it is NOT XCOM. Well, no ♥♥♥♥, its The Bureau--it's simply its own game within a larger XCOM universe.

reviewText:
This game was kinda confusing in the beginning: Whether I was playing an espionage, zombie killing or an alien invasion game. Well I got it after a few minutes, but anyway I'm going to review about XCOM Declassified.

This game demands some strategic movements from the player. Each agent you take could individually have various focusing abilities and strength. It is your decision which agent will accompany you and how much of a synergy they could bring out. For instance, if you have a sniper, then it could be good to have a mechanic to improve in a bit of defense and additional artillery.

In the beginning it might not be too difficult even without much usage of skills, but it will become more challenging towards the end. Different types of enemies will appear and it is your job to kill enemies as fast as you can, and survive.

Also the choices you make will affect the ending too. Choose wisely!

The scenery is mostly alien tech, which I found interesting and took a few screenshots. Overall it looks beautiful.
I have enjoyed a good amount of time playing XCOM Declassified, so I think it's worth the price I've paid :)

reviewText:
I'm a fan of the XCom franchise, but I went into this one very skeptical due to its more action oriented design than the traditional titles. Once I started play tho I was pleasantly surprised. The game is obviously very visually amazing but they didn't waste all their time on that and leave you with a shallow piece of crap.

The plot is very well written and engaging and better thought out, imo, than the one used for XCOM Enemy Unknown. While there is no grand strategy element to this, the way you handle your 3 man teams has an excellent amount of tactical play to it. The time dilation used keeps the game going but allows you a certain level of precision for giving orders and using special abilities.

Despite the fact that the overall plot will remain the same, there are numerous choices within the game that will affect how events play out. This gives the game a surprising amount of replay value. I also recommend the Hangar 6 DLC which gives even more life to the game and fleshes out the story even more.

reviewText:
First Impressions:

Impressive amount of depth for a squad-based third person shooter - clearly built with a lot of love.

It's the first in what hopefully becomes a very successful spin-off of the much beloved XCOM series.  In traditional XCOM, the entire game is played from a tactical point of view, giving orders to a unit of soldiers fighting against the alien menace. In the Bureau, you play as the commander of a squad, participating in combat as well as using a pretty unique Battle Focus" system to issue orders.

The actual issuing of orders is a bit tricky at times - the soldiers don't always do what you want them to do.  However
date: once you get used to the goofy little nuances
recommended: it easily becomes the most compelling and interesting feature of the game.\n\nA lot of people will tell you that this game isn't XCOM or it's some kind of abomination.  Those people are known as idiots.  This game was always intended to be a spinoff - If you're looking for something truer to the original experience
hoursPlayed: you're looking for XCOM: Enemy Unknown.  It has all the flavor and intrigue of XCOM
voteText: but again
helpfulPercent: it's a spinoff - it has a non-traditional gameplay style.\n\nIt's my opinion that this is good. Others can disagree
votesHelpful: but I don't actually care what they think."

reviewText:
What to say..  If you're looking for a turn based experiance of squad VS. mobs of alien hoards you may have come to the wrong game but...

I really enjoyed The Bureau.  It might not be in the traditional spirit of previous Xcom games.. and feels like a mashup between Mass Effect and Gears Of Wars, but it really seemed to deliver.

The Burearu is a game about the struggle of a classy detective and his squadmates against inhuman odds.  The action is live and every order you make counts.  The combat is full of tension and adrenaline, and I enjoyed every minute of it.  If you're a fan of the Xcom lore and don't mind a deviation in gameplay style I'd definately recommend XCOM declassified.

If you are in it for the turn based mechanic however, I plead with you to wait for the next xcom title, as the active third person shooter gameplay may not be up your alley. It is quite polished and I can not think of a single complaint to make, but it does not follow the gameplay tradition of the games of the series that game before it.

That said, I have played all of The Bureau main campaign before writing this review (save for the post final boss content) and am 100% satisfied with the game save that I wish it was a little longer.

reviewText: Despite my initial hesitance toward the change of style for this game (from its initial showings), it's a surprisingly competent tactical TPS set in the early XCOM universe. It begins as your standard cover based shooter, but once you've moved onto the first main operation, opens up quite a bit as you unlock new abilities for both yourself and your squad mates. In some early game operations you can still sit behind cover for most firefights and take potshots at enemies, but a) that's *really* boring and b) doesn't work on harder difficulties (I played on hard
date: I guess, but there's still one difficulty above that).\n\nIn many of the later operations, enemies will flank your position, throw grenades to flush you out, or rush you head on with cloaked enemies and mutons with jetpacks. The fun (and frustration) comes from flanking enemies with your squad mates (giving you a damage bonus) and using their abilites to funnel enemies into your line of fire, but I found myself in many battles to constantly be waiting for my heal ability to be on cooldown, or running around reviving my squad who have run out of cover for no reason. The game doesn't seemingly give you the ability to keep" your squad in certain positions; sure
hoursPlayed: but it always felt that once I moved far enough away (far enough being not very far) they would move out of cover and subsequently die
voteText: forcing me to take a ton of damage to revive them and waste my heal ability on myself.\n\nAll that aside (and despite some minor quirks I had with the controls) I enjoyed my time with it. It's no XCOM UFO Defense or even Enemy Unknown for that matter
helpfulPercent: but it offers enough challenge and tactical options to be worth one playthrough."
