reviewText:
The Bureau is a game with a lot of baggage. It was first announced as the way 2K was choosing to revive the X-Com franchise, a decision that was understandably received with a considerable amount of bafflement and ill will. Yes, people wanted a modern X-Com, but that meant a turn-based strategy game of research and tactical battles, not some shooter. The fact that, as shooters went, it actually looked pretty interesting and ambitious was largely lost in the outpouring of disgust over the brand they chose to attach to it. Then it faded from view, and in the meantime Firaxis' much more faithful franchise reboot was announced and even released before The Bureau came back into view, now branded with that name. Unfortunately, it was clear that some ambition had been lost along the way, and its development was revealed to have been troubled and fraught with drama. It came out to a general wave of indifference, and was promptly dismissed.

Having now completed it, I believe this indifference was unwarranted. It's true that it's not X-Com. And the game originally previewed might well have been a better one. But the end result is a rather enjoyable melding of squad tactics and quality shooting, with light RPG elements; attached to a fairly compelling scenario of apocalyptic alien assault. Both major and side missions have interesting things to show you, and reveal more about the nature and motivations of your foe, and there's even a pretty spiffy late game twist. And I really appreciated the sequences where you walk around the XCOM base between missions. The various people you can converse with are all fairly well drawn as characters, if not horribly deep, and there are additional story tidbits and several layers of ambient conversations and announcements throughout, changing after every major mission.

Mind you, it's not perfect, either. The notion that all of this is a secret that's been covered up for decades is, well, just not plausible at all, especially when the rest of the time they want to give you a sense of the appalling scale of events. Some of the conversations are a little prone to repetition. And there are some disappointing technical issues, some of which seem to be specific to AMD cards from what I've read, but others seem more generally problematic. I had severe framerate issues with either PhysX setting on and active (i.e. if I was around PhysXed cloth or effects), and on settings above Medium (at least in the DirectX 11 client), the shadows were prone to very distracting and glitchy flickering. I've also read some people have had issues with crashes, although I personally did not experience these.

The technical issues were pretty easy to work around, and if you're prepared to quietly ignore the premise that any of the game's events are covert, that's not the biggest deal in the world either. So I don't feel either of these things should put you off The Bureau. I quite enjoyed myself all the way to the end, and I would definitely recommend it.

reviewText:
First off let me say I know what the X-COM games are like but this is the first one I have really played and I have to say I loved every bit of it.  Everything was great and I go into details about certain things.

The game takes place, I believe, before Enemy Unknown, but either way you don't have to played and or beat it to get the story for this.  You fight aliens for the X-COM unit, the game is third person and while this is not a game where you can just run and gun I did not have a lot of trouble, I played on Easy though because its the first ever X-COM game I have played.  I can see how it will be a lot harder on higher difficulites.

The game looks great too, just for reference I only ran the DX11 version of the game, so I have no idea if the graphics are any different on whatever the normal setting is.  I also used controller support instead of mouse and keyboard.  There are a decent amount of side things to do while in your base and handling several Agents is fun too.  You can send teams out to some missions to get some kind of reward, I never lost a person while doing them but I reached or went above the threat number for the mission.  There are also side opperations you can do too.

The story is very good and has some really good twists in it, and let me say, because I missed one, always explore the base and do all the side investigations if you want all the rewards and side missions from them.  I beat the game in about 12 hours so it is not very long game, but longer than most third person games I have played and I plan to get the DLC missions to play at some point in the future.
Also I ran across no bugs, or crashes when I played the game.
4/5

reviewText: Honestly, it a solid game. Sure there are some things that are off in this game, such as the enemies being bullet sponges, the exclusion of a jump button, and how the abilities interfere chronologically with the story, but overall the gunplay is solid and the strategical squad commands feel like XCOM at it's simplist core. However, your squad AI doesn't always listen to you and they usually end up in the enemy's line of sight. Music is repetative, but fitting. The visuals are fantastic. It has a vibrant cartoony feel that's very Bioshock Infinitesque. Overall, even though the 3rd person setting is a weird departure from the traditional Turn Based gameplay, it still holds up with the XCOM name. 2012's Enemy Unknown is far better than this, but if you enjoy games like Mass Effect, then you should get this. 7/10

reviewText:
Having played XCOM: Enemy Unknown, I must say The Bureau is an entirely different experience altogether. Unlike Enemy Unknown, the Bureau is more like a rewritten story of how XCOM came about. Despite many reviews criticising it for being too rigid and not really an enjoyable experience, I feel otherwise.

In my humble opinion, The Bureau storyline was splendidly written. Never once did I feel a sense of boredom. The gameplay can be cruel too, one wrong move and bam your created teammate/AI dies. Perhaps most people won't feel the lost but for me it did. When my AI died in one of the later missions I felt the full brunt of the impact, as I had to resort to using one of my lower level-ed AI in his stead. However that gives the game realism and in that sense the player have to make each and every decision wisely. On a side note, the gameplay(3rd person FPS) reminds me a lot of GRAW2(Ghost Recon Advanced Warfighter 2).

As for replay value, it really depends on individuals. I probably would give the game another go and try out different classes but at the same time maybe not. Please pardon me for sidetracking, but I couldn't finish Bioshock Infinite, although it was spectacular I felt that it was overhyped, and not really my type of game whereas Dishonored had me engaged. Therefore as I said it depends on individuals! Just to give anyone reading this a hint: THERE WOULD BE A PLOT TWIST :D All in all, I give the Bureau the mighty thumbs up it deserves and would recommend it to anyone that is a fan of FPS!

reviewText:
I'm just going to clerify this now. I love the original XCOM games. The ones that were hard as hell, and made everything into a exceedingly one sided game of Russian Roulette.

That being said, I can't honestly recommend The Bureau. While it is an XCOM game, it just lacks the feeling of XCOM. The chance to hit doesn't mean anything like it did in the old games, and as long as you have line of sight it's almost always a hit. There is strategy in it, and I do appreciate their attempt to make height and range a factor in battle. But the skills that your units gain from combat make it too easy to bulldoze through the aliens.

On the other hand, it does have a very interesting story. One that shows history in a stranger light, and almost seems like it came from a tabloid magazine or some conspiracy theorist's mind. It's interesting, but could have been so much more. XCOM is known as a world organization, yet in this game is only shown as a United States one. Yes, there is reasoning for it in the story, but that doesn't mean that you have to limit the game map to just the US. What about Canada? Or Mexico? Maybe Europe or Asia? What happened there? How did they fight? Did they fight?

Maybe thats just me asking too many questions. But there are plot holes that could have been filled. Overall, it is ok. Not good enough for me to recommend it to anyone, but still stable enough to be played and enjoyed by some. Graphicly, it looked nice. Explosions and blood was somewhat realistic, and the details in the aliens was nice. Gameplay wise, it could have been stronger, and less formulated like most 3rd person shooters.

I'd honestly give it a 3/5 rating, with a strong warning to anyone who wants to buy it.

reviewText: The story feels like it was written by a 14 year old who just found out about what conspiracy theories are; the voice acting is at an average AAA level, the gameplay is your standard third person cover shooting, but is dragged down due to enemies being bullet sponges, movement is somewhat fluid, but not nearly as fluid as something like gears of war. The tactical element is close to non-existant; you can send orders to your squad mates, but you'll spend most of your time just sending them back due to them often moving without you ordering them to and placing themselves in bad positions that gets them shot down. Also, the fact that every dying squadmate just comes back, makes death feel unimportant unlike previous XCOM games. Visually it's pretty good looking, but the graphics nor aestetichs will leave a lasting impression on you considering that there are games like Metro: Last Light out there.\n\nIMO it's a ♥♥♥♥ you/10 but at some moments I was almost entertained so there's that.

reviewText: Mass Effect 1: XCOM Declassified the game.  this is how i could best describe it.  excelent cover based 3rd-person tactical game.  while this isn't a traditional top down turn based strategy x-com, i give them credit for at least trying something new.  While this isn't the best 3rd person squad based tactics game out there, its by no means bad either.  if you liked how mass effect played and you like the xcom storyline then this game is a good match for you.  if you're only looking for the traditional xcom experience, you will not like this game.  its a mixed bag of goodies but of course not everyone will like it. reviewText:
It's an XCOM game, alright. At least more than Enforcer ever was.

Battles can get hectic, so staying in cover and ordering your teammates do the work for you is vital. But that's what XCOM is all about: hiding in bushes and commanding people to their death. And every death hurts you deep inside, even if not as much as in Enemy Unknown, but still. You just get fond to your teammates.

Only thing missing are the redshirds you send to suicide runs to flush out stinky aliens from their holes, but two squad mates are enough, as witnessed by many other 3rd Person Shooters. Any more teammates just would make the battles even more cluttered.

Was it worth it? To me: yes!  With a mindblowing scifi plot, where gameplay mechanics were well integrated, and 60's themed environments I can recommend it. Last level especially is something beautiful.

reviewText: It's like Mad Men, but with.. aliens?
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
First things first.
1, Forget about metascore (currently around 6.5), this game is far better than this.
2, This is not a strategy, it´s a tactical TPS.
3, I am not hardcore XCOM fan (I played only XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Within - and I love those games)
4, I´m fat and I have a bad haircut. Deal with it.

When The Bureau was announced, I was super excited, because the trailer looked amazing, the premise of alien attack situated in the USA in 60s as FPS with some tactical elements seemed great. We all know that there were some problems during the development and that the game was reworked many times. That sounds like a bad thing ( *cough* Colonial Marines *cough*), eh? Well it is NOT.
GRAPHICS are stunning (I played on DX11). Seriously, I´ve never seen a game with better lightning of a scene. I often caught myself just staring on the scene and taking screenshots, because it simply looked beautiful. It required a decent hardware though on HIGH setting, I played on MID-HIGH. No cons. 10/10
GAMEPLAY The main part of the game are fights of course. Ever played Mass Effect? Imagine that, but better ( HERESY!). Far better. Yea, I said that. Here is the thing. On a mission, you can take two agents with you. Each agent can have one of four classes (Engineer, Recon, Commando, Support). I´ve ended up using Support and Engineer (Engineer can put a turret or mines on the battlefield, Support creates a shield, can give a stims to the whole team etc). You have a special class, called Agent. You can Heal, do some kind telekinetics, put a drone on a battlefield, and at level 9 out 10, you can use a mind control ( yea, those are not the agents you are looking for). You can give the commands to your team via command list (imagine KOTOR). When you press SPACE key, it will put you in slow motion mod and you have lot of time to think (not that much though, the game is not completely freezed). At the beginning of the game you will not use it that much, but when the ♥♥♥♥ hit the fan (that means when Sectopod or Muton introduce themselves on a scene), you will beg for mercy and most of the time, you will end up planning what to do, where to put your agents, and wondering how the ♥♥♥♥ you are supposed to kill them all. This game is challenging on a first walkthrough. Not THAT hard, but decently hard.
The weaponry of this game is not too big ( Colt 1911, M14, Springfield,  then laser and plasma variations, grenades), but nothing to complain, the main power of this game is within the abilities/perks of the team).
One thing bothered me though. A.I. of the squadmates. There are not dumb, not really, but they are not shooting much when no order is given to them, and they do not roll out when a ♥♥♥♥ing grenade is under them! That was the only thing that was frustrating me. 8.5/10
STORY is decent, nothing original of course, but it drives you towards the end, because you will want to know what the hell is happening here (or ... well, THERE). The main character, William Carter, is and old school badass agent with some serious issues from the past, but when the ♥♥♥♥ needs to be done, he is called for duty.  I do not want to spoil anything, so let´s just say that story is kinda mass-effectish". 7/10

FINAL VERDICT
I enjoyed this game very much
hoursPlayed: but interesting story. Together with awesome graphics and gameplay
voteText: I must say to the world - ♥♥♥♥ METACRITICS. I do regret that I didn´t bought this game at launch but on Summer Sale
helpfulPercent: and it´s shame that there will be no sequel ( the game was not succesful in terms of sales)\n9/10"

reviewText: Despite what the professional reviewers may say about this game, it is a solid third-person shooter. The game mechanics borrow heavily from Mass Effect 1, since you can give orders to squad mates, use alien powers such as lift or summon a friendly blob, and talk to NPC's between missions. Even the dialogue uses the multiple answer wheel from the game. The story is deserving of the XCOM title, contrary to what others may say. I'm not an XCOM elitest, so the fact that this game wasn't an RTS didn't bother me. Enemy Unknown was a great game, and to me The Bureau can proudly call itself an XCOM game as well. The final act has an interesting twist and the post-finale voiceover has a cool nod to EU. The game is not perfect though. Your squad mates are far from intelligent. Alyx Vance or Elizabeth, they are not. They are not completely useless either. Give them an order and they follow it just fine. The problem is that major baby-sitting is required. There are some graphical issues, such as ties clipping through the characters chest, or textures taking some time to load in. As well, there is a base hub you can walk around in-between missions to explore for documents, but there's not much in it. As I said already, The Bureau is a solid third-person shooter with an interesting story, good voice acting, and amazing looking locales. If it's on sale, give it a buy. As for the DLC, it can probably be left alone. Code breakers is a side mission that takes all of 10-15 minutes, the pistol is just that, a pistol, and Hangar 6 is a horde mode style game type that provides some background information on the game's plot. Overall I give The Bureau a  7/10.

reviewText:
This game was very enjoyable. The setting was great and the story was pretty good, although i didn't care for the choice the main character had to make about 3/4 of the way in.

It is a cover based shooter but your squad relies solely on you directly giving them commands and cannot accomplish anything without your input. If you are able to quickly react to heavy enemy fire and give orders and utilize your own abilities, then you will enjoy the gameplay. The squad leader has the ability to slow down time during combat to issue commands, but the enemy will still be firing on you as this happens.

All in all this game is worth a play through.

reviewText: Considering what I'd previously heard about this game, I expected that paying $4 for it would still be too much. Turns out, I was incorrect on that. reviewText:
I played through on Veteran setting and the game was extremely frustrating early on.  Your squadmates are idiots and seem to  die often early on; plus you lack any abilities that will really help you early on.

Towards mid-game everything becomes MUCH more fun.  I ended up playing with a Tank/Sniper combo that allowed me to just wreck alien enemies.

All said and done, I would definitely recommend this game, but the beginning is rather frustrating.  If you like Mass Effect, I suggest you give this game a playthrough, not as good, but likable in it's own way, especially if you are also a fan of XCOM.

reviewText:
I followed the wandering development of The Bureau: Xcom Declassified for a number of years. Patiently I observed as it transitioned from FPS to 3rd person hoping that it would not suffer in it’s long development cycle. I’m sorry to say that despite some rather nice visuals it suffers from serious design bloat. As teams changed, development laboured and it seems as they moved onward they continuing to tack on new fresh ideas. Perhaps this was done to show progression and relevancy for upper management. But it comes across as a series of continuously muddled concepts that were never truly flushed out.

Combat jumps between uninspired to slightly broken. Agents can take shots through some obstacles or take excessive damage sitting flush against walls. The sparks of laserfire can be seen clipping through various barriers and my snipers can shoot through several layers of walls. Grenades are a bit off. The enemies can seem to toss them across the stage while my weak human arms can only lobe a grenade a few feet further than a effective shotgun blast. I bet the enemies can lobe grenades a bit further if they were to throw them towards me. Rather they throw the grenade upwards and vaguely in my direction. I’ve been counting the number of seconds from when a enemy throws a grenade and when it lands on my feet. On average I’m aware of a grenade is on it’s way for 4-6 seconds. Then another 4-5 seconds before it detonation I could be half way across the map before it goes off. Not a very effective weapon, at least for them.

Speaking of ineffective you learn quickly that as your allies are made of paper and the close combat of the shotgun, and alien equivalent shotgun are the most useless weapons in the game and I can not think of a single instance where close combat would be recommend unless you want to kill you allies. But they seem to do that quite well on their own. They are eager to jump into the action early in the game, but while I enjoy their eagerness to prove who can go down in a fight the fastest its recommend you keep them out of harms way until they prove themselves to be useful in a couple of levels.

Although being a powerhouse can be fun overtime the missions are tedious. Pop all skills and target the biggest enemy. Rinse and repeat. It's rare to jump between cover with a few expections during the last few missions. Other than a single boss battle all combat mission play out the same. The variety of enemy types is varied but can nearly all be destroyed with the same tactics again and again. But enough about the combat because that’s the best part of the game. While it’s a bit too easy, too-linear, and mostly uninhabited hot" zones  there are far worse offenders.

In the brilliant 2012 X-Com the time spent at your bunker was filled with activities to improve all your stats build new areas etc...Let’s not dwell too long in comparisons as it’s simply not fair. The return to your bunker goes between serviceable to unbearable. The conversations you have with the members of X:Com are done with dialog trees. Perhaps showing it’s influence from mass effect a bit too much! But the conversations are pointless. Full of false choices or at their best tedium to unlock a extra mission you can’t participate in. The nuggets exploring this area are banal conversations
date: in-active NPC’s & and fetch quests. Most of them can be skipped or simply forgotten. Some of these conversations will lead you to a mini game where you scan an area by holding L (360 controller) where you can see objects that need your attention a-la detective mode. These seem totally optional and only open paths for your extra team mates to go explore and level while you are following the main story.\n\nFrankly I’m having an ok time with it. I don’t want to throw it under the bus
recommended: it’s pretty boring outside of combat and after you get a few levels on yourself and your team mates it simply becomes a slaughter fest where nothing can harm you. I highly doubt we will hear about this franchise again and it’s a shame because at it’s best you can see what it could've been. It takes too much inspiration from better games and does not improve on them. It's a project that just needed to get out the door. Too much time
hoursPlayed: money and engery was spent re-hashing a collection of mechanices
voteText: techniques
helpfulPercent: artistic approaches over year to simply have them all go to waste. At least it was released and we'll never have to wonder

reviewText:
The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a third-person tactical shooter set in the 1960's and allows the player to take control of Agent William Carter, a washed up agent with a haunted past. This game is different to the other entries in the XCOM series in that the game does not play like an RTS game or feature an isometric view, and is instead played as a standard cover shooter with an over the shoulder view. Does this make it a good game? Yes.
While hardcore fans will of XCOM will find this change of formula jarring, I personally found this formula to be a unique technique and a fresh flavour specific to the XCOM series. While the game plays a bit more like Mass Effect this time around (you can pause the game and command your team mates via a command screen, such as ordering them to move or use special abilities, etc) , it still feels like XCOM, as you still have to take strategic care in how you enter combat situations. I liked how you had to be strategic in how you placed your team mates, and how you must constantly adapt to combat as enemies flank you and draw you out of cover. This made for a tense and enjoyable gameplay experience, and is definitely a must on the harder difficulties. Unfortunately, the AI of your squadmates leaves a lot to be desired, and you will definitely get frustrated by their lack of competence.
You will also get frustrated by the generic and often boring characters as well as the lacklustre plotline; this is standard alien-invasion fare, and anyone else looking for a riveting science fiction story will need to look elsewhere. I rarely find moments of the plot interesting, except for the rare dialogue encounters with the aliens themselves, which were a joy to behold. However, none of the other characters offered much in the way of development and voice acting, and I found them bland and uninteresting.
The graphics are quite nice, and lots of love and care have been dedicated to the lighting and detailed environments in the game. Many of the details in this game are quite nice, and this game looks extremely good when cranked up to max settings whilst running on DX11.
In short? The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a unique yet unusual entry in the XCOM franchise, and is a reward to fans of tactical shooters in general. Despite the occassional stumble in gameplay, incompetent team-mate AI and a lacklustre story, The Bureau is a solid game and I recommend it highly despite its flaws. I give this game a 7.5 / 10.

reviewText:
First off let me say I know what the X-COM games are like but this is the first one I have really played and I have to say I loved every bit of it.  Everything was great and I go into details about certain things.

The game takes place, I believe, before Enemy Unknown, but either way you don't have to played and or beat it to get the story for this.  You fight aliens for the X-COM unit, the game is third person and while this is not a game where you can just run and gun I did not have a lot of trouble, I played on Easy though because its the first ever X-COM game I have played.  I can see how it will be a lot harder on higher difficulites.

The game looks great too, just for reference I only ran the DX11 version of the game, so I have no idea if the graphics are any different on whatever the normal setting is.  I also used controller support instead of mouse and keyboard.  There are a decent amount of side things to do while in your base and handling several Agents is fun too.  You can send teams out to some missions to get some kind of reward, I never lost a person while doing them but I reached or went above the threat number for the mission.  There are also side opperations you can do too.

The story is very good and has some really good twists in it, and let me say, because I missed one, always explore the base and do all the side investigations if you want all the rewards and side missions from them.  I beat the game in about 12 hours so it is not very long game, but longer than most third person games I have played and I plan to get the DLC missions to play at some point in the future.
Also I ran across no bugs, or crashes when I played the game.
4/5

reviewText: Honestly, it a solid game. Sure there are some things that are off in this game, such as the enemies being bullet sponges, the exclusion of a jump button, and how the abilities interfere chronologically with the story, but overall the gunplay is solid and the strategical squad commands feel like XCOM at it's simplist core. However, your squad AI doesn't always listen to you and they usually end up in the enemy's line of sight. Music is repetative, but fitting. The visuals are fantastic. It has a vibrant cartoony feel that's very Bioshock Infinitesque. Overall, even though the 3rd person setting is a weird departure from the traditional Turn Based gameplay, it still holds up with the XCOM name. 2012's Enemy Unknown is far better than this, but if you enjoy games like Mass Effect, then you should get this. 7/10

reviewText: the meta score for the game in the store is misleading.  I came into this not knowing what to expect, and am pleasently suprised.  The campaign,(so far), is long missions, about 20 to 30 minutes minimum, and have the majority of that time taken up with combat.  The cover system is nice, teling you if you are commanding your squad to safety or target practice for the enemy.  The AI is not always the smartest for friendlies, but enemies are challenging enough, even on a lower difficulty.  Gunplay is solid and the weapons feel appropriate for how they are used, and new ones pop up frequently enough to keep the action mixed.  Powers among the team are decent, depening on who you decide to bring along.  all in all, a solid game that offers an interesting, albeit somewhat ripped off, alien invasion story set in a nifty early 60's atmosphere

reviewText:
Gameplay - Mass Effect 2 clone. However, I felt it was more crucial to employ squadmember skills during battle than what i was used to in Mass Effect 2 on similar difficult. This is a good thing. (Saying Mass Effect 2 since i haven't yet completed 3)

Difficulty - I played it on the second hardest difficulty and although the learning curve was alright, it started out alot tougher than expected. Expect a hard time against your first Muton unless you're above average in tactics and how you pick your squads.

Graphics - The graphics are alright. I'm not really that good on judging them though since i put gameplay first. Everything reminded me again of Mass Effect 2, though the the backdrop is the early 60s in the US. The main character animation during story dialogues was repetive though.

Story - I expected a lot more shallow story from the get go. It really suprised me how it twists and turns later on. The side missions were quite a bit lacking though, and again something picked up from the Mass Effect franchise. I didn't really feel there were any rewards to them either.

Sound - Music and sound effects were solid. Voice acting above average and in style with what i feel is true for the 60s. There are also quite a few references to early 60s rock music.

The Bad - Although i encountered no gamebreaking bugs, there are a few annoying ones. Like dialogue looping after the sequence is finished, items that have been checked will glow again after a side mission if you have tips on in options and a few glitchy things now and then.

Bottom line - Anyone with interest in 3rd person action, bioshock rpgs or the Xcom franchise should find value here. I really enjoyed it while not expecting it to be anything more than a twitchy, corridor, action game.

reviewText: Not quite in the same style as XCom: Enemy Unknown, this XCom title takes on a more first person/squad approach.  It's playstyle is a mix between real time and turn based.  To compare it to the original 1990s XCom series, this game's combat system mirrors the attempts at real time integration with turn based strategy which was attempted in the XCom Apocolypse game.\n\nIf you're looking for a game similar to XCom Enemy Unknown, this is likely NOT the game for you.  I recommend the DLC of Enemy Within.  If you're looking for a stand-alone, good game, in the XCom universe, that's a mix between FPS, TBS, and RTS, pick up this title.

reviewText:
Heyyo,

Sadly? The AI ruins what could have been a fun Tactical Squad-Based Third-Person Shooter... Which is too bad since the squad AI can actually kill enemies unlike most other squad-based games as of late so they actually contribute to combat... but at the same time? They do detract by being idiots whom if you don't give move orders will usually stick too close to the player and not run from grenades which enemies use quite a bit...

Now that I've mentioned the major weakness of the game? I'll talk about the strength which is the visuals... and wow are they good! Just look at the screenshots even. The Art, 3D modeling and mapping department definitely did their job on this game. The use of Unreal Engine 3 shines with Direct3D 11 goodness to show off the visuals of the game. The only thing that could have made this game better is better Anti-Aliasing.. I have the ingame Anti-Aliasing set to High" which is the highest setting yet there's still quite a lot of pixelation. My guess is they used FXAA which doesn't compare to proper Multisampling Anti-Aliasing of times past.

Voice acting is also pretty good. Varied cast and decent attention to detail helps add to the game as I felt like the voice actors actually game a damn about the lines they were reading.

The storyline is also pretty decent about how the aliens invaded and how you're fighting to gain their technology to combat them with and that makes this game feel like a good spin off of X-COM... and it would have been if the damn AI wasn't so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Whomever worked on the AI coding of this game sadly let down the rest of the team since this is a singleplayer game thus AI is extremely important... maybe they needed more time or more staff dedicated to making the AI better? Either way

reviewText:
The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is the prequel to the much loved and well received XCOM: Unknown and XCOM: Enemy Within.
It is set in 1960s America during a massive alien invasion that has swept through the planet annihilating any resistance with very advanced technology and sheer numbers. You play as Agent Carter, an anti-hero with a dark past as he recruited by a shadowy general - with more secrets than him - into the top secret XCOM programme. From there Carter and his squad launch a desperate guerilla war against the invaders.

XCOM Declassified utilises a third-person perspective with standard controls but differentiates when it allows you to lead a squad tactically and thoroughly - much like XCOM: Enemy Unknown.
But that, and the lore, are where the similarities end.
This game is demanding and requires tactical awareness at all times, it is not turn based and you must rely on checkpoints (which I personally don't like).
It gives you a massive degree of control over the battlefield and (with the ability to choose your character lines) parts of the - very engaging - storyline.
The commands are difficult to learn but once you've got it, it opens up a world of opportunities.
That method didn't work? Make him do that while he flanks and you provide cover.

As for graphics, they're typical and reminiscent of ye-olde times (okay, 50 years ago) but that's not a bad thing. The sound quality is good with an original dynamic soundtrack.
I've had no problems with my low-end rig so I expect it to be a good edition to your library.

I recommend this game for quick, tactical thinkers. Anyone expecting an average TPS will be sorely disappointed.

reviewText:
Overall it is alright; combat, movement is clunky sorta similar to mass effect. Story on its own was alright.

There are three camps for this game:

1) Expected something like the past XCOM games and expected something different than what it is. Which influenced their opinion on it. Their opinion would become worst for any reason if they pre-ordered the game.

2) Didn't expect anything, pre-ordered the game or bought the game at retail.

3) Bought the game on a discount or a pack.

I'm apart of the third group and I rather enjoyed the game. If you take the storyline as having light elements from XCOM but has nothing to do with the rest of them, this is how I enjoyed the game. This game suffers from 'different color jimmys' ending(s). Overall it reminds me of a watered down Mass Effect.

I would recommend this game if you go in treating it as it has nothing to do with the other XCOM games and liked Mass Effect to some degree. Make sure you get it on a discount, unsure if I would recommend it without a discount or in a bundle.

reviewText:
Not sure why this game is so hated. It isn't exactly groundbreaking, but it was certainly fun.

Pros
-Mechanics are fairly easy to figure out
-Enemies are varied and enjoyable to fight
-Missions aren't terribly difficult, but there are some nasty (and fun!) fights that require some thinking and planning to win
-Storyline is a bit of a mystery until later game, but the wait was worth the pay off, imho
-If you are an avid XCOM fan like me, this game is a solid shooter entry into our beloved franchise

Cons
-Storyline is somewhat short, especially for a game that is primarily about the single-player experience
-As far as shooters go, this game is average. The basic shooting mechanics aren't going to win any awards. Doesn't mean they are bad though
-Even a token multiplayer co-op experience would have been nice

reviewText:
Well, I don't understand all the criticism towards this game. I actually genuinely liked it. It isn't the best game I have ever played, but it is really well done.

First of all, the graphics are incredible - character animations, locations design - everything works for the atmosphere. I just wish they added some elements destruction, such as destroying chairs and tables.

The game itself is third-person shooter with covers and tactical pause during which you can give orders to 2 your companions. There are different companion classes, and they have different skills. I constantly used such abilities as put the turret or use critical shot during my playthrough.

The story starts very slow, but closer to the end it runs so fast and is full or different twists and revelations. Sure, it has lots of cliches, but it isn't that bad. There are even three different endings depending on your choice.

All in all, the game is above mediocre thanks to very well done shooting and giving orders mechanics and thanks to great graphics. 7.5/10

reviewText:
If you are a PC player, SAVE YOUR MONEY! The keyboard/mouse controls are the worst I have ever seen in a PC game.  It's like trying to play Beethoven's 5th Symphony on the piano when you've never had a piano lesson. (It can be done but not by many.)

If you don't press the correct sequence of movement keys (W,LShift, LShift, for example) you can't do anything (shoot, move, command others). You just stand there getting killed while you try to figure out what keys you are supposed to press that will unfreeze you. Tool tips and commentary appear in various areas of the screen so you don't reallly know where to look. The tutorial, such as it is, flashes by the screen so quickly you often miss the instructions.

Perhaps it plays better if you connect a game pad to your PC... I don't know because I don't use a game pad.

The story line is decent. For a TPS game the field of view is very limited and, once again, the keyboard controls are an abortion. On top of all of that, even when you do get the right key sequence, the game software is VERY slow to respond (I have an i5 quad core and an Nvidia GTX750, so I don't think it's my gear).

Ambitious project. Major FAIL.  Major disappointment.

reviewText: Despite my initial hesitance toward the change of style for this game (from its initial showings), it's a surprisingly competent tactical TPS set in the early XCOM universe. It begins as your standard cover based shooter, but once you've moved onto the first main operation, opens up quite a bit as you unlock new abilities for both yourself and your squad mates. In some early game operations you can still sit behind cover for most firefights and take potshots at enemies, but a) that's *really* boring and b) doesn't work on harder difficulties (I played on hard
date: I guess, but there's still one difficulty above that).\n\nIn many of the later operations, enemies will flank your position, throw grenades to flush you out, or rush you head on with cloaked enemies and mutons with jetpacks. The fun (and frustration) comes from flanking enemies with your squad mates (giving you a damage bonus) and using their abilites to funnel enemies into your line of fire, but I found myself in many battles to constantly be waiting for my heal ability to be on cooldown, or running around reviving my squad who have run out of cover for no reason. The game doesn't seemingly give you the ability to keep" your squad in certain positions; sure
hoursPlayed: but it always felt that once I moved far enough away (far enough being not very far) they would move out of cover and subsequently die
voteText: forcing me to take a ton of damage to revive them and waste my heal ability on myself.\n\nAll that aside (and despite some minor quirks I had with the controls) I enjoyed my time with it. It's no XCOM UFO Defense or even Enemy Unknown for that matter
helpfulPercent: but it offers enough challenge and tactical options to be worth one playthrough."

reviewText:
The Bureau is a game with a lot of baggage. It was first announced as the way 2K was choosing to revive the X-Com franchise, a decision that was understandably received with a considerable amount of bafflement and ill will. Yes, people wanted a modern X-Com, but that meant a turn-based strategy game of research and tactical battles, not some shooter. The fact that, as shooters went, it actually looked pretty interesting and ambitious was largely lost in the outpouring of disgust over the brand they chose to attach to it. Then it faded from view, and in the meantime Firaxis' much more faithful franchise reboot was announced and even released before The Bureau came back into view, now branded with that name. Unfortunately, it was clear that some ambition had been lost along the way, and its development was revealed to have been troubled and fraught with drama. It came out to a general wave of indifference, and was promptly dismissed.

Having now completed it, I believe this indifference was unwarranted. It's true that it's not X-Com. And the game originally previewed might well have been a better one. But the end result is a rather enjoyable melding of squad tactics and quality shooting, with light RPG elements; attached to a fairly compelling scenario of apocalyptic alien assault. Both major and side missions have interesting things to show you, and reveal more about the nature and motivations of your foe, and there's even a pretty spiffy late game twist. And I really appreciated the sequences where you walk around the XCOM base between missions. The various people you can converse with are all fairly well drawn as characters, if not horribly deep, and there are additional story tidbits and several layers of ambient conversations and announcements throughout, changing after every major mission.

Mind you, it's not perfect, either. The notion that all of this is a secret that's been covered up for decades is, well, just not plausible at all, especially when the rest of the time they want to give you a sense of the appalling scale of events. Some of the conversations are a little prone to repetition. And there are some disappointing technical issues, some of which seem to be specific to AMD cards from what I've read, but others seem more generally problematic. I had severe framerate issues with either PhysX setting on and active (i.e. if I was around PhysXed cloth or effects), and on settings above Medium (at least in the DirectX 11 client), the shadows were prone to very distracting and glitchy flickering. I've also read some people have had issues with crashes, although I personally did not experience these.

The technical issues were pretty easy to work around, and if you're prepared to quietly ignore the premise that any of the game's events are covert, that's not the biggest deal in the world either. So I don't feel either of these things should put you off The Bureau. I quite enjoyed myself all the way to the end, and I would definitely recommend it.

reviewText:
First off let me say I know what the X-COM games are like but this is the first one I have really played and I have to say I loved every bit of it.  Everything was great and I go into details about certain things.

The game takes place, I believe, before Enemy Unknown, but either way you don't have to played and or beat it to get the story for this.  You fight aliens for the X-COM unit, the game is third person and while this is not a game where you can just run and gun I did not have a lot of trouble, I played on Easy though because its the first ever X-COM game I have played.  I can see how it will be a lot harder on higher difficulites.

The game looks great too, just for reference I only ran the DX11 version of the game, so I have no idea if the graphics are any different on whatever the normal setting is.  I also used controller support instead of mouse and keyboard.  There are a decent amount of side things to do while in your base and handling several Agents is fun too.  You can send teams out to some missions to get some kind of reward, I never lost a person while doing them but I reached or went above the threat number for the mission.  There are also side opperations you can do too.

The story is very good and has some really good twists in it, and let me say, because I missed one, always explore the base and do all the side investigations if you want all the rewards and side missions from them.  I beat the game in about 12 hours so it is not very long game, but longer than most third person games I have played and I plan to get the DLC missions to play at some point in the future.
Also I ran across no bugs, or crashes when I played the game.
4/5

reviewText: Honestly, it a solid game. Sure there are some things that are off in this game, such as the enemies being bullet sponges, the exclusion of a jump button, and how the abilities interfere chronologically with the story, but overall the gunplay is solid and the strategical squad commands feel like XCOM at it's simplist core. However, your squad AI doesn't always listen to you and they usually end up in the enemy's line of sight. Music is repetative, but fitting. The visuals are fantastic. It has a vibrant cartoony feel that's very Bioshock Infinitesque. Overall, even though the 3rd person setting is a weird departure from the traditional Turn Based gameplay, it still holds up with the XCOM name. 2012's Enemy Unknown is far better than this, but if you enjoy games like Mass Effect, then you should get this. 7/10
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: the meta score for the game in the store is misleading.  I came into this not knowing what to expect, and am pleasently suprised.  The campaign,(so far), is long missions, about 20 to 30 minutes minimum, and have the majority of that time taken up with combat.  The cover system is nice, teling you if you are commanding your squad to safety or target practice for the enemy.  The AI is not always the smartest for friendlies, but enemies are challenging enough, even on a lower difficulty.  Gunplay is solid and the weapons feel appropriate for how they are used, and new ones pop up frequently enough to keep the action mixed.  Powers among the team are decent, depening on who you decide to bring along.  all in all, a solid game that offers an interesting, albeit somewhat ripped off, alien invasion story set in a nifty early 60's atmosphere
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Gameplay - Mass Effect 2 clone. However, I felt it was more crucial to employ squadmember skills during battle than what i was used to in Mass Effect 2 on similar difficult. This is a good thing. (Saying Mass Effect 2 since i haven't yet completed 3)

Difficulty - I played it on the second hardest difficulty and although the learning curve was alright, it started out alot tougher than expected. Expect a hard time against your first Muton unless you're above average in tactics and how you pick your squads.

Graphics - The graphics are alright. I'm not really that good on judging them though since i put gameplay first. Everything reminded me again of Mass Effect 2, though the the backdrop is the early 60s in the US. The main character animation during story dialogues was repetive though.

Story - I expected a lot more shallow story from the get go. It really suprised me how it twists and turns later on. The side missions were quite a bit lacking though, and again something picked up from the Mass Effect franchise. I didn't really feel there were any rewards to them either.

Sound - Music and sound effects were solid. Voice acting above average and in style with what i feel is true for the 60s. There are also quite a few references to early 60s rock music.

The Bad - Although i encountered no gamebreaking bugs, there are a few annoying ones. Like dialogue looping after the sequence is finished, items that have been checked will glow again after a side mission if you have tips on in options and a few glitchy things now and then.

Bottom line - Anyone with interest in 3rd person action, bioshock rpgs or the Xcom franchise should find value here. I really enjoyed it while not expecting it to be anything more than a twitchy, corridor, action game.

reviewText:
“They won’t know what hit them!”

A very well done adaptation of the X-COM universe on the basis of a TPS.
--

My rating system consists of six categories in descending order of importance:

-	Atmosphere
-	Characters
-	Details
-	Tactical demand
-	Story
-	Combat & Controls

Based on the performance each category will receive one of the following grading:

-	S-Rank: excellent
-	A-Rank: very good
-	B-Rank: solid
-	C-Rank: satisfactory
-	D-Rank: inferior

In case of an S-Rank rating, a game reference will be included in brackets as a token of my respect.
--

Atmosphere: S-Rank

(Oh you know how it is: rampaging alien hordes, bolts of deadly blue plasma, walking death machines from another world. All in a day’s work.)

Characters: A-Rank

Details: S-Rank

(I’ll just say this: if I have to do any evasive maneuver, you’d better hold onto your barf bag with both of your hands.)

Tactical demand: B-Rank

Story: A-Rank

Combat & Controls: S-Rank

(Our own guns aren’t good enough anymore! Now they want some crazy ray-guns.)
--

To conquer all achievements of The Bureau: X-COM Declassified, including the DLC Hangar 6, you will most likely spend around 20 hours. I recommend to start the main campaign on the highest difficulty for ‘Vigilo Confido’ and pick up all other achievements on the way.

Achievement difficulty: 4 of 10

Common:
- Singleplayer [+1]
- DLC [+1]

Special:
- No One Left Behind [+1]
- Vigilo Confido [+1]
--

The Bureau: X-COM Declassified (PC) – TPS (Science-Fiction) – 2013
X-COM: Enemy Unknown (PC) – Turn-based strategy (Science-Fiction) – 2012
X-COM: Enforcer (PC) – TPS (Science-Fiction) – 2001
X-COM: Interceptor (PC) – Space flight simulator (Science-Fiction) – 1998
X-COM: Apocalypse (PC) – Turn-based strategy (Science-Fiction) – 1997
X-COM: Terror from the Deep (PC) – Turn-based strategy (Science-Fiction) – 1995
X-COM: UFO Defense (PC) – Turn-based strategy (Science-Fiction) – 1994

reviewText: Wow, this game is terrible. Shoddy command mechanics (done better by Mass Effect), dull writing, terrible voice acting, samey combat, and more. The game isn't even sure if it's set in the 1950s or the 1960s either - Sherman tanks are serving alongside M14 rifles and many men still wear hats even though they were on their way out. This game deosn't even have the central mechanic that drove your strategy in XCOM - the capture of materials to upgrade your technology. Sometimes you just find equipment lying around and that's that. No live capture mechanics, no research, nothing.\n\nI got this in a Humble Bundle for a fraction of its original price, and I still feel like I paid too much.

reviewText:
The Bureau Xcom Declassified was at first an FPS but then it got scrapped and we got a strategic Third person shooter but will you want to play this game ? In the Bureau you play as William Carter who is a CIA agent who is trying to deliver an artifact to a secret goverment facility but an Alien Invasion happens and its up to you to stop the alien invasion. So how is this game ? Its actually quite good and the reviews for this are way too harsh because its not that bad actually. So first of all if you like mass effect you will simply love this game because theres alot of things similar to Mass Effect. Like the talk wheel and also the combat is quite similar. So now for the good. Amazing story with twist and turns along the way which is a great expierence. The game has a huge hub before the missions and in missions the maps are quite good. The game is quite short maybe 7 to 6 hours long. The game also graphiclly looks great. The combat is fun and simple all the diffrent members are awesome to use in the battlefield. now for the bad. The game might get repetetive after a while and the talking sections might drive you insane sometimes. Some bugs as well. So overall The Bureau: Xcom Declassified is a great game which you should own no matter if youre an Xcom fan or not. I Give The Bureau: Xcom Declassified a 8/10.
Now for the the dlc
First of all we have the Light Plasma Pistol. Its a great weapon which pretty much one shots everything so if you want to breeze through the game get it. I give the Light Plasma Pistol DLC a 8/10
Now for the Codebreakers mission. In the mission you play as Carter who goes to a radio transmission facility after the alien invasion because it went silent. Overall this mission is only 10 minutes long and is not worth the full price only get it on sale i give the Code Breakers Dlc a 4/10
And finnaly we have Hangar 6 R and D. In this dlc pack you play as Nico DaSilva before the events that lead to the main game. In this Dlc you work on a SleepWalker case and you try to relive the memories of the victim to find out whats causing the infection. Overall This dlc is amazingly bad. All you do is fight waves of enemies every level and it gets boring incredibly fast. This Dlc is also quite buggy as well. Only get this dlc on sale For the achievements or to witness how it all began. I give Hangar 6 R and D a 3/10

reviewText: A diamond in the rough. It's a great game and combines Mass Effect-like dialogue/conversations with a third person tactical shooter. You really need to think of everything you do, which is great. The game can get crazy hard sometimes though. All in all it's pretty good, the story is a bit meh in the beginning but it picks up pace fast enough and gets great. Lots of plot twists. Gameplay is good. I don't get why there's so much hate.

The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a science fiction video game in the X-COM series, developed by 2K Marin and released by 2K Games for Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360.

The Bureau is a third-person shooter with an emphasis on squad-based tactics.

after quite a few hrs,,and a stab at the dlcs that added quest and missions(i bought a 2k games bundle that had this in it..so i was only out the 5 bucks for dlc that was on steam sale)...i havent been disapointed...i played..and was entertained...it had story..and reminded me of 60's sci-fi...

my system is nothing special...ran it both in dx9 and dx 11.. ran ok either way...i could see spending 15 bucks on it for steam sale..20 bucks with dlc.. i thought the game was good

how i rate games..i rate on entertainment value...think of a movie for example...
buy a dvd or go to a theater(i prefer theater as an example)....thats using something simple.. $10 dollars for ticket..anything else is extra...so if just basics 10 bucks for 2hrs...to me thats fair for entertainment

was the game more like work or play?...was the game entertaining..did i play more than the hours i would have spent on price if same amount spent in movies(equation example..$50/10=5x2=10hrs)

right now game lists on steam for 20...have i played more than 4 hrs... yep.......was i entertained...yep.......will i play again...maybe...
was the game too hard...nope...was it too easy...nope...
would you recomend it to your friends.....depends on the friend..
gamers yes...
posers(ones that think the game has to look good for it to be good) nope.....

i will give it a 7/10...ive played better and i have played a hell of a lot worse

reviewText: An X-Com game turned into a 1960's based Mass Effect style game, and not in a good way.  It's like ME2 and 3 in that the mainline, gun combat has had too much focus.  Upgrades do not reflect weapon tech level (bullets, laser, then plasma), where as soldiers can, at the start when you only have the starting weapons, have tech for, say, a turret, that uses tech based off of the alien's weapons.  Any and all choices you make (and side missions) will have 0, repeat, 0 impact on the story, as (SPOILIER) X-Com HQ eventually gets attacked and destroyed, killing virtually everyone inside of the base save for some major characters.  The whole idea of having to take alien weapons that haven't been destroyed by operator death using the Venn Brace (the device on Carter's arm in virtually all screen shots)" is just stupid.  The AI isn't the brightest.  The game also lacks a key aspect of X-Com and it's choices: will this work out in the long run.\n\nLets use X-Com: Enemy Unknown for example: You recieve an abduction mission. reviewText:
I don't hate it. I just can't recommend it outside of a sale.

The first I ever heard of this game had me cautiously optimistic. I like XCom.... A lot. Enough to own it, and it's baby brother, and all of their step-siblings. I want to like this game, but I just... can't. It's like your best friends little brother. He should be as cool as your best friend... maybe even better in some regards, but instead he's a slightly annoying hybrid. He has some of the qualities of your buddy, but they're not as refined, and they try way too hard to be relevant (Sorry, Jesse). There are a lot of things in this game that are similar to XCom, but they're watered down, and they don't work quite right.

The concept is fantastic.

The execution is terrible.

The music is good to excellent.

The gameplay is average.

The graphics are decent.

The story is average.

The overall experience feels very rushed.

There are some humorous graphical anomalies that I enjoyed making fun of.

Overall, I would say 5/10. If you can get it for less than 5 bucks, it might be worth your time. Any more than that, and you're wasting your money, but... it's your money, so do with it what you will.

reviewText:
I loved XCOM: Enemy Unknown and Enemy Within and seeing the gameplay for this game, I didn't understand what all the bad rep was about. It looked super appealing to me - it seemed to take the concept of XCOM and wrap it as a first person RTS that looked really neat. Granted, it's story looked like it use some help, but XCOM hasn't been as much about story as much as keeping you entertained and feel accomplished for sweet plan executions.

This game falls short. I've played some offline to a grand total of about 4 hours of gameplay time, and I just can't get behind it. It feels like it had a great idea, but a budget that fell short and an atmosphere that tries to take itself too seriously in a serious story (somehow). It looked great on pen and paper, but there's so many little querks with it, and the controls feels a little stiff.

I mean, if you can get it on one of those sales where it goes for $4 and you're dying to try it, go ahead - you might like it. But honestly, I'm not sure I'll be able to finish this one. Sorry Firaxis Games.

reviewText:
TPS with cover, small-scale squad and rudimentary leveling and gear management mechanics.

+ High levels of detail, quality and polish (it looks, sounds and feels good)
+ Special setting (American 50ths/60ths, with some related music, places designed accordingly and historical remarks and story-related influences)
+ Some interesting characters with a pretty great voice acting and very nice animations/motion capturing
+ Good immersion. Story is nice. Nothing too special, but it has some interesting points. Apparently there are multiple endings, since you can make some critical choices towards the end of the game.
+ Good action. Squad mechanics are nice. You fight in a squad of three. Not overly complex. You can slow down/almost pause the game (battle focus") to examine the field and give orders without sweating: Go into cover
recommended: use special powers to buff/debuff units
hoursPlayed: place mines or turrets
voteText: push enemies around or draw them out of cover and such things. I played on second least difficulty. Combat can get tense at times. Keeping great distance to enemies worked the best. They try to flank you and if you don't pay attention they can harm you badly that way
helpfulPercent: but with battle focus you can avoid these situations fairly well (most enemies are highlighted through walls when using that feature
votesHelpful:
so unless they cloak or teleport around or use other means of faster movement they cannot really sneak up on you too easily).

? I've seen another review criticize the saving system. It's autosave and checkpoints only. I think that's better than having to save yourself. Quicksave and all may encourage some people to attempt mending every mistake they make in combat right away rather than to live through with the consequences (in case of "The Bureau" it means the death of agents - which I did avoid by loading checkpoints). At least that's what I always tend to do in games that give me direct means of saving (which can destroy immersion and challenge). So I think I'm glad how the saving works in this game.

? I wish there was a "stay in cover" order. I sometimes wouldn't want my squad members to expose themselves to the enemy at all. They act somewhat autonomous
votesTotal: if they do their health may get shot down badly. If you choose good cover spots and keep enemies distracted a bit with "minions" or by attracting fire yourself this usually isn't happening too quickly
votesFunny: and when they are very low on health they seem to stay behind cover completely
commentsCount: but I would have prefered taking less chances there in a few situations.\n\n- Controls are irritating a bit. You sprint with SHIFT and go into cover with that as well. Because of that when sprinting close to objects you sometimes go into cover without wanting it. I couldn't find or remember a specific button to pull out of the "Move there" order either (I did improvise with another order). Sprinting itself feels a bit odd or "strict" too. You can only sprint forward
column16: not into diagonal directions
column17:
so you might feel slighty less "mobile" than you'd expect from most other action titles. Moving around the HQ can feel tedious at times because you cannot sprint there.

- Allied A.I. is sometimes making strange moves. In particular when their position is getting overrun or pressed by hostile grenades they would sometimes leap/flee into the direction of the enemies rather than fall back. If you don't call them back a bit as they step into the open exposing themselves they may get hurt badly. But that's about all of "strangeness" I've noticed there.

- Using some abilities/powers can feel a bit tedious. Like if you want to spawn a minion you need to move a cursor from your character to the target location. But that cursor gets blocked by cover objects. Even if you are technically in range of the place you want to spawn your minion at you may not be able to do so (or not as easily). It makes no logical sense because your characters "throw" glowing balls to make stuff spawn
column18: meaning that hip-high cover elements shouldn't be hindering you as much as they sometimes do.\n\n- When things get messy it's sometimes hard to keep track of the skill/power queue. Every squad member has five possible actions (attack

reviewText:
The 60's setting could be so nice, something fresh. The idea of a Squad shooter in XCOM Universe sounded interesting. Bought it in a Sale and now after almost 5h i gave up on it.

The game runs awfully
(Core i5 4500K - 8GB DDR3 RAM - Raedon R9 280X OC)
- In the First Mission you go to a Small town and the first combat ran at 5 - 10 FPS. Try managing your Squad like this -.-
- Shadow and light flickering randomly
- Switching to or from DX11 didn't help at all. get to the townsquare, FPS goes downhill.
- The AI is a Joke for a Squad based game. You are more busy, trying to keep these Idiots alive than actually combating somehting. Even if you manually order them to a cover, they manage to get shot behind that cover in about 10 seconds. because these idiots mostly pop their heads out right when the enemy starts shooting.
In the First 2 Missions i spent more time running between my Squadmates, reviving them, at app. 20 FPS than doing anything other.

TL;DR:
Don't Buy. The cool 60's Flair isn't worth it. The game get's this flair because it's a secret timemachine, warping your PC back to the 60's too.

reviewText: I picked up this game on a steam sale, amid the lackluster reviews. While the general concept of the game was good, the story and the replayability is seriously lacking. I was hoping for a first person take on the popular X-COM games of late. This game was too linear, and too short. Side missions were pointless. Tons of backpack upgrades, but for what? With a team of only 3, you're left with very few choices. If you're an X-COM fan and this is cheap, pick it up. If you're on the fence, wait until the next X-COM game or pick up the OTHER X-COM titles.

reviewText: Having loved the experience of playing XCOM Enemy Unknown exactly for its turn-based characteristic, I was somehow reluctant to try Declassified as a first person shooter version. I generally liked the game for the atmosphere and beautiful graphics, both on Earth and space levels. But the game is too repetitive to be considered a great game. It can be quite challenging, that is true, but it never really captivates you. You do not feel rewarded as in the turn-based version, even though there was a great deal of luck and chance factor involved in the previous game. Still, it is worth your money if you want a beautifully designed shooter.

reviewText:
This is a poorly made pile of garbage that should've never seen release. Even knowing that there's new dlc for it makes me want nothing more than my money back, and some mind bleach so I can forget I ever played it.
Allow me to go into detail as to why:
First and foremost, the game isn't finished. There are graphical and technical glitches all over the place, but not so much as to make the game unplayable. The game also looks like something from 2003, but with an extreme bloom filter and some shiney guns. Remember the whole research and progressing threat thing from xcom? Yeah, that's nowhere to be found in here. You have a series of very linear missions, with some side missions, and a cast of side characters who really are completely underdeveloped. Your soldiers all have one voice. One voice, with no variations, like in xcom EU/EW.
The only condition I'd see as feasible ground for buying this pile of donkey ♥♥♥♥ would be if the developers were holding you ransom, with a gun to your freaking head, and were telling you to buy it.
It took me about 14 hours to beat, so I guess it's kind of a long-ish game, but so's getting your ♥♥♥♥ probed with a spoon. A long game isn't necessarily a good thing, if the game itself is garbage.
The only really good thing I can say is that there's a relatively good twist at the end. It actually comes very close to being the best part of the game for me--but it's at the end, so the best part was when I finally beat this pile of ♥♥♥♥, and uninstalled it.

In short: DO NOT BUY UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES

This game just feels unfinished or like a quick publish for the XCOM series (or continuation of games about killing aliens.)"

reviewText:
เกมส์ยังทำได้ไม่ดีเท่าที่ควรทั้งระบบการเล่น เนื้อเรื่อง ที่ควรได้รับการขัดเกลาเพิ่มเติมให้ดีกว่านี้

1.ระบบการเล่น เป็นแอคชัน+วางแผน ซึ่งทำได้น่าสนใจ(ในตอนแรกที่ดูตัวอย่าง) เราไม่สามารถยืนโชว์พาวรับกระสุนได้ต้องหลบหลังที่กำบังและใช้การวางแผน แต่พอเล่นจริงกลับเจอเรื่องขัดใจอยู่ไม่น้อยไม่ว่าจะเป็นการเลือกสกิลต่างๆ ที่ไม่ลื่นใหล การสั่งให้เพื่อนยิงเป้าหมายหนึ่งแต่กลับไปยิงอีกเป้าหมายหนึ่ง เป็นต้น
1.1 รูปแบบการเล่นจะคล้ายๆ mass effect คือวิ่งๆ คุย แล้วไปสู้ในฉากๆนึง แต่ขอโทษเหอะมันไม่ได้สนุกเหมือน mass effect เลย
กับการวิ่งๆคุยๆเนี่ย ถึงจะมีการตอบคำถามแต่ก็เป็นแค่การถามเรื่องราวต่างๆเพิ่มเติม ไม่ได้มีผลกระทบกับเนื้อเรื่องเลย
1.2 ตัวละครเราพัฒนาความสามารถได้ตื้นเขินมากๆ ไม่หลากมีความหลากหลายเท่าที่ควร
1.3 ศัตรูและอาวุธมีน้อยนิดถึงจะเปลี่ยนรูปร่างไปบ้างแต่วิธีกำจัดก็เหมือนกัน ไม่มีความท้าทาย

2.AI ที่ขาดๆเกิน ฉลาด รู้จะหลบหลังที่กำบัง รู้จักมาโอบล้อมเรา เพิ่มเลือด/เกราะให้เพื่อน แต่ให้ตายเหอะบางทีอยู่ใกล้กันจนจมูกจะแตะกันพี่แกยังไม่เห็นเลย โถๆ

3.บั๊คคคคคคคคค มีอยู่ด่านหนึ่งที่ถ้าคุณไม่เจอบั๊คก็ถือว่าโชคดี แต่หากคุณโชคร้ายเหมือนผมคุณจะไปเจอกับบัคที่ร้ายแรงอย่างการตกฉากตายแบบงงๆ าทงแก้เดียวที่ทำได้คือต้องรีคอมใหม่ ผมลองรีเซตภารกิจ หรือ โหลดออโตเซพก่อนหน้าก็ไม่หาย จนเกือบได้เลิกเล่น

4.เนื้อเรื่องเฉยๆมากไม่ได้น่าติดตามเท่าไรเลย ช่วงต้นเกมส์คือช่วงสนุกสุดแล้วมั้ง

สรุป 6.5/10 แนะนำให้ซื้อตอนมันลดราคานะ ถือว่าเล่นได้เพลินๆถ้าไม่คิดไรมาก

reviewText: Bureau is an interesting departure from the norm for the XCOM series. It sees the hero battling through aliens in a 3rd person semi tactical interface using special powers and abilities to overcome foes through the complementary skills of the squad as a whole. Use a turret to pin enemies down then stealth a squad member around the side to flank and kill them. The graphics are pretty good but it is a bit of a system hog needing a hefty PC to run at full detail levels. Whilst the gameplay is in no ways bad it is not exemplary and plays pretty much like a re-skinned Mass Effect 3 but without as detailed or engrossing a storyline. Worth a budget price or interest from fans of the series.

reviewText:
Coming from a new to the XCOM series perspective, I find it hard to understand why this game got such negative reviews. I'll admit my first reaction to the game was that it was underwhelming and would get repetive fast. However the further I played into the game I was drawn in by the story. I already liked the idea of a 50s era noir setting with aliens and I just wanted to know what would happen next. Sure there are a few areas which could have used a bit more depth, however I feel the story makes up for that.

For example, my agents reached level 5 with much of the game left to go so it was a bit dissappointing to see that they had reached their maximum capability with so much left of the game to complete. That being said, the graphics in this game are really nice for the most part. The AI I can see could have used a bit of work, although I can understand the choices they made to keep them 'dumb'. If all the enemies just rushed you on the hard difficulty there would be no way to defend youself, literally, and the game would be impossible.

Overall, I really enjoyed this game though. The story was gripping, yet a tad dry at times with the 'investigations',
8/10

reviewText:
I bought this game for only $4.99, so my judgement of this game would be quite different from someone who purchased it for $59.99. That being said, the game is good as it is bad. The story starts out pretty good, but by the end, becomes little more than incomprehensible gibberish. The combat is solid enough, and forces you to use cover, but enemies love grenade spam tactics.

To make it worse, the snap-lock cover can become really finicky and stick you to places you rather not be ending your life with a quick dose of lasers and grenades. I like the reliance on abilites, including your squadmates, however, the pitiful AI makes more than half encounters end in fustruation as you are forced to babysit them and manually extract any real use out of them.

DirectX11 API is broken with framerates dipping into the low 20's, and this is on a very powerful rig. The graphics are pretty, nothing exceptional but the variance of American landscapes powered by Unreal 3 is a nice treat to the eyes. The Alien locales, on the other hand, are of the generic shiny grey metallic tile" SCI-FI variety.

The best way to summarize this game is to call it a inferior Mass Effect clone set in 1962. It is by no means a bad game
date: and surely worth $4.99 in entertainment money
recommended: but to expect more from such a quality developer of the Bioshock games
hoursPlayed: you'll only end up dissapointed."

reviewText:
A very interesting game; The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is definitely not your typical video game.  It attempts to bridge third-person shooting with more tactical/strategy elements like a conventional XCOM game.  While many people have more detailed opinions about how WELL this is accomplished, I think the game has a pretty good rapport in trying and getting most of the two things down.  I say this to mean it is possible to just go rambo and kill all the aliens yourself with your team as minimal support.  It is also possible to not really fight and micromanage your team to kill everybody for you.  However, the game is really the best when you can master the two and be able to multitask shooting things and issuing commands for your team to shoot things as well.  I actually enjoyed that about this game very much because it allows me to focus on different enemies while being reassured that my team is putting the hurt on someone else.

However, I think the most difficult part of The Bureau to swallow is the story.  I could talk for ages about its story, but I will try to keep it brief.  The game does not pull its punches in its portrayal of its characters; pretty much all of the characters are morally gray characters - none of them are psychopaths, but each of their motivations make them do evil things.  In that way, the characters are very realistic, they are imperfect people (or aliens) controlled like puppets and thus act out of rage, fear, and sadness.  Most will never get redemption as their thirst for vengeance makes them ignore the suffering of others; a world not unlike our own.

THings I really found quirky about this game is that damn near everybody smokes.  I had heard that those 60s people really liked their deathsticks, but I never thought it was THAT bad.  Also, the agent customization options are pretty cool because all of the agents dress sharply and it gives me a satisfying feeling to see a well-dressed man with a vest and tie blow a Sectoid head off.  Also, it has an interesting take on third person" shooter (if you know what I mean the twist).

In conclusion
date: if you want a purely shoot-em-up or purely tactical game
recommended: then this one is not for you.  However
hoursPlayed: The Bureau is an interesting blacksheep for those who want to give a new hybrid a go
voteText: with a plot that is complex
helpfulPercent: but quite acurate in what we would do if aliens attacked.  And no
votesHelpful: we do not become friends."

reviewText:
All I remember about this game is  hating it just based on the idea of it. I've played every Xcom since the release day of the original UFO Defense, and have logged more time in it over the years than I have spent sleeping and eating combined. I've seen some horrible attempts at shoe-horning IPs into every new hot genre to come to gaming, and they all stunk. So when I saw the previews of Mad Men Vs Giant Oil Spills, I thought it was the dumbest thing yet to happen to a franchise that had been abused like a prisoner of war over the years.

While it is horrible on almost every computer that tries to run it (the framerate will dive so bad, that the audio stutters), the design of the game (think Gears of War without the size 85 boots) is fun. But where this game REALLY steps out and earns its recommendation is the story and it's presentation. If you set your graphics filter to 'film grain' the game really comes to life as a period piece of fiction.

The dialogue is amateurish as many of the characters seem to have an uncanny grasp of modern slang (including the aliens!) and use language and phrases not accurate to the time period, but the story still works on a fundamental level. If you are a die hard XCOM fan who passed on this just out of defiance, you'll find that the only existance of anything XCOM is more along the lines of an easter egg rather than an actual theme. (You hear many references to the SKYRANGER, but when you see it, the few chuckles you get are worth it).

get this game on sale, and play it - you'll enjoy it.

reviewText:
Pros:
- Allows to know the story of XCOM before the events of Enemy Unknown
- Aliens? You get to shoot them

Cons:
- Crappiest ally AI ever, cannot shoot ♥♥♥♥ (most of the time it WON'T shoot anything), gets killed pretty easily too
- You going 3rd person and doing 85% of the work in every single battle since your allies are useless
- Annoying interface
- Crappy graphics
- Glitchy textures and objects
- Crashes (literally stopped me from playing)
- Terribly low res 30 fps cutscenes?
- INCREDIBLY repetitive and EXTREMELY linear battlefield combat experiences
- Generic overused storyline with extremely overused underdog fallen angel hero
- Extremely limited weaponry range
- Nearly 0 technological evolution compared to Enemy Unknown
- Limited movement in Combat on top of generic bland characters

Not going to lie... this game is pretty crappy. I'm having a hard time finding anymore pros to try to balance everything out.

reviewText:
Give it a chance.

XCOM's return to prominence has been an interesting one, originally an FPS with little to do with the original series, it was scrapped, and it's side project, Enemy Unknown, became an unexpected hit.
Following in the wake of it's success is The Bureau, kind of a half way house between the original FPS concept and the popular strategy remake. Many of the original concepts from the scrapped FPS return here, such as the 1950s setting, the 'silicoids' and the investigative themes.
What on the surface looks like a shallow cash-in, is actually a very deep and enjoyable hybrid TPS/RTS game, but in order to really enjoy The Bureau you have to be willing to give it a chance and excuse some of it's shortcomings.
It's story is paint-by-numbers, it's characters are shallow, the levels are linear, it's everything you'd expect from a mediocre shooter, but for those willing to invest in the game, there's a deep and tactical experience to be had, not to mention some genuinely clever plot twists that most people won't see coming.

The Bureau boasts many of the features of a 'true' XCOM game, you'll unlock better equipment as the game progresses, you'll recruit and train soldiers who can die permenantly, and you'll need to be strategic and use your assets creatively in order to win against increasingly grim odds. What sets it apart from the traditional XCOM games is the story driven campaign and the more personal perspective of being a soldier in the field.

It features quite nice graphics at times, and the 50s setting and aesthetic is charming, reminiscent of Bioshock and Fallout. The cover-based shooting is simple but tight, and using the tactical view, which slows time and allows you to issue orders and use skills, is a joy to use, you'll get immense satisfaction from pulling off combos.

For those fans of the XCOM universe, old and new, this is a must have game, and for fans of third person shooters and strategy games, this is a solid addition to your library.

reviewText: When I got this game, I was expecting more of the same as in XCOM: Enemy Unkown., but that was not what I got. What I got instead was a 3rd person shooter. And while this was not as good, it was a lot more fun than I thought it would be. Solid graphics and sound and even better voice acting mixed with fun gameplay and pretty long single player game kept me quite entertained.\nAbout the only real disappointment was the clunky misssion focus where you have your teammates orders. They didn't listen to them very well or kept leaving where I told them to go, but was still a very fun game. Some pretty crazy moments and battles and a pretty solid story as well. If you like 3rd person shooters and liked XCOM: EU, you will probably enjoy this as well.
