reviewText:
This is a poorly made pile of garbage that should've never seen release. Even knowing that there's new dlc for it makes me want nothing more than my money back, and some mind bleach so I can forget I ever played it.
Allow me to go into detail as to why:
First and foremost, the game isn't finished. There are graphical and technical glitches all over the place, but not so much as to make the game unplayable. The game also looks like something from 2003, but with an extreme bloom filter and some shiney guns. Remember the whole research and progressing threat thing from xcom? Yeah, that's nowhere to be found in here. You have a series of very linear missions, with some side missions, and a cast of side characters who really are completely underdeveloped. Your soldiers all have one voice. One voice, with no variations, like in xcom EU/EW.
The only condition I'd see as feasible ground for buying this pile of donkey ♥♥♥♥ would be if the developers were holding you ransom, with a gun to your freaking head, and were telling you to buy it.
It took me about 14 hours to beat, so I guess it's kind of a long-ish game, but so's getting your ♥♥♥♥ probed with a spoon. A long game isn't necessarily a good thing, if the game itself is garbage.
The only really good thing I can say is that there's a relatively good twist at the end. It actually comes very close to being the best part of the game for me--but it's at the end, so the best part was when I finally beat this pile of ♥♥♥♥, and uninstalled it.

In short: DO NOT BUY UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES

reviewText:
Give it a chance.

XCOM's return to prominence has been an interesting one, originally an FPS with little to do with the original series, it was scrapped, and it's side project, Enemy Unknown, became an unexpected hit.
Following in the wake of it's success is The Bureau, kind of a half way house between the original FPS concept and the popular strategy remake. Many of the original concepts from the scrapped FPS return here, such as the 1950s setting, the 'silicoids' and the investigative themes.
What on the surface looks like a shallow cash-in, is actually a very deep and enjoyable hybrid TPS/RTS game, but in order to really enjoy The Bureau you have to be willing to give it a chance and excuse some of it's shortcomings.
It's story is paint-by-numbers, it's characters are shallow, the levels are linear, it's everything you'd expect from a mediocre shooter, but for those willing to invest in the game, there's a deep and tactical experience to be had, not to mention some genuinely clever plot twists that most people won't see coming.

The Bureau boasts many of the features of a 'true' XCOM game, you'll unlock better equipment as the game progresses, you'll recruit and train soldiers who can die permenantly, and you'll need to be strategic and use your assets creatively in order to win against increasingly grim odds. What sets it apart from the traditional XCOM games is the story driven campaign and the more personal perspective of being a soldier in the field.

It features quite nice graphics at times, and the 50s setting and aesthetic is charming, reminiscent of Bioshock and Fallout. The cover-based shooting is simple but tight, and using the tactical view, which slows time and allows you to issue orders and use skills, is a joy to use, you'll get immense satisfaction from pulling off combos.

For those fans of the XCOM universe, old and new, this is a must have game, and for fans of third person shooters and strategy games, this is a solid addition to your library.

They didn't listen to them very well or kept leaving where I told them to go, but was still a very fun game. Some pretty crazy moments and battles and a pretty solid story as well. reviewText:
All I remember about this game is  hating it just based on the idea of it. I've played every Xcom since the release day of the original UFO Defense, and have logged more time in it over the years than I have spent sleeping and eating combined. I've seen some horrible attempts at shoe-horning IPs into every new hot genre to come to gaming, and they all stunk. So when I saw the previews of Mad Men Vs Giant Oil Spills, I thought it was the dumbest thing yet to happen to a franchise that had been abused like a prisoner of war over the years.

While it is horrible on almost every computer that tries to run it (the framerate will dive so bad, that the audio stutters), the design of the game (think Gears of War without the size 85 boots) is fun. But where this game REALLY steps out and earns its recommendation is the story and it's presentation. If you set your graphics filter to 'film grain' the game really comes to life as a period piece of fiction.

The dialogue is amateurish as many of the characters seem to have an uncanny grasp of modern slang (including the aliens!) and use language and phrases not accurate to the time period, but the story still works on a fundamental level. If you are a die hard XCOM fan who passed on this just out of defiance, you'll find that the only existance of anything XCOM is more along the lines of an easter egg rather than an actual theme. (You hear many references to the SKYRANGER, but when you see it, the few chuckles you get are worth it).

get this game on sale, and play it - you'll enjoy it.

reviewText: who doesn't love 1960s cops?. Anyway, The Graphics were great, Gameplay was also great. There are actually some pretty cool upgrades, after you get your hands on enemy weaponry you can lift a target and have your squad gang up on him, or you can push them back with a burst of the outsider guns. Each Squad member has his own specialties like taunting, critical strike etc. which make it interesting to explore the potential of all squad members. The Controls were pretty simple i really enjoy the game. 8/10.

reviewText: So... What happens when an overly ambitious publishing house (Take Two Interactive) is jealous of the marketing potential of one of its development houses' franchises... And wants to milk the franchise more thoroughly/ more quickly than that franchises' home development house (Firaxis) is willing to? It hands the franchise over to one of its other development houses (2K Marin) and tells it to make a derivative product that by-and-large is derivative at-best, and delivers no unqiue value... But manages to grab more money more quickly from unsuspecting fanboys of the franchise.\n\nThat's what The Bureau: XCOM Declassified" is
recommended: though... The game is good enough in its own right for me to not completely feel as is I've been screwed over twice. (Once by being hoodwinked
hoursPlayed: and twice by buying a bad game.)\n\nMake no mistake: this isn't XCOM
voteText: in the classical sense. Instead
helpfulPercent: think of it as a complete mod for Mass Effect. That is... Mass Effect with an XCOM skin.\n\nCombat is *not* turn-based. Rather
votesHelpful: it is "real-time + bullet-time-style slow-down"  for sake of using special abilities (a la mass effect - complete with selection wheel and everything...). Time is *not* paused when in the selection wheel; rather
votesTotal: time is greatly reduced. Relative to "pure/true XCOM" games
votesFunny: strategy and item management are *greatly* simplified in favor of tactical gunplay. There's no base-building element at all. Weapon and gear are simplified
commentsCount:
relative to traditional XCOM games. Flanking/ hidden/ exposed attack bonuses are similar.

(Story-wise... This game is best considered a prequel to the XCOM series (I'm specifically thinking of XCOM: Enemy Unknown - don't have experience with the previous ones).)

Presuming one's expectations are "reset" with the above... I'd recommend purchasing this *at 50% or greater discount only* (not at full price). It *is* sufficiently immersive
column16: has a decent enough of a story line
column17: and a couple of neat twists... Such that it's worth playing through
column18: IMO. Although it has about the right playthrough timelength (when bought at discount)
column19: note that it has zero replay value. (IMO)\n\nSimply put... This game looks like (a "period-correct" variant of) XCOM
column20: and resembles XCOM... But it certainly doesn't *feel* like XCOM... And it sure as hell doesn't *play* like XCOM. Despite all of that
column21: however... It's worth a discount buy
column22: as it's not a bad game in its own right.\n\nI do wish they would have left the name "XCOM" out of the title
column23: though. It would have prevented some player disaapointments due to false expectations
column24: IMO."

reviewText:
This game isn't bad but it's not good either. The idea of mixing third person combat and RTS is interesting but it's execution is flawed.

Remeniscent of Mass Effect when it comes to exploring the main headquaters and interacting with some of the main characters. The narrative is very linear and full of cliches.

A similar sentiment I can share with are the characters. None of them stand out as relatable or even worth detailing. The fedoras had more character than the actual characters.

The gameplay at best is abysmal, the fusion of TPS and RTS do not mix at all. The games design isn't justifiable enough to have the word XCOM in it's name.

Also the games AI isn't.

Example: I ordered my engineer to approach some cover just outside an enemy position (the enemy took cover in a book store hiding behind shelves and the main counter). So in close quaters he would have a clear shot with his shotgun. That was what should have happened.

Instead he took cover in the store, in the middle of the enemy position, he was surrounded on all sides and within seconds he was killed.

It was tragic but hillarious. I could've saved him due to the bleed out mecahnic but I decided not to for the greater good.

A more appropriate title/name for this game would be The Bureau: Darwin Awards Declassified.

I only recommend this game because of the shenanigans the AI is capable of enacting.
But I would certainly recommend that you move straight onto Enemy Unknown.

reviewText:
This game gets a bad rep because it's not like other XCOM games.

Standing on it's own, this game is pretty darn good. If you are a Mass Effect I would definitely give this game a shot. The game play is engaging as you control your team in tactical fashion by way of pausing and giving orders.

You build your team and agents up throughout missions, even dispensing new recurits on their own misisons where they can gain experience and join you in future battles.

If you get caught in some mayhem and an agent on your team goes down, you'll fight for your life until the end of the battle at which point your trusted pilot Barnes will dispatch you a new recruit.

While the characters are quite thin, the dialog options terrible, the story hooks you in enough to enjoy the ride as you try to save the world.

This game is definitely underrated and far better than expected when giving the chance.

reviewText:
It is quite a pity that this game has such a low score on Metacritic...probably because most people expect it to play like the original XCOM...
Anyway, this is quite fun - the story is over the top and nonsensical until close to the end, where a few things are explained.
Regardless of that, though, combat is nice - you control yourself (3rd person) and 2 other agents against various groups of aliens. You fight in real time in the usual way - aim and shoot; and you can also go in a slow motion mode temporarily to issue orders to your squad, so that they can go into cover, focus on specific enemies, etc.
On top of the normal shooting mechanics, you and your squad level up" with experience and get perks
date: which make the combat a lot more interesting - for example by deploying turrets

reviewText:
I didn't expect much and was pleasantly surprised.

The gameplay:story ratio is good (i.e. you're not bogged down by too much story early on).
The combat is fun, it's actually like Mass Effect, but with more reliance on your team and on cover.

reviewText:
I didn't expect much and was pleasantly surprised.

The gameplay:story ratio is good (i.e. you're not bogged down by too much story early on).
The combat is fun, it's actually like Mass Effect, but with more reliance on your team and on cover.
The way you can give your squadmates orders feels more precise than in Mass Effect, esp. for AoE skills.
The game is gorgeous.

A thing that bothers me a bit is that the main missions become quite long, about 1 hour each and I'm also not a fan of running around so much in the base to get to the different people so I can talk to them (but that's optional anyway).

reviewText:
This is not a great game, just an almost good third person shooter with covers and idiot allies. Think of Gears of War in XCOM setting with stupid AI teammates whom you have to micromanage all the time.

Playing it on Commander (the highest difficulty) now, and the squad mates running into enemy grenades (or not able to run away from them) is the most frustrating thing. I have to micro manage those idiots and run away manually each time an alien throws a nade, and that's really annoying.

Another game breaker is that squad members just cannot stay behind the cover. They try to attack enemies and get shot in the face. And while you can run away from grenades, can't really do anything with this thing. There should've been agressive/passive behavior for allies and also simple commands like hold ground, stay in cover, etc. As it is, The Bureau is really bad in this regard.

However, the game becomes easier as agents get new abilities and you get accustomed to controls. On the lower difficulty settings you can even make mistakes and still win.

Overall, you can totally buy the game on sale just to walk the corridors of XCOM base and shoot aliens with plasma and laser weapons. But don't expect too much.

reviewText: Lackluster Alien Killing. Combat style of Mass Effect and facial structure / character depth of LA Noir. It's fun for bursts at a time the leveling system is alright but little is affected by picking different paths in the skill tree. Whatever perks you miss you can have another person pick up making your choices meaningless. With the difficulty set at its highest the AI is there however most of the difficulty comes from the nerf bullets that are placed in the gun in this setting. Lots of talking and paltry character background for some of the main characters but it all feels cliche, (e.g.), the main character is a lone gun who lost his family and blames himself. The nicest thing I can say about this game is how things react with nvidia physx turned up. Cloth moves properly and when doors fall apart it looks very nice. This doesn't happen much and it doesn't mean you can make your own path as you are shoved down this corridor into slightly different aliens. Being that this game is only a year old you would think the graphics would still be decent which they are but the same can be said for metro last light and that just got a graphics release meaning they both were not made to meet the demands of the pc gaming community. If you love other XCOM games this adds to the lore and is worth the time. If you are like me however and could take it or leave you will get bored with the occasional oh and aw of flashy explosions and hopes for a challenging situation only to be found forced through another beigh town, hallway, or steile enviornment with the same few enemies. 7/10 Average, boring with tight controls .

reviewText:
First of all, if you have played previous xcom games, this one is totally different. 3rd person shooter with tactics on combat. I enjoyed it a lot in my first walkthrough. The atmosphere is great, detailed enough, story based at 60's is really funny, reminding me old classic sci-fi/noir movies. The characters are also good.

The gameplay now is what you make it to be. You have 2 soldiers in your squad, who obey to your orders (well not always). You have some choices of what you want them to do. So you either just give orders and let them have their fun, or you grab your gun and kill every alien comes your way. You choose.

My overall rating:
PLUS:
-unique atmosphere, detailed enough with a great taste of old sci-fi and noir movies
-music
-missions

MINUS:
-gameplay's AI is bad (squad is basically dumb sometimes, in a ridiculus way)
-dialogs and story make in some points no sense at all
-graphics are good but with low fps (i think this has changed with a patch, i havent tried it yet)

So my rating: 7/10

reviewText:
I'm not very far into this yet and already I have tons of problems with it--problems that have nothing to do with X-Com loyalty. I'm not even that experienced with traditional X-Com. My problems stem from this being a very problematically designed tactical shooter with a story and writing that just doesn't add up...or make sense...or make me feel anything.

First off lets talk mechanics. As a tactical shooter, this game does at least try to bring more complexity to the genre, but that complexity is undermined by a control system that feels very loose and innacurate (I'm talking about aiming and shooting here). In addition to that, the AI of your companions leaves much to be desired.  Even when you are giving them orders regularly and changing their positions often, you will find that they are generally inneffective and frustrating to work with. I'm sure that they improve some as they level, but I doubt even then that it will totally solve how chaotically and unpredictably they behave.

As for the story, it is about as mediocre as they come. Neither the writing nor the cinematic presentation are very good at all. Often the cinematography and dialog are so bad that I have no idea what is happening. The result is a game that feels like it is coming apart at the seems. The presentation is so sloppy and disjointed that the only way anyone could possibly enjoy it is by not paying attention to it and filling in the blanks with their own imagination.

This game should have had it all for me. I am huge fan of retro science fiction worlds and X-Files-esque conspiracy laden story telling. Despite that, I can only express dissatisfaction with this game as a product. It is simply a broken, unpolished, cash-in by a company that should know better at this point. For shame 2K. For shame.

If you're just looking for a tactical shooter with a decent story, try Spec Ops: The Line instead. That game has an incredibly satisfying cinematic atmosphere, despite its tactical mechanics being simpler and more familiar. If you're looking for a good retro sci-fi game with aliens and government agents and all that stuff...well, tell me when you find one because I'd love to play it.

Who I'd recommend this for:
Virtually no one. This is one of those games that is only for people who have decided to like it before they ever even played it. If you're into the surfaces of the game world and have a lot of patience for poor mechanics, you might have a good time. If you're someone who is simply interested in playing bad games (and I say that earnestly because I do think there is nobility in that, especially for designers) you might want to give it a try as well, but I wouldn't pay full price if that's the case. Hell, I wouldn't even pay half price. I bought this game on sale for $15, and I wish I had waited until they were chuckin' it away for $5.
